verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:1
verses.text: Theodoret Dialogues:  Prologue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:2
verses.text: Some men, distinguished neither by family nor education, and without any of the honourable notoriety that comes of an upright life, are ambitious of achieving fame by wicked ways.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:3
verses.text: Of these was the famous Alexander, the coppersmith, a man of no sort of distinction at all,—no nobility of birth, no eloquence of speech, who never led a political party nor an army in the field; who never played the man in fight, but plied from day to day his ignominious craft, and won fame for nothing but his mad violence against Saint Paul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:4
verses.text: Shimei, again, an obscure person of servile rank, has become very renowned for his audacious attack on the holy David.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:5
verses.text: It is said too that the originator of the Manichaean heresy was a mere whipping-block of a slave, and, from love of notoriety, composed his execrable and superstitious writings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:6
verses.text: The same line of conduct is pursued by many now, who after turning their backs on the honourable glory of virtue on account of the toil to be undergone ere it be won, purchase to themselves the notoriety that comes of shame and disgrace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:7
verses.text: For through eagerness to pose as champions of new doctrines they pick up and get together the impiety of many heresies, and compile this heresy of death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:8
verses.text: Now I will endeavour briefly to dispute with them, with the double object of curing them, if I can, of their unsoundness, and of giving a word of warning to the whole.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:9
verses.text: I call my work "Eranistes, or Polymorphus," for, after getting together from many unhappy sources their baleful doctrines, they produce their patchwork and incongruous conceit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:10
verses.text: For to call our Lord Christ God only is the way of Simon, of Cerdo, of Marcion, and of others who share this abominable opinion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:11
verses.text: The acknowledgment of His birth from a Virgin, but coupled with the assertion that this birth was merely a process of transition, and that God the Word took nothing of the Virgin's nature, is stolen from Valentinus and Bardesanes and the adherents of their fables.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:12
verses.text: To call the godhead and the manhood of the Lord Christ one nature is the error filched from the follies of Apollinarius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:13
verses.text: Again the attribution of capacity of suffering to the divinity of the Christ is a theft from the blasphemy of Arius and Eunomius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:14
verses.text: Thus the main principle of their teaching is like beggars' gabardines—a cento of ill-matched rags.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:15
verses.text: So I call this work Eranistes or Polymorphus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:16
verses.text: I shall write it in the form of a dialogue with questions and answers, propositions, solutions, and antitheses, and all else that a dialogue ought to have.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:17
verses.text: I shall not insert the names of the questioners and respondents in the body of the dialogue as did the wise Greeks of old, but I shall write them at the side at the beginning of the paragraphs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:18
verses.text: They, indeed, put their writings in the hands of readers highly and variously educated, and to whom literature was life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:19
verses.text: I, on the contrary, wish the reading of what I write, and the discovery of whatever good it may give, to be an easy task, even to the illiterate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:20
verses.text: This I think will be facilitated if the characters of the interlocutors are plainly shown by their names in the margin, so the disputant who argues on behalf of the apostolical decrees is called "Orthodoxos," and his opponent "Eranistes".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:21
verses.text: A man who is fed by the charity of many we commonly call "Beggar;" a man who knows how to get money together we call a "Chrematistes".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:22
verses.text: So we have given our disputant this name from his character and pursuits.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:23
verses.text: I beg that all those into whose hands my book may fall will lay aside all preconceived opinion and put the truth to the test.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:24
verses.text: For clearness' sake I will divide my book into three dialogues.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:25
verses.text: The first will contain the contention that the Godhead of the only-begotten Son is immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:26
verses.text: The second will by God's help show that the union of the Godhead and the manhood of the Lord Christ is without confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:27
verses.text: The third will contend for the impassibility of the divinity of our saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 1:28
verses.text: After these three disputations we will subjoin several others as it were to complete them, giving formal proof under each head, and making it perfectly plain that the apostles' doctrine is preserved by us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:1
verses.text: Dialogue I.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:2
verses.text: —The Immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:3
verses.text: Orthodoxos and Eranistes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:4
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:5
verses.text: —Better were it for us to agree and abide by the apostolic doctrine in its purity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:6
verses.text: But since, I know not how, you have broken the harmony, and are now offering us new doctrines, let us, if you please, with no kind of quarrel, investigate the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:7
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:8
verses.text: —We need no investigation, for we exactly hold the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:9
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:10
verses.text: —This is what every heretic supposes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:11
verses.text: Aye, even Jews and Pagans reckon that they are defending the doctrines of the truth; and so also do not only the followers of Plato and Pythagoras, but Epicureans too, and they that are wholly without God or belief.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:12
verses.text: It becomes us, however, not to be the slaves of a priori assumption, but to search for the knowledge of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:13
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:14
verses.text: —I admit the force of what you say and am ready to act on your suggestion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:15
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:16
verses.text: —Since then you have made no difficulty in yielding to this my preliminary exhortation, I ask you in the next place not to suffer the investigation of the truth to depend on the reasonings of men, but to track the footprints of the apostles and prophets, and saints who followed them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:17
verses.text: For so wayfarers when they wander from the high-road are wont to consider well the pathways, if haply they shew any prints of men or horses or asses or mules going this way or that, and when they find any such they trace the tracks as dogs do and leave them not till once more they are in the right road.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:18
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:19
verses.text: —So let us do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:20
verses.text: Lead on yourself, as you began the discussion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:21
verses.text: Orth—Let us, therefore, first make careful and thorough investigation into the divine names,—I mean substance, and essences, and persons and proprieties, and let us learn and define how they differ the one from the other.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:22
verses.text: Then let us thus handle afterwards what follows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:23
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:24
verses.text: —You give us a very admirable and proper introduction to our argument.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:25
verses.text: When these points are clear, our discussion will go forward without let or obstacle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:26
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:27
verses.text: —Since we have decided then that this must be our course of procedure, tell me, my friend, do we acknowledge one substance of God, alike of Father and of the only begotten Son and of the Holy Ghost, as we have been taught by Holy Scripture, both Old and New, and by the Fathers in Council in Nicaea, or do we follow the blasphemy of Arius?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:28
verses.text: —We confess one substance of the Holy Trinity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:29
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:30
verses.text: —And do we reckon hypostasis to signify anything else than substance, or do we take it for another name of substance?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:31
verses.text: —Is there any difference between substance and hypostasis?  Orth—In extra Christian philosophy there is not, for οὐσία signifies τὸ ὄν, that which is, and ὑπόστασις that which subsists.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:32
verses.text: But according to the doctrine of the Fathers there is the same difference between οὐσία and ὑπόστασις as between the common and the particular, and the species and the individual.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:33
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:34
verses.text: —Tell me more clearly what is meant by race or kind, and species and individual.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:35
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:36
verses.text: —We speak of race or kind with regard to the animal, for it means many things at once.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:37
verses.text: It indicates both the rational and the irrational; and again there are many species of irrational, creatures that fly, creatures that are amphibious, creatures that go on foot, and creatures that swim.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:38
verses.text: And of these species each is marked by many subdivisions; of creatures that go on foot there is the lion, the leopard, the bull, and countless others.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:39
verses.text: So, too, of flying creatures and the rest there are many species; yet all of them, though the species are the aforesaid, belong to one and the same animal race.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:40
verses.text: Similarly the name man is the common name of mankind; for it means the Roman, the Athenian, the Persian, the Sauromatian, the Egyptian, and, in a word, all who are human, but the name Paulus or Petrus does not signify what is common to the kind but some particular man; for no one on hearing of Paul turns in thought to Adam or Abraham or Jacob, but thinks of him alone whose name he has heard.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:41
verses.text: But if he hears the word man simply, he does not fix his mind on the individual, but bethinks him of the Indian, the Scythian, and the Massagete, and of all the race of men together, and we learn this not only from nature, but also from Holy Scripture, for God said, we read, "I will destroy man from the face of the earth," and this he spake of countless multitudes, and when more than two thousand and two hundred years had gone by after Adam, he brought universal destruction on men through the flood, and so the blessed David says: "Man that is in honour and understandeth not," accusing not one here nor one there, but all men in common.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:42
verses.text: A thousand similar examples might be found, but we must not be tedious.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:43
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:44
verses.text: —The difference between the common and the proper is shewed clearly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:45
verses.text: Now let us return to discussion about οὐσία and ὑπόστασις  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:46
verses.text: —As then the name man is common to human nature, so we understand the divine substance to indicate the Holy Trinity; but the hypostasis denotes any person, as the Father, the Son and the Holy Ghost; for, following the definitions of the Holy Fathers, we say that hypostasis and individuality mean the same thing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:47
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:48
verses.text: —We agree that this is so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:49
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:50
verses.text: —Whatever then is predicated of the divine nature is common both to the Father, to the Son, and to the Holy Ghost, as for instance "God," "Lord," "Creator," "Almighty," and so forth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:51
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:52
verses.text: —Without question these words are common to the Trinity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:53
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:54
verses.text: —But all that naturally denotes the hypostasis ceases to be common to the Holy Trinity, and denotes the hypostasis to which it is proper, as, for instance, the names "Father," "Unbegotten," are peculiar to the Father; while again the names "Son," "Only Begotten," "God the Word," do not denote the Father, nor yet the Holy Ghost, but the Son, and the words "Holy Ghost," "Paraclete," naturally denote the hypostasis of the Spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:55
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:56
verses.text: —But does not Holy Scripture call both the Father and the Son "Spirit"?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:57
verses.text: —Yes, it calls both the Father and the Son "Spirit," signifying by this term the incorporeal illimitable character of the divine nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:58
verses.text: The Holy Scripture only calls the hypostasis of the Spirit "Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:59
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:60
verses.text: —This is indisputable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:61
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:62
verses.text: —Since then we assert that some terms are common to the Holy Trinity, and some peculiar to each hypostasis, do we assert the term "immutable" to be common to the substance or peculiar to any hypostasis?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:63
verses.text: —The term "immutable" is common to the Trinity, for it is impossible for part of the substance to be mutable and part immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:64
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:65
verses.text: —You have well said, for as the term mortal is common to mankind, so are "immutable" and "invariable" to the Holy Trinity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:66
verses.text: So the only-begotten Son is immutable, as are both the Father that begat Him and the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:67
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:68
verses.text: —Immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:69
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:70
verses.text: —How then do you advance the statement in the gospel "the word became flesh," and predicate mutation of the immutable nature?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:71
verses.text: —We assert Him to have been made flesh not by mutation, but as He Himself knows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:72
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:73
verses.text: —If He is not said to have become flesh by taking flesh, one of two things must be asserted, either that he underwent the mutation into flesh, or was only so seen in appearance, and in reality was God without flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:74
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:75
verses.text: —This is the doctrine of the disciples of Valentinus, Marcion, and of the Manichees, but we have been taught without dispute that the divine Word was made flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:76
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:77
verses.text: —But in what sense do you mean "was made flesh"? "Took flesh," or "was changed into flesh"?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:78
verses.text: —As we have heard the evangelist say, "the word was made flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:79
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:80
verses.text: —In what sense do you understand "was made"?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:81
verses.text: —He who underwent mutation into flesh was made flesh, and, as I said just now, as He knows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:82
verses.text: But we know that with Him all things are possible, for He changed the water of the Nile into blood, and day into night, and made the sea dry land, and filled the dry wilderness with water, and we hear the prophet saying "Whatsoever the Lord pleased that did He in heaven, and in earth, in the seas and all deep places".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:83
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:84
verses.text: —The creature is transformed by the Creator as He will, for it is mutable and obeys the nod of Him that fashioned it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:85
verses.text: But His nature is immutable and invariable, wherefore of the creature the prophet saith "He that maketh and transformeth all things".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:86
verses.text: But of the divine Word the great David says "Thou art the same and thy years shall not fail".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:87
verses.text: And again the same God says of Himself "For I am the Lord and I change not".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:88
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:89
verses.text: —What is hidden ought not to "be enquired into".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:90
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:91
verses.text: —Nor yet what is plain to be altogether ignored.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:92
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:93
verses.text: —I am not aware of the manner of the incarnation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:94
verses.text: I have heard that the Word was made flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:95
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:96
verses.text: —If He was made flesh by mutation He did not remain what He was before, and this is easily intelligible from several analogies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:97
verses.text: Sand, for instance, when it is subjected to heat, first becomes fluid, then is changed and congealed into glass, and at the time of the change alters its name, for it is no longer called sand but glass.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:98
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:99
verses.text: —So it is.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:100
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:101
verses.text: —And while we call the fruit of the vine grape, when once we have pressed it, we speak of it no longer as grape, but as wine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:102
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:103
verses.text: —Certainly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:104
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:105
verses.text: —And the wine itself, after it has undergone a change, it is our custom to name no longer wine, but vinegar.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:106
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:107
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:108
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:109
verses.text: —And similarly stone when burnt and in solution is no longer called stone, but lime.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:110
verses.text: And innumerable other similar instances might be found where mutation involves a change of name.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:111
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:112
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:113
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:114
verses.text: —If therefore you assert that the Divine Word underwent the change in the flesh, why do you call Him God and not flesh? for change of name fits in with the alteration of nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:115
verses.text: For if where the things which undergo change have some relation to their former condition (for there is a certain approximation of vinegar to wine and of wine to the fruit of the vine, and of glass to sand) they receive another name after their alteration, how, where the difference between them is infinite and as wide as that which divides a gnat from the whole visible and invisible creation (for so wide, nay much wider, is the difference between the nature of flesh and of Godhead) is it possible for the same name to obtain after the change?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:116
verses.text: —I have said more than once that He was made flesh not by mutation, but continuing still to be what He was, He was made what He was not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:117
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:118
verses.text: —But unless this word "was made" becomes quite clear it suggests mutation and alteration, for unless He was made flesh by taking flesh He was made flesh by undergoing mutation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:119
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:120
verses.text: —But the word "take" is your own invention.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:121
verses.text: The Evangelist says the Word was made flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:122
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:123
verses.text: —You seem either to be ignorant of the sacred Scripture, or to do it wrong knowingly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:124
verses.text: Now if you are ignorant, I will teach you; if you are doing wrong, I will convict you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:125
verses.text: Answer then; do you acknowledge the teaching of the divine Paul to be of the Spirit?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:126
verses.text: —Certainly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:127
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:128
verses.text: —And do you allow that the same Spirit wrought through both Evangelists and Apostles?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:129
verses.text: —Yes, for so have I learnt from the Apostolic Scripture "There are diversities of gifts but the same spirit," and again "All these things worketh that one and the selfsame spirit, dividing to every man severally as He will," and again "Having the same Spirit of the Faith".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:130
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:131
verses.text: —Your introduction of the apostolic testimony is in season.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:132
verses.text: If we assert that the instruction alike of the evangelists and of the apostles is of the same spirit, listen how the apostle interprets the words of the Gospel, for in the Epistle to the Hebrews he says, "Verily he took not on him the nature of angels, but he took on him the seed of Abraham".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:133
verses.text: Now tell me what you mean by the seed of Abraham.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:134
verses.text: Was not that which was naturally proper to Abraham proper also to the seed of Abraham?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:135
verses.text: —No; not without exception, for Christ did no sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:136
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:137
verses.text: —Sin is not of nature, but of corrupt will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:138
verses.text: On this very account, therefore, I did not say indefinitely what Abraham had, but what he had according to nature, that is to say, body and reasonable soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:139
verses.text: Now tell me plainly; will you acknowledge that the seed of Abraham was endowed with body and reasonable soul? If not, in this point you agree with the ravings of Apollinarius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:140
verses.text: But I will compel you to confess this by other means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:141
verses.text: Tell me now; had the Jews a body and a reasonable soul?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:142
verses.text: —Of course they had.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:143
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:144
verses.text: —So when we hear the prophet saying, "But thou, Israel, art my servant, Jacob whom I have chosen, the seed of Abraham my friend," are we to understand the Jews to be bodies only? Are we not to understand them to be men consisting of bodies and souls?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:145
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:146
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:147
verses.text: —And the seed of Abraham not without soul nor yet intelligence, but with everything which characterizes the seed of Abraham?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:148
verses.text: —He who so says puts forward two sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:149
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:150
verses.text: —But he who says that the Divine Word is changed into the flesh does not even acknowledge one Son, for mere flesh by itself is not a son; but we confess one Son who took upon Him the seed of Abraham, according to the divine apostle, and wrought the salvation of mankind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:151
verses.text: But if you do not accept the apostolic preaching, say so openly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:152
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:153
verses.text: —But we maintain that the utterances of the apostles are inconsistent, for there appears to be a certain inconsistency between "the Word was made flesh" and "took upon Him the seed of Abraham".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:154
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:155
verses.text: —It is because you lack intelligence, or because you are arguing for arguing's sake, that the consistent seems inconsistent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:156
verses.text: It does not so appear to men who use sound reasoning; for the divine apostle teaches that the Divine Word was made Flesh, not by mutation, but by taking on Him the seed of Abraham.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:157
verses.text: At the same time, too, he recalls the promise given to Abraham.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:158
verses.text: Or do you not remember the promises given to the Patriarch by the God of the Universe?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:159
verses.text: —What promises?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:160
verses.text: —When He brought him out of his father's house, and ordered him to come into Palestine, did He not say to him "I will bless them that bless thee, and curse him that curseth thee, and in thy seed shall all families of the earth be blessed"?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:161
verses.text: —I remember these promises.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:162
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:163
verses.text: —Remember, too, the covenants made by God with Isaac and Jacob, for He gave them, too, the same promises, confirming the former by the second and the third.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:164
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:165
verses.text: —I remember them too.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:166
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:167
verses.text: —It is in relation to these covenants that the divine apostle writes in his Epistle to the Galatians "Now to Abraham and his seed were the promises made".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:168
verses.text: He saith not "seeds" as of many, but as of one…which is Christ, very plainly showing that the manhood of Christ sprang from the seed of Abraham, and fulfilled the promise made to Abraham.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:169
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:170
verses.text: —So the apostle says.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:171
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:172
verses.text: —Enough has been said to remove all the controversy raised on this point.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:173
verses.text: But I will nevertheless remind you of another prediction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:174
verses.text: The blessing given to the Patriarch Jacob and to his father and his grandfather was given by him to his son Judah alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:175
verses.text: He said "A Prince shall not fail Judah, nor a leader from his loins, until he shall have come to whom it is in store, and he is the expectation of the Gentiles".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:176
verses.text: Or do you not accept this prediction as spoken of the Saviour Christ?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:177
verses.text: —Jews give erroneous interpretations of prophecies of this kind, but I am a Christian; I trust in the Divine word; and I receive the prophecies without doubt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:178
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:179
verses.text: —Since then you confess that you believe the prophecies and acknowledge the predictions have been divinely uttered about our Saviour, consider what follows as to the intention of the words of the apostle, for while pointing out that the promises made to the patriarchs have reached their fulfilment, he uttered those remarkable words "He took not on Him the nature of angels," all but saying the promise is true; the Lord has fulfilled His pledges; the fount of blessing is open to the gentiles; God had taken on Him the seed of Abraham; through it He brings about the promised salvation; through it He confirms the promise of the gentiles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:180
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:181
verses.text: —The words of the Prophet fit in admirably with those of the apostle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:182
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:183
verses.text: —So again the divine apostle, reminding us of the blessing of Judah, and pointing out how it received its fulfilment exclaims "For it is evident that our Lord sprang out of Judah".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:184
verses.text: So too the Prophet Micah and the evangelist Matthew.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:185
verses.text: For the former spoke his prediction, and the latter connects the prophecy with his narrative.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:186
verses.text: What is extraordinary is that he says that the open enemies of the truth plainly told Herod that the Christ is born in Bethlehem, for it is written, he says, "And thou Bethlehem in the land of Judah art not the least among the Princes of Judah for out of thee shall come a Governor who shall rule my people Israel".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:187
verses.text: Now let us subjoin what the Jews in their malignity omitted and so made the witness imperfect.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:188
verses.text: For the prophet, after saying "Out of thee shall he come forth unto me that is to be Ruler in Israel" adds "Whose goings forth have been of old, from everlasting".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:189
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:190
verses.text: —You have done well in adducing the whole evidence of the Prophet, for he points out that He who was born in Bethlehem was God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:191
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:192
verses.text: —Not God only but also Man; Man as sprung from Judah after the flesh and born in Bethlehem; and God as existing before the ages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:193
verses.text: For the words "Out of thee shall he come forth unto me that is to be Ruler," shew his birth after the flesh which has taken place in the last days; while the words "Whose goings forth have been of old, from everlasting" plainly proclaim His existence before the ages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:194
verses.text: In like manner also the divine apostle in his Epistle to the Romans bewailing the change to the worse of the ancient felicity of the Jews, and calling to mind their divine promises and legislation, goes on to say "Whose are the fathers, and of whom concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over all God blessed for ever Amen," and in this same passage he exhibits Him both as Creator of all things and Lord and Ruler as God and as sprung from the Jews as man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:195
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:196
verses.text: —Well; you have explained these passages, what should you say to the prophecy of Jeremiah? For this proclaims him to be God only.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:197
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:198
verses.text: —Of what prophecy do you speak?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:199
verses.text: —"This is our God and there shall none other be accounted of in comparison to him—he hath found out all the way of knowledge, and hath given it unto Jacob his servant and to Israel his beloved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:200
verses.text: Afterward did he shew himself upon earth and conversed with men".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:201
verses.text: In these words the Prophet speaks neither of the flesh, nor of manhood, nor of man, but of God alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:202
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:203
verses.text: —What then is the good of reasoning? Do we say that the Divine nature is invisible? or do we dissent from the Apostle when he says "Immortal, invisible, the only God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:204
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:205
verses.text: —Indubitably the Divine nature is invisible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:206
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:207
verses.text: —How then was it possible for the invisible nature to be seen without a body? Or do you not remember those words of the apostle in which he distinctly teaches the invisibility of the divine nature? He says "Whom no man hath seen nor can see".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:208
verses.text: If therefore the Divine Nature is invisible to men, and I will add too to Angels, tell me how he who cannot be seen or beheld was seen upon earth?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:209
verses.text: —The Prophet says he was seen on the earth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:210
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:211
verses.text: —And the apostle says "Immortal, invisible, the only God" and "Whom no man hath seen and can see".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:212
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:213
verses.text: —What then? is the Prophet lying?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:214
verses.text: —God forbid.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:215
verses.text: Both utterances are the words of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:216
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:217
verses.text: —Let us inquire then how the invisible was seen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:218
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:219
verses.text: —Do not, I beg you, bring in human reason.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:220
verses.text: I shall yield to scripture alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:221
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:222
verses.text: —You shall receive no argument unconfirmed by Holy Scripture, and if you bring me any solution of the question deduced from Holy Scripture I will receive it, and will in no wise gainsay it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:223
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:224
verses.text: —You know how a moment ago we made the word of the evangelist clear by means of the testimony of the apostle; and that the divine apostle showed us how the Word became Flesh, saying plainly "for verily He took not on Him the nature of angels but He took on Him the seed of Abraham".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:225
verses.text: The same teacher will teach us how the divine Word was seen upon the earth and dwelt among men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:226
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:227
verses.text: —I submit to the words both of apostles and of prophets.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:228
verses.text: Shew me then in accordance with your promise the interpretation of the prophecy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:229
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:230
verses.text: —The divine apostle, writing to Timothy, also says "without controversy great is the mystery of godliness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:231
verses.text: God was manifest in the flesh, justified in the spirit, seen of angels, preached unto the Gentiles, believed on in the world, received up into glory".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:232
verses.text: It is therefore plain that the divine nature is invisible, but the flesh visible, and that through the visible the invisible was seen, by its means working wonders and unveiling its own power, for with the hand He fashioned the sense of seeing and healed him that was blind from birth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:233
verses.text: Again He gave the power of hearing to the deaf, and loosed the fettered tongue, using his fingers for a tool and applying his spittle like some healing medicine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:234
verses.text: So again when He walked upon the sea He displayed the almighty power of the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:235
verses.text: Fitly, therefore, did the apostle say "God was manifest in the flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:236
verses.text: For through it appeared the invisible nature beheld by its means by the angel hosts, for "He was seen," he says, "of angels".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:237
verses.text: The nature then of bodiless beings has shared with us the enjoyment of this boon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:238
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:239
verses.text: —Then did not the angels see God before the manifestation of the Saviour?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:240
verses.text: —The apostle says that He "was made manifest in the flesh and seen of angels".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:241
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:242
verses.text: —But the Lord said, "Take heed that ye despise not one of these little ones, for I say unto you that their angels do always behold the face of my Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:243
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:244
verses.text: —But the Lord said again, "Not that any man hath seen the Father save he which is of God, he hath seen the Father".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:245
verses.text: Wherefore the evangelist plainly exclaims, "No man hath seen God at any time," and confirms the word of the Lord, for he says, "The only begotten Son which is in the bosom of the Father He hath declared Him," and the great Moses, when he desired to see the invisible nature, heard the Lord God saying, "There shall no man see me and live".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:246
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:247
verses.text: —How then are we to understand the words, "Their angels do always behold the face of my Father which is in heaven"?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:248
verses.text: —Just as we commonly understand what is said about men who have been supposed to see God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:249
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:250
verses.text: —Pray make this plainer, for I do not understand.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:251
verses.text: Can God be seen of men also?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:252
verses.text: —Certainly not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:253
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:254
verses.text: —Yet we hear the divine scripture saying God appeared unto Abraham at the oak of Mamre; and Isaiah says "I saw the Lord sitting upon a throne high and lifted up," and the same thing is said by Micah, by Daniel and Ezekiel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:255
verses.text: And of the lawgiver Moses it is related that "The Lord spake to Moses face to face as a man speaketh unto his friend," and the God of the universe Himself said, "With him will I speak mouth to mouth, even apparently and not in dark speeches".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:256
verses.text: What then shall we say; did they behold the divine nature?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:257
verses.text: —By no means, for God Himself said, "There shall no man see me and live".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:258
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:259
verses.text: —Then they who say that they have seen God are liars?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:260
verses.text: —God forbid—they saw what it was possible for them to see.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:261
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:262
verses.text: —Then the loving Lord accommodates his revelation to the capacity of them that see Him?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:263
verses.text: —Yes; and this He has shewn through the Prophet, "for I," He says, "have multiplied visions and by the hands of the Prophets was made like".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:264
verses.text: He does not say "was seen" but "was made like".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:265
verses.text: And making like does not shew the very nature of the thing seen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:266
verses.text: For even the image of the emperor does not exhibit the emperor's nature, though it distinctly preserves his features.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:267
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:268
verses.text: —This is obscure and not sufficiently plain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:269
verses.text: Was not then the substance of God seen by them who beheld those revelations?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:270
verses.text: —No; for who is mad enough to dare to say so?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:271
verses.text: —But yet it is said that they saw.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:272
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:273
verses.text: —Yes; it is said; but we both in the exercise of reverent reason, and in reliance on the Divine utterances, which exclaim distinctly, "No man hath seen God at any time," affirm that they did not see the Divine Nature, but certain visions adapted to their capacity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:274
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:275
verses.text: —So we say.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:276
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:277
verses.text: —So also then let us understand of the angels when we hear that they daily see the face of your Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:278
verses.text: For what they see is not the divine substance which cannot be circumscribed, comprehended, or apprehended, which embraces the universe, but some glory made commensurate with their nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:279
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:280
verses.text: —This is acknowledged.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:281
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:282
verses.text: —After the incarnation, however, He was seen also of angels, as the divine apostle says, not however by similitude of glory, but using the true and living covering of the flesh as a kind of screen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:283
verses.text: "God," he says, "was made manifest in the flesh, justified in the Spirit, seen of angels".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:284
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:285
verses.text: —I accept this as Scripture, but I am not prepared to accept the novelties of phrase.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:286
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:287
verses.text: —What novelties of phrase have we introduced?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:288
verses.text: —That of the "screen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:289
verses.text: What Scripture calls the flesh of the Lord a screen?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:290
verses.text: —You do not seem to be a very diligent reader of your Bible; if you had been you would not have found fault with what we have said as in a figure.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:291
verses.text: For first of all the fact that the divine apostle says that the invisible nature was made manifest through the flesh allows us to understand the flesh as a screen of the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:292
verses.text: Secondly, the divine apostle in his Epistle to the Hebrews, distinctly uses the phrase, for he says, "Having therefore, brethren, boldness to enter into the Holiest by the blood of Jesus by a new and living way, which he hath consecrated for us, through the veil, that is to say his flesh; and having an High Priest over the House of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:293
verses.text: Coming with truth drawing near with a true heart in fulness of faith".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:294
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:295
verses.text: —Your demonstration is unanswerable, for it is based on apostolic authority.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:296
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:297
verses.text: —Do not then charge us with innovation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:298
verses.text: We will adduce for you yet another prophetic authority, distinctly calling the Lord's flesh a robe and mantle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:299
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:300
verses.text: —Should it not appear obscure and ambiguous we will say nothing against it, and be thankful for it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:301
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:302
verses.text: —I will make you yourself testify to the truth of the promise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:303
verses.text: You know how the Patriarch Jacob, when he was addressing Judah, limited the sovereignty of Judah by the birth of the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:304
verses.text: "A prince shall not fail Judah, nor a leader from his loins until he shall have come to whom it is in store and he is the expectation of the Gentiles".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:305
verses.text: You have already confessed that this prophecy was uttered about the saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:306
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:307
verses.text: —I have.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:308
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:309
verses.text: —Remember then what follows; for he says "And unto him shall the gathering of the people be…he shall wash his robe in wine and his mantle in the blood of the grape".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:310
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:311
verses.text: —The Patriarch spoke of garments, not of a body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:312
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:313
verses.text: —Tell me, then, when or where he washed his cloak in the blood of the grape?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:314
verses.text: —Nay; tell me you when he reddened his body in it?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:315
verses.text: —Answer I beseech you more reverently.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:316
verses.text: Perhaps some of the uninitiated are within hearing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:317
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:318
verses.text: —I will both hear and answer in mystic language.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:319
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:320
verses.text: —You know that the Lord called himself a vine?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:321
verses.text: —Yes I know that he said "I am the true vine".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:322
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:323
verses.text: —Now what is the fruit of a vine called after it is pressed?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:324
verses.text: —It is called wine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:325
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:326
verses.text: —When the soldiers wounded the Saviour's side with the spear, what did the evangelist say was poured out from it?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:327
verses.text: —Blood and water.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:328
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:329
verses.text: —Well, then; he called the Saviour's blood blood of the grape, for if the Lord is called a vine, and the fruit of the vine wine, and from the Lord's side streams of blood and water flowed downwards over the rest of his body, fitly and appropriately the Patriarch foretells "He shall wash his robe in wine and his mantle in blood of the grape".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:330
verses.text: For as we after the consecration call the mystic fruit of the vine the Lord's blood, so he called the blood of the true vine blood of the grape.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:331
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:332
verses.text: —The point before us has been set forth in language at once mystical and clear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:333
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:334
verses.text: —Although what has been said is enough for your faith, I will, for confirmation of the faith, give you yet another proof.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:335
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:336
verses.text: —I shall be grateful to you for so doing, for you will increase the favour done me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:337
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:338
verses.text: —You know how God called His own body bread?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:339
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:340
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:341
verses.text: —And how in another place he called His flesh corn?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:342
verses.text: —Yes, I know.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:343
verses.text: For I have heard Him saying "The hour is come that the Son of man should be glorified," and "Except a corn of wheat fall into the ground and die, it abideth alone; but if it die it bringeth forth much fruit".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:344
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:345
verses.text: —Yes; and in the giving of the mysteries He called the bread, body, and what had been mixed, blood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:346
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:347
verses.text: —He so did.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:348
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:349
verses.text: —Yet naturally the body would properly be called body, and the blood, blood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:350
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:351
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:352
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:353
verses.text: —But our Saviour changed the names, and to His body gave the name of the symbol and to the symbol that of his body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:354
verses.text: So, after calling himself a vine, he spoke of the symbol as blood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:355
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:356
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:357
verses.text: But I am desirous of knowing the reason of the change of names.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:358
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:359
verses.text: —To them that are initiated in divine things the intention is plain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:360
verses.text: For he wished the partakers in the divine mysteries not to give heed to the nature of the visible objects, but, by means of the variation of the names, to believe the change wrought of grace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:361
verses.text: For He, we know, who spoke of his natural body as corn and bread, and, again, called Himself a vine, dignified the visible symbols by the appellation of the body and blood, not because He had changed their nature, but because to their nature He had added grace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:362
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:363
verses.text: —The mysteries are spoken of in mystic language, and there is a clear declaration of that which is not known to all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:364
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:365
verses.text: —Since then it is agreed that the body of the Lord is called by the patriarch "robe" and "mantle" and we have reached the discussion of the divine mysteries, tell me truly, of what do you understand the Holy Food to be a symbol and type? Of the godhead of the Lord Christ, or of His body and His blood?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:366
verses.text: —Plainly of those things of which they received the names.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:367
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:368
verses.text: —You mean of the body and of the blood?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:369
verses.text: —I do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:370
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:371
verses.text: —You have spoken as a lover of truth should speak, for when the Lord had taken the symbol, He did not say "this is my godhead," but "this is my body;" and again "this is my blood" and in another place "the bread that I will give is my flesh which I will give for the life of the world".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:372
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:373
verses.text: —These words are true, for they are the divine oracles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:374
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:375
verses.text: —If then they are true, I suppose the Lord had a body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:376
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:377
verses.text: —No; for I maintain him to be bodiless.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:378
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:379
verses.text: —But you confess that He had a body?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:380
verses.text: —I say that the Word was made flesh, for so I have been taught.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:381
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:382
verses.text: —It seems, as the proverb has it, as if we are drawing water in a pail with a hole in it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:383
verses.text: For after all our demonstrations and solutions of difficulties, you are bringing the same arguments round again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:384
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:385
verses.text: —I am not giving you my arguments, but those of the gospels.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:386
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:387
verses.text: —And have I not given you the interpretation of the words of the gospels from those of prophets and apostles?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:388
verses.text: —They do not serve to clear up the point at issue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:389
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:390
verses.text: —And yet we shewed how, being invisible, He was made manifest through flesh, and the relationship of this very flesh we have been taught by the sacred writers—"He took on Him the seed of Abraham".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:391
verses.text: And the Lord God said to the patriarch, "in thy seed shall all the nations of the earth be blessed," and the apostle, "It is evident our Lord sprang out of Judah".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:392
verses.text: We adduced further several similar testimonies; but, since you are desirous of hearing yet others, listen to the apostle when he says, "For every high priest taken from among men is ordained that he may offer both gifts and sacrifices, wherefore it is of necessity that this man have somewhat also to offer".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:393
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:394
verses.text: —Point out, then, how He offered after taking a body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:395
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:396
verses.text: —The divine apostle himself clearly teaches in the very passage, for after a few words he says: "Wherefore, when He cometh into the world, He saith, sacrifice and offering thou wouldst not, but a body hast thou prepared me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:397
verses.text: He does not say "into a body hast thou changed," but "a body hast thou prepared," and he shows plainly that the formation of the body was wrought by the Spirit in accordance with the utterance of the gospel, "Fear not to take unto thee Mary thy wife; for that which is generated in her is of the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:398
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:399
verses.text: —The virgin then gave birth only to a body?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:400
verses.text: —It appears that you do not even understand the composition of words, much less their meaning, for he is teaching Joseph the manner, not of the generation, but of the conception.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:401
verses.text: For he does not say that which is generated of her, i-e: made, or formed, is of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:402
verses.text: Joseph, ignorant of the mystery, was suspicions of adultery; he was therefore plainly taught the formation by the Spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:403
verses.text: It is this which He signified through the prophet when He said "A body hast thou prepared me" for the divine Apostle being full of the Spirit interpreted the prediction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:404
verses.text: If then the offering of gifts is the special function of priests and Christ in His humanity was called priest and offered no other sacrifice save His own body, then the Lord Christ had a body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:405
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:406
verses.text: —This even I have repeatedly affirmed, and I do not say that the divine Word appeared without a body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:407
verses.text: What I maintain is not that He took a body but that He was made flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:408
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:409
verses.text: —So far as I see our contest lies with the supporters of Valentinus, of Marcion, and of Manes; but even they never had the hardihood to say that the immutable nature underwent mutation into flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:410
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:411
verses.text: —Reviling is unchristian.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:412
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:413
verses.text: —We do not revile, but we are fighting for truth, and we are vexed at your arguing about the indisputable as though it could be disputed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:414
verses.text: However, I will endeavour to put an end to your ungracious contention.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:415
verses.text: Answer now; do you remember the promises which God made to David?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:416
verses.text: —Which?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:417
verses.text: —Those which the prophet inserted in the th Psalm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:418
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:419
verses.text: —I know that many promises were made to David.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:420
verses.text: Which are you enquiring about now?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:421
verses.text: —Those which refer to the Lord Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:422
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:423
verses.text: —Recall the utterances yourself, for you promised to adduce your proofs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:424
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:425
verses.text: —Listen now how the prophet praises God at the very beginning of the Psalm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:426
verses.text: He saw with his prophetic eyes the future iniquity of his people, and the captivity that was in consequence foredoomed; yet he praised his own Lord for unfailing promises.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:427
verses.text: "I will sing," he says, "of the mercies of the Lord forever, with my mouth will I make known Thy faithfulness to all generations, for thou hast said, Mercy shall be built up for ever, Thy faithfulness shalt Thou establish in the very heavens".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:428
verses.text: Through all this the prophet teaches that the promise was made by God on account of lovingkindness, and that the promise is faithful.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:429
verses.text: Then he goes on to say what He promised, and to whom, introducing God Himself as the speaker.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:430
verses.text: ("I have made a covenant with my chosen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:431
verses.text: ) It is the Patriarchs that He called chosen; then He goes on "I have sworn unto David my servant," and He states concerning what He swore, "Thy seed will I establish for ever, and build up thy throne to all generations".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:432
verses.text: Now whom do you suppose to be called the seed of David?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:433
verses.text: —The promise was made about Solomon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:434
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:435
verses.text: —Then he made his covenant with the Patriarchs about Solomon, for before what was said about David he mentioned the promises made to the Patriarchs "I have made a covenant with my chosen," and He promised the Patriarchs that in their seed He would bless all nations.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:436
verses.text: Kindly point out how the nations were blessed through Solomon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:437
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:438
verses.text: —Then God fulfilled this promise, not by means of Solomon, but of our Saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:439
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:440
verses.text: —So then our Lord Christ gave the fulfilment to the promises made to David.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:441
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:442
verses.text: —I hold that these promises were made by God, either about Solomon, or about Zerubbabel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:443
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:444
verses.text: —Just now you used the arguments of Marcion and Valentinus and of Manes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:445
verses.text: Now you have gone over to the directly opposite faction, and are advocating the impudence of the Jews.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:446
verses.text: This is just like all those who turn out of a straight road; they err and stray first one way and then another, wandering in a wilderness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:447
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:448
verses.text: —Revilers are excluded by the Apostle from the kingdom.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:449
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:450
verses.text: —Yes, if their revilings are vain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:451
verses.text: Sometimes the divine Apostle himself opportunely uses this mode of speech.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:452
verses.text: He calls the Galatians "foolish," and of others he says "men of corrupt minds, reprobate concerning the faith," and again of another set, "Whose God is their belly, whose glory is in their shame," and so forth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:453
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:454
verses.text: —What occasion did I give you for reviling?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:455
verses.text: —Do you really not think that the willing advocacy of the declared enemies of the truth furnishes the pious with very reasonable ground of indignation?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:456
verses.text: —And what enemies of the truth have I patronized?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:457
verses.text: —Now, Jews.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:458
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:459
verses.text: —How so?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:460
verses.text: —Jews connect prophecies of this kind with Solomon and Zerubbabel, in order to exhibit the groundlessness of the Christian position; but the mere words are quite enough to convict them of their iniquity, for it is written "I will establish my throne for ever".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:461
verses.text: Now not only Solomon and Zerubbabel, to whom such prophecies are applied by the Jews, have lived out their appointed time, and reached the end of life, but the whole race of David has become extinct; for who ever heard of any one at the present day descended from the root of David?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:462
verses.text: —But are not, then, those who are called Patriarchs of the Jews of the family of David?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:463
verses.text: —Certainly not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:464
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:465
verses.text: —Whence, then, are they sprung?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:466
verses.text: —From the foreigner Herod, who, on his father's side, was an Ascalonite, and on his mother's an Idumaean; but they, too, have all disappeared, and many years have gone by since their sovereignty came to an end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:467
verses.text: But our Lord God promised not only to maintain the seed of David for ever, but to establish his kingdom undestroyed; for He said, "I will build up my throne to all generations".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:468
verses.text: But we see that his race is gone, and his kingdom come to an end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:469
verses.text: Yet though we see this, we know that the God of the Universe is true.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:470
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:471
verses.text: —That God is true is plain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:472
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:473
verses.text: —If, then, God is true, as in truth He is, and promised David that He would establish His race for ever, and keep his kingdom through all time, and if neither race nor kingdom are to be seen, for both have come to an end, how can we convince our opponents that God is true?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:474
verses.text: —I suppose, then, the prophecy really points to the Lord Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:475
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:476
verses.text: —If, then, you confess this, let us investigate together a passage in the middle of the Psalm; we shall then more clearly see what the prophecy means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:477
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:478
verses.text: —Lead on; I will religiously follow in your footsteps.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:479
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:480
verses.text: —After making many promises about this seed that it should be Lord both by sea and land and higher than the kings of the earth and be called the first begotten of God, and should boldly call God, Father God also added this, "My mercy will I keep for him for evermore and my covenant shall stand fast with him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:481
verses.text: His seed also will I make to endure for ever and his throne as the days of heaven".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:482
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:483
verses.text: —The promise goes beyond the bounds of human nature, for both the life and the honour are indestructible and eternal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:484
verses.text: But men endure but for a season; their nature is short lived and their kingdom even during its lifetime undergoes many and various vicissitudes, so that truly the greatness of the prophecy befits none but the Saviour Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:485
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:486
verses.text: —Go on then to what follows and your opinion upon this point will be in every way confirmed, for again saith the God of the universe, "Once have I sworn by my holiness, if I lie unto David, his seed shall endure for ever and his throne as the sun before me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:487
verses.text: It shall be established for ever as the moon".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:488
verses.text: Then, pointing out the truth of the promise He adds, "And the witness is faithful in heaven".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:489
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:490
verses.text: —We must believe without doubt in the promises given by the faithful witness, for, if we are wont to believe men who have promised to speak the truth even if they do not confirm their words with an oath, who can be so mad as to disbelieve the Creator of the Universe, when He adds an oath to his words? For He who forbids others to swear confirmed the immutability of his counsel by an oath, "that by two immutable things in which it was impossible for God to lie we might have a strong consolation who have fled for refuge to lay hold upon the hope set before us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:491
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:492
verses.text: —If then the promise is irrefragable, and among the Jews there is now neither family nor kingdom of the prophet David to be seen, let us believe that our Lord Jesus Christ is plainly called seed of David in His humanity, for of Him the life and the kingdom are both alike eternal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:493
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:494
verses.text: —We have no doubt; and this I own to be the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:495
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:496
verses.text: —These proofs then are sufficient to show clearly the manhood which our Lord and Saviour took of David's seed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:497
verses.text: But to remove all possibility of doubt by the witness of the majority, let us hear how God makes mention of the promises given to David through the voice of the prophet Isaiah.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:498
verses.text: "I will make," he says, "an everlasting covenant with you," and, signifying the law-giver, he adds, "even the sure mercies of David".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:499
verses.text: Since He made this promise to David, and spoke through Esaias, He will assuredly bring the promise to pass.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:500
verses.text: And what follows after the prophecy is in harmony with what I say, for he saith "Behold I have given him for a witness to the people, a leader and commander to the people.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:501
verses.text: Behold nations that know thee not shall call upon thee, and peoples that understand thee not shall run unto thee".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:502
verses.text: Now this fits in with none that are sprung from David, for who of David's descendants, as Esaias says, was made a ruler of nations? And what nations in their prayers ever called on David's descendants as God?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:503
verses.text: —About what is perfectly clear it is unbecoming to dispute, and this plainly refers to the Lord Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:504
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:505
verses.text: —Then let us pass on to another prophetic testimony and let us hear the same prophet saying "There shall come forth a rod out of the stem of Jesse and a branch shall grow out of his roots".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:506
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:507
verses.text: —I think this prophecy was delivered about Zerubbabel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:508
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:509
verses.text: —If you hear what follows, you will not remain in your opinion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:510
verses.text: The Jews have never so understood this prediction, for the prophet goes on, "and the Spirit of the Lord shall rest upon him, the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of counsel and might, the spirit of knowledge and the fear of the Lord".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:511
verses.text: This would never be attributed by any one to a mere man, for even to the very holy the gifts of the Spirit are given by division, as the divine apostle witnesses when he says, "To one is given by the Spirit the word of wisdom, to another the word of knowledge by the same Spirit," and so on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:512
verses.text: The prophet describes Him who sprang from the root of Jesse as possessing all the powers of the spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:513
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:514
verses.text: —To gainsay this were sheer folly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:515
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:516
verses.text: —Now hear what follows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:517
verses.text: You will see some things that transcend human nature, he goes on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:518
verses.text: "He shall not judge after the sight of His eyes, neither reprove after the hearing of His ears, but with righteousness shall He judge the poor, and reprove with equity the mighty of the earth, and He shall smite the earth with the word of His mouth, and with the breath of His lips shall he slay the wicked".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:519
verses.text: Now of these predictions some are human and some divine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:520
verses.text: Justice, truth, equity, and rectitude in giving judgment exhibit virtue in human nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:521
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:522
verses.text: —We have so far clearly learned that the prophet predicts the coming of our Saviour Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:523
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:524
verses.text: —The sequel will shew you yet more plainly the truth of the interpretation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:525
verses.text: For he goes on, "The wolf shall dwell with the lamb," and so on, whereby he teaches at once the distinction of modes of life and the harmony of faith; and experience furnishes a proof of the prediction, for they that abound in wealth, they that live in poverty, servants and masters, rulers and ruled, soldiers and citizens and they that wield the sceptre of the world are received in one font, are all taught one doctrine, are all admitted to one mystic table, and each of the believers enjoys an equal share.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:526
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:527
verses.text: —It is thus shewn that God is spoken of.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:528
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:529
verses.text: —Not only God but man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:530
verses.text: So at the very beginning of this prediction he says that a rod shall grow out of the root of Jesse.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:531
verses.text: Then at the conclusion of the prediction he takes up once more the strain with which he began, for he says "There shall be a root of Jesse which shall stand for an ensign of the people, to it shall the Gentiles seek and his rest shall be glorious".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:532
verses.text: Now Jesse was the father of David, and the promise with an oath was made to David.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:533
verses.text: The prophet would not have spoken of the Lord Christ as a rod growing out of Jesse if he had only known Him as God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:534
verses.text: The prediction also foretold the change of the world, for "the earth" he says "shall be full of the knowledge of the Lord as the waters cover the sea".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:535
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:536
verses.text: —I have heard the prophetic utterances.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:537
verses.text: But I was anxious to know clearly if the divine company of the apostles also says that the Lord Christ sprang from the seed of David according to the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:538
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:539
verses.text: —You have asked for information which so far from being hard is exceedingly easy to give you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:540
