verses.text: Only listen to the first of the apostles exclaiming "David being a prophet and knowing that God had sworn an oath to him that of the fruit of his loins, according to the flesh, He would raise up Christ to sit upon His throne; he seeing this before spake of the resurrection of Christ, that His soul was not left in hell neither His flesh did see corruption".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:541
verses.text: Hence you may perceive that of the seed of David according to the flesh sprang the Lord Christ, and had not flesh only but also a soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:542
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:543
verses.text: —What other apostle preached this?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:544
verses.text: —The great Peter alone was sufficient to testify to the truth, for the Lord after receiving the confession of the truth given by Peter alone confirmed it by a memorable approval.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:545
verses.text: But since you are anxious to hear others proclaiming this same thing, hear Paul and Barnabas preaching in Antioch in Pisidia; for they, when they had made mention of David, continued "Of this man's seed hath God according to his promise raised unto Israel a Saviour, Jesus," and so on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:546
verses.text: And in a letter to Timothy the divine Paul says "Remember that Jesus Christ of the seed of David was raised from the dead according to my gospel".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:547
verses.text: And, when writing to the Romans, at the very outset he calls attention to the Davidic kin, for he says "Paul a servant of Jesus Christ, called to be an apostle, separated unto the gospel of God which He had promised before by his prophets in the holy scriptures concerning His Son which was made of the seed of David according to the flesh," and so on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:548
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:549
verses.text: —Your proofs are numerous and convincing; but tell me why you have omitted what follows?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:550
verses.text: —Because it is not about the Godhead, but about the manhood, that you are in difficulties.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:551
verses.text: Had you been in doubt about the Godhead, I would have given you proof of it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:552
verses.text: It is enough to say "according to the Flesh" to declare the Godhead which is not expressed in terms.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:553
verses.text: When speaking of a relationship of man in general I do not say the son of such an one "according to the flesh," but simply "son," so the divine Evangelist writing his genealogy says "Abraham begat Isaac" and does not add according to the flesh, for Isaac was merely man, and he mentions the rest in like manner, for they were men and had no qualities transcending their nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:554
verses.text: But when the heralds of the truth are discoursing of our Lord Christ, and are pointing out to the ignorant His lower relation, they add the words "according to the flesh," thus indicating His Godhead and teaching that the Lord Christ was not only man but also Eternal God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:555
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:556
verses.text: —You have adduced many proofs from the apostles and prophets, but I follow the words of the Evangelist "The Word was made Flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:557
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:558
verses.text: —I also follow this divine teaching, but I understand it in a pious sense, as meaning that He was made Flesh by taking flesh and a reasonable soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:559
verses.text: But if the divine Word took nothing of our nature, then the covenants made with the patriarchs by the God of all with oaths were not true, and the blessing of Judah was vain, and the promise to David was false, and the Virgin was superfluous, because she did not contribute anything of our nature to the Incarnate God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:560
verses.text: Then the predictions of the prophets have no fulfilment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:561
verses.text: Then vain is our preaching, vain our faith and vain the hope of the resurrection for the Apostle, it appears, lies when he says "and hath raised us up together and made us sit together in heavenly places in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:562
verses.text: For if the Lord Christ had nothing of our nature then He is falsely described as our first fruits, and His bodily nature has not risen from the dead and has not taken the seat in Heaven on the right hand; and if He has obtained none of these things, how hath God raised us up together and made us sit together with Christ, when we in no wise belong to Him in Nature? But it is impious to say this, for the divine apostle, though the general resurrection has not yet taken place, though the kingdom of heaven has not yet been bestowed upon the faithful, exclaims, "He hath raised us up together and made us sit together in heavenly places in Christ Jesus," in order to teach that since the resurrection of our first fruits, and His sitting on the right hand has come to pass, we too in general shall attain the resurrection, and that all they who share in His nature and have adopted His faith, share too in the first fruits of His glory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:563
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:564
verses.text: —We have gone through many and sound arguments, but I was anxious to know the force of the Gospel saying.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:565
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:566
verses.text: —You stand in need of no interpretation from without.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:567
verses.text: The evangelist himself interprets himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:568
verses.text: For after saying "the Word was made flesh," he goes on "and dwelt among us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:569
verses.text: That is to say by dwelling in us, and using the flesh taken from us as a kind of temple, He is said to have been made flesh, and, teaching that He remained unchanged, the evangelist adds "and we beheld His glory—the glory as of the only begotten of the Father, full of grace and truth".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:570
verses.text: For though clad with flesh He exhibited His Father's nobility, shot forth the beams of the Godhead, and emitted the radiance of the power of the Lord, revealing by His works of wonder His hidden nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:571
verses.text: A similar illustration is afforded by the words of the divine apostle to the Philippians: "Let this mind be in you which was also in Christ Jesus, who being in the form of God thought it not robbery to be equal with God, but made Himself of no reputation and took upon Him the form of a servant and was made in the likeness of men, and being found in fashion as a man he humbled Himself and became obedient unto death even the death of the cross".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:572
verses.text: Look at the relation of the utterances.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:573
verses.text: The evangelist says "the Word was made flesh and dwelt among us," the apostle, "took upon him the form of a servant;" the evangelist "We beheld His glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father"—the apostle, "who being in the form of God thought it not robbery to be equal with God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:574
verses.text: To put the matter briefly, both teach that being God and son of God, and clad with His Father's glory, and having the same nature and power with Him that begat Him, He that was in the beginning and was with God, and was God, and was Creator of the world, took upon Him the form of a servant, and it seemed that this was all which was seen; but it was God clad in human nature, and working out the salvation of men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:575
verses.text: This is what was meant by "The word was made flesh" and "was made in the likeness of men and being found in fashion as a man".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:576
verses.text: This is all that was looked at by the Jews, and therefore they said to him "For a good work we stone Thee not but for blasphemy and because that Thou being a man makest Thyself God," and again "This man is not of God because He keepeth not the Sabbath Day".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:577
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:578
verses.text: —The Jews were blind on account of their unbelief, and therefore used these words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:579
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:580
verses.text: —If you find even the apostles before the resurrection thus saying, will you receive the interpretation? I hear them in the boat, after the mighty miracle of the calm, saying "what manner of man is this, that even the winds and the sea obey Him?"  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:581
verses.text: —This is made plain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:582
verses.text: But now tell me this;—the divine apostle says that He "was made in the likeness of man".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:583
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:584
verses.text: —What was taken of him was not man's likeness, but man's nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:585
verses.text: For "form of a servant" is understood just as "the form of God" is understood to mean God's nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:586
verses.text: He took this, and so was made in the likeness of man, and was found in fashion as a man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:587
verses.text: For, being God, He seemed to be man, on account of the nature which He took.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:588
verses.text: The evangelist, however, speaks of His being made in the likeness of man as His being made flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:589
verses.text: But that you may know that they who deny the flesh of the Saviour are of the opposite spirit, hear the great John in his Catholic Epistle saying "Every spirit that confesses that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh is of God, and every spirit that confesses not that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh is not of God, and this is that spirit of Anti-Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:590
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:591
verses.text: —You have given a plausible interpretation, but I was anxious to know how the old teachers of the Church have understood the passage "the word was made flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:592
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:593
verses.text: —You ought to have been persuaded by the apostolic and prophetic proofs; but since you require further the interpretations of the holy Fathers I will also furnish you, God helping me, this medicine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:594
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:595
verses.text: —Do not bring me men of obscure position or doubtful doctrine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:596
verses.text: I shall not receive the interpretation of such as these.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:597
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:598
verses.text: —Does the far famed Athanasius, brightest light of the church of Alexandria, seem to you to be worthy of credit?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:599
verses.text: —Certainly, for he ratified his teaching by the suffering he underwent for the Truth's sake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:600
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:601
verses.text: —Hear then how he wrote to Epictetus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:602
verses.text: "The expression of John 'the Word was made flesh' has this interpretation, so far as can be discovered from the similar passage which we find in St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:603
verses.text: Paul 'Christ was made a curse for us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:604
verses.text: ' It is not because He was made a curse but because He received the curse on our behalf that He is said to have been made a curse, and so it is not because He was turned into flesh, but because He took flesh on our behalf, that He is said to have been made flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:605
verses.text: So far the divine Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:606
verses.text: Gregory, too, whose glory among all men is great, who formerly ruled the Imperial city at the mouth of the Bosphorus and afterwards dwelt at Nazianzus, thus wrote to Cledonius against the specious fallacies of Apollinarius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:607
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:608
verses.text: —He was an illustrious man and a foremost fighter in the cause of piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:609
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:610
verses.text: —Hear him then.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:611
verses.text: He says "the expression 'He was made Flesh' seems to be parallel to His being said to have been made sin and a curse, not because the Lord was transmuted into these,—for how could He?—but because He accepted these when He took on Him our iniquities and bore our infirmities".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:612
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:613
verses.text: —The two interpretations agree.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:614
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:615
verses.text: —We have shown you the pastors of the south and north in harmony; now then let us introduce too the illustrious teachers of the west, who have written their interpretation, if with another tongue, yet with one and the same mind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:616
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:617
verses.text: —I am told that Ambrosius, who adorned the episcopal throne at Milan, fought in the first ranks against all heresy, and wrote works of great beauty and in agreement with the teaching of the apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:618
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:619
verses.text: —I will give you his interpretation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:620
verses.text: Ambrosius says in his work concerning the faith "It is written that the Word was made flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:621
verses.text: I do not deny that it is written, but look at the terms used; for there follows 'and dwelt among us,' that is to say dwelt in human flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:622
verses.text: You are therefore astonished at the terms in which it is written that the Word was made flesh, on the assumption of flesh, by the divine Word, when also concerning sin which He had not, it is said that He was made sin, that is to say not that He was made the nature and operation of sin, but that he might crucify our sin in the flesh; let them then give over asserting that the nature of the Word has undergone change and alteration, for He who took is one and that which was taken other".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:623
verses.text: It is now fitting that you should hear the teachers of the east, this being the only quarter of the east, this being the only quarter of the world which we have hitherto left unnoticed, though they indeed might well have first witnessed to the truth, for to them was first imparted the teaching of the apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:624
verses.text: But since you have sharpened your tongues against the first-born sons of piety by whetting them on the hone of falsehood, we have reserved for them the last place, that after first hearing the rest, you might lay witness by the side of witness, and so at once admire their harmony, and cease from your own interminable talk.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:625
verses.text: Listen then to Flavianus who for a long time right wisely moved the tiller of the church of Antioch, and made the churches which he guided ride safe over the Arian storm, by expounding to them the word of the gospel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:626
verses.text: "The Word was made flesh and dwelt among us; He is not turned into flesh, nor yet did he cease from being God, for this he was from all eternity and became flesh in the dispensation of the incarnation after himself building his own temple, and taking up his abode in the passible creature".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:627
verses.text: And if you desire to hear the ancients of Palestine, lend your ears to the admirable Gelasius, who did diligent husbandry in the church of Caesarea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:628
verses.text: Now these are his words in his homily on the festival of the Lord's epiphany.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:629
verses.text: "Learn the truth from the words of John the Fisherman, 'And the word was made flesh,' not having himself undergone change, but having taken up his abode with us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:630
verses.text: The dwelling is one thing; the Word is another; the temple is one thing, and God who dwells in it, another".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:631
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:632
verses.text: —I am much struck by the agreement.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:633
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:634
verses.text: —Now do you not suppose that the rule of the apostolic faith was kept by John, who first nobly watered the field of the church of the Antiochenes, and then was a wise husbandman of that of the imperial city?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:635
verses.text: —I hold this teacher to be in all respects an admirable one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:636
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:637
verses.text: —Well, this most excellent man has interpreted this passage of the Gospel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:638
verses.text: He writes, "When you hear that the Word was made flesh, be not startled or cast down, for the substance did not deteriorate into flesh—an idea of the uttermost impiety—but continuing to be just what it is, so took the form of a servant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:639
verses.text: For just as when the apostle says 'Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us,' he does not say that the substance of Christ departed from His own glory, and took the substance of a curse, a position which not even devils would imagine, nor the utterly senseless, and the naturally idiotic—so remarkable being the connection between impiety and insanity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:640
verses.text: But what he does assert is that after receiving the curse due to us, He does not suffer us to be cursed for the future.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:641
verses.text: It is in this sense that He is stated to have been made flesh, not because he had changed the substance into flesh, but because he had assumed the flesh, the substance remaining all the while unimpaired".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:642
verses.text: You may like to hear also Severianus, Bishop of Gabala.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:643
verses.text: If so, I will adduce his testimony and do you lend your ears.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:644
verses.text: "The text 'the Word was made flesh' does not indicate a deterioration of nature but the assumption of our nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:645
verses.text: Suppose you take the word 'was made' to indicate a change; then when you hear Paul saying 'Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us,' do you understand him to mean a change into the nature of a curse? Just as being made a curse had no other meaning than that He took our curse upon Himself, so the words was made flesh and dwelt among us mean nothing other than the assumption of flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:646
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:647
verses.text: —I admire the exact agreement of these men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:648
verses.text: For they are as unanimous in giving the same interpretations of evangelical writings as if they had met in the same place and written down their opinion together.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:649
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:650
verses.text: —Mountains and seas separate them very far from one another, yet distance does not damage their harmony, for they were all inspired by the same gift of the spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:651
verses.text: I would also have offered you the interpretations of the victorious champions of piety Diodorus and Theodorus, had I not seen that you were ill disposed towards them, and had inherited the hostility of Apollinarius; you would have seen that they have expressed similar experiences, drawing water from the divine Fount, and becoming themselves too, streams of the spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:652
verses.text: But I will pass them by, for you have declared a truceless war against them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:653
verses.text: I will, however, shew you the famous teacher of the Church, and his mind about the divine incarnation, that you may know what opinion he held concerning the assumed nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:654
verses.text: You have no doubt heard of the illustrious Ignatius, who received episcopal grace by the hand of the great Peter, and after ruling the church of Antioch, wore the crown of martyrdom.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:655
verses.text: You have heard too of Irenaeus, who enjoyed the teaching of Polycarp, and became a light of the western Gauls;—of Hippolytus and Methodius, bishops and martyrs, and the rest, whose names I will append to their expressions of opinion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:656
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:657
verses.text: —I am exceedingly desirous of hearing their testimony too.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:658
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:659
verses.text: —Hear them now bringing forward the apostolic teaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:660
verses.text: Testimony of Saint Ignatius, bishop of Antioch, and martyr.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:661
verses.text: From the letter to the Smyrnaeans (I.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:662
verses.text: ):—  "Having a full conviction with respect to our Lord as being truly descended from David according to the flesh, son of God according to Godhead and power, born really of a virgin, baptized by John that all righteousness might be fulfilled by Him, really in the time of Pontius Pilate and of Herod the tetrarch crucified for our sake in the flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:663
verses.text: Of the same in the same epistle:—  "For what advantageth it me if a man praises me but blasphemes my Lord, in not confessing him to be a bearer of flesh? but he who does not make this confession really denies Him and is himself bearer of a corpse".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:664
verses.text: Of the same from the same epistle:—  "For if these things were done by our Lord in appearance only, then it is in appearance only that I am a prisoner in chains; and why have I delivered myself to death, to fire, to sword, to the beasts? But he who is near to the sword is near to God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:665
verses.text: Only in the name of Jesus Christ that I may share his sufferings I endure all things while He, Perfect Man whom some in their ignorance deny, gives me strength".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:666
verses.text: From the same in the letter to the Ephesians:—  "For our God Jesus Christ was born in Mary's womb by dispensation of God of the seed of David and of the Holy Ghost who was born and was baptized that our mortality might be purified".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:667
verses.text: From the same epistle:—  "If ye all individually come together by grace name by name in one faith, and in one Jesus Christ according to the flesh of David's race Son of God and Son of man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:668
verses.text: Of the same from the same epistle:—  "There is one Physician of flesh and of spirit generate and ingenerate, God in man, true life in death, Son of Mary and of God, first passible and then impassible, Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:669
verses.text: Lastly of the same in his epistle to the Trallians:—  "Be ye made deaf therefore when any man speaks to you apart from Jesus Christ, who was of David's race and of Mary, who was really born and really ate and drank and was persecuted in the time of Pontius Pilate, was crucified and died, while beings on earth and beings in heaven and beings under the earth were looking on".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:670
verses.text: Testimony of Irenaeus bishop of Lyons, from his third book Against the heresies:—  "Why then did they add the words 'In the city of David,' save to proclaim the good news that the promise made by God to David, that of the fruit of his loins should come an everlasting king, was fulfilled; a promise which indeed the Creator of the world had made".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:671
verses.text: Of the same from the same book:—  "And when he says 'Hear ye now, Oh House of David' he means that the everlasting King whom God promised to David that he would raise up from his body is He who was born of David's Virgin".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:672
verses.text: Of the same from the same book:—  "If then the first Adam had had a human father and had been begotten of seed, it would have been reasonable to say that the second Adam had been begotten of Joseph.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:673
verses.text: But if the former was taken from earth, and his creator was God, it was necessary also that He who renews in himself the man created by God should have the same likeness of generation with that former.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:674
verses.text: Why then did not God again take dust? Why did he on the other hand ordain that the formation should be made of Mary? That there might be no other creation; that that which was being saved might be no other thing; but that the former might himself be renewed without loss of the likeness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:675
verses.text: For then do they too fall away who allege that He took nothing from the Virgin, that they may repudiate the inheritance of the flesh and cast off the likeness".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:676
verses.text: Of the same from the same book:—  "Since his going down into Mary is useless; for why went He down into her if He was designed to take nothing from her? And further, if He had taken nothing from Mary He would not have accepted the food taken from earth whereby is nourished the body taken from earth, nor would He like Moses and Elias, after fasting forty days, have hungered, on account of His body demanding its own food, nor yet would John his disciple when writing about him have said—'Jesus being wearied from his journey sat,' nor would David have uttered the prediction about him 'And they added to the pain of my wounds,' nor would he have wept over Lazarus, nor would He have sweated drops of blood, nor would He have said, 'my soul is exceedingly sorrowful,' nor yet when He was pierced would blood and water have issued from His side.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:677
verses.text: For all these things are proofs of the flesh taken from earth, which He had renewed in Himself in the salvation of his own creature".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:678
verses.text: Of the same from the same book:—  "For as by the disobedience of the one man who was first formed from rude earth the many were made sinners and lost their life, so also was it fitting that through obedience of one man, the firstborn of a virgin, many should be made righteous and receive their salvation".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:679
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "'I have said ye are gods and all of you children of the Most High but ye shall die like man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:680
verses.text: ' This He says to them that did not accept the gift of adoption, but dishonour the incarnation of the pure generation of the word of God, deprive man of his ascent to God, and are ungrateful to the Word of God who for their sakes was made flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:681
verses.text: For this cause was the word made man that man receiving the word and accepting the adoption should be made God's son".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:682
verses.text: Of the same from the same book:—  "Since then on account of the foreordained dispensation the spirit came down, and the only begotten Son of God, who also is Word of the Father, when the fulness of time was come, was made flesh in man and our Lord Jesus Christ—being one and the same—fulfilled all the human dispensation as the Lord himself testifies, and the apostles confess, all the teachings of men who invented the ogdoads and tetrads and similitudes are proved plainly false".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:683
verses.text: Testimony of the Holy Hippolytus, Bishop and Martyr, from his discourse on"The Lord is my shepherd":—  "And an ark of incorruptible wood was the Saviour Himself, for the incorruptibility and indestructibility of His Tabernacle signified its producing no corruption of sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:684
verses.text: For the sinner who confesses his sin says 'My wounds stink and are corrupt because of my foolishness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:685
verses.text: ' But the Lord was without sin, made in His human nature of incorruptible wood, that is to say, of the Virgin and the Holy Ghost, overlaid within and without, as it were, by purest gold of the word of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:686
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse on Elkanah and Hannah:—  "Bring me then, O Samuel, the Heifer drawn to Bethlehem, that you may shew the King begotten of David, and anointed King and Priest by the Father".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:687
verses.text: From the same discourse:—  "Tell me, O Blessed Mary, what it was that was conceived by thee in the womb; what it was that was borne by thee in a Virgin's womb.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:688
verses.text: It was the Word of God, firstborn from Heaven, on thee descending, and man firstborn being formed in a womb, that the first born Word of God might be shewn united to a firstborn man".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:689
verses.text: From the same discourse:—  "The second, which was through the prophets as through Samuel, he revokes, and turns his people from the slavery of strangers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:690
verses.text: The third, in which He took the manhood of the Virgin and was present in the flesh; who, when He saw the city wept over it".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:691
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse on the beginning of Isaiah:—  "He likens the world to Egypt; its idolatry, to images; its removal and destruction to an earthquake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:692
verses.text: The Word he calls the 'Lord' and by a 'swift cloud' he means the right pure tabernacle enthroned on which our Lord Jesus Christ entered into life to undo the fall".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:693
verses.text: Testimony of the Holy Methodius,bishop and martyr, from his discourse on the martyrs:—  "So wonderful and precious is martyrdom that our Lord Jesus Christ Himself, the Son of God, testified in its honour that He thought it not robbery to be equal with God, that He might crown with this grace the Manhood into whom He had come down".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:694
verses.text: Testimony of the holy Eustathius, bishop of Antioch, confessor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:695
verses.text: From his interpretation of the xvith Psalm:—  "The soul of Jesus experienced both.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:696
verses.text: For it was in the place of the souls of men and being made without the flesh, lives and survives.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:697
verses.text: So it is reasonable and of the same substance as the souls of men, just as the flesh is of the same substance as the flesh of men, coming forth from Mary".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:698
verses.text: Of the same from his work about the soul:—  "On looking at the education of the child, or at the increase of his stature, or at the extension of time, or at the growth of the body, what would they say? But, to omit the miracles wrought upon earth, let them behold the raisings of the dead to life, the signs of the Passion, the marks of the scourges, the bruises and the blows, the wounded side, the prints of the nails, the shedding of the blood, the evidences of the death, and in a word the actual resurrection of the very body".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:699
verses.text: From the same work:—  "Indeed if any one looks to the generation of the body, he would clearly discover that after being born at Bethlehem He was wrapped in swaddling clothes, and was brought up for some time in Egypt, because of the evil counsel of the cruel Herod, and grew to man's estate at Nazareth".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:700
verses.text: From the same work:—  "For the tabernacle of the Word and of God is not the same, whereby the blessed Stephen beheld the divine glory".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:701
verses.text: Of the same from his sermon on "the Lord created me in the beginning of His way":—  "If the Word received a beginning of His generation from the time when passing through His mother's womb He wore the human frame, it is clear that He was made of a woman; but if He was from the first Word and God with the Father, and if we assert that the universe was made by Him, then He who is and is the cause of all created things was not made of a woman, but is by nature God, self existent, infinite, incomprehensible; and of a woman was made man, formed in the Virgin's womb by the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:702
verses.text: From the same work:—  "For a temple absolutely holy and undefiled is the tabernacle of the word according to the flesh, wherein God visibly made his habitation and dwelt, and we assert this not of conjecture, for He who is by nature the Son of this God when predicting the destruction and resurrection of the temple distinctly instructs us by His teaching when He says to the murderous Jews, 'Destroy this temple and in three days I will raise it up.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:703
verses.text: '"  From the same work:—  "When then the Word built a temple and carried the manhood, companying in a body with men, He invisibly displayed various miracles, and sent forth the apostles as heralds of His everlasting kingdom".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:704
verses.text: Of the same from his interpretation of Psalm xcii:—  "It is plain then if 'He that anointeth' means God whose throne He calls 'everlasting,' the anointer is plainly by nature God, begotten of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:705
verses.text: But the anointed took an acquired virtue, being adorned with a chosen temple of the Godhead dwelling in it".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:706
verses.text: The testimony of the holy Athanasius, Bishop of Alexandria and Confessor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:707
verses.text: From the defence of Dionysius Bishop of Alexandria:—  "'I am the vine, ye are the branches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:708
verses.text: My Father is the husbandman.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:709
verses.text: ' For we according to the body are of kin to the Lord, and for this reason He himself said 'I will declare thy name unto my brethren.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:710
verses.text: ' And just as the branches are of one substance with the vine, and of it, so too we, since we have bodies akin to the body of the Lord, receive them of His fulness, and have it as a root for our resurrection and salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:711
verses.text: And the Father is called a husbandman, for He Himself through the Word tilled the vine which is the Lord's body".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:712
verses.text: Of the same from the same treatise:—  "The Lord was called a vine on account of His bodily relationship to the branches which are ourselves".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:713
verses.text: Of the same from his greater oration concerning the faith:—  "The scripture 'in the beginning was the Word' clearly indicates the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:714
verses.text: The passage 'the Word was made flesh' shews the human nature of the Lord".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:715
verses.text: From the same discourse:—  "'He shall wash His garments in wine' that is His body, which is the vestment of the Godhead in His own blood".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:716
verses.text: Of the same from the same discourse:—  "The Word 'was' is referred to His divinity, the words 'was made flesh' to His body, the Word was made flesh not by being reduced to flesh, but by bearing flesh, just as any one might say such an one became or was made an old man, though not so born from the beginning, or the soldier became a veteran, not being previously such as he became.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:717
verses.text: John says, 'I became,' or 'was in the island of Patmos on the Lord's day.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:718
verses.text: ' Not that he was made or born there, but he says 'I became or was in Patmos' instead of saying 'I arrived;' so the Word 'arrived' at flesh, as it is said 'the Word was made flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:719
verses.text: ' Hear the words 'I became like a broken vessel,' and 'I became like a man that hath no strength, free among the dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:720
verses.text: '"  Of the same from his letter to Epictetus:—  "Whoever heard such things? Who taught them? Who learnt them? 'Out of Zion shall go forth the law and the Word of the Lord from Jerusalem.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:721
verses.text: ' But whence did these things come forth? What hell vomited them out? To say that the body taken of Mary was of the same substance as the Godhead of the Word, or that the Word was changed into flesh and bones and hairs and a whole body; whoever heard in a church or at all among Christians that God bore a body by adoption and not by birth?"  Of the same from the same Epistle:—  "But who, hearing that the Word made for Himself a passible body, not of Mary, but of His own substance, would call the sayer of these things a Christian? Who has invented so unfounded an impiety, as even to think and to say that they who affirm the Lord's body to be of Mary, conceive no longer of a Trinity, but of a quaternity in the godhead? As though they that are of this opinion described the flesh which the Saviour clothed himself with of Mary as of the substance of the Trinity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:722
verses.text: "Whence further have some men vomited forth an impiety as bad as the foregoing, and alleged that the body is not of later time than the godhead of the Word, but has always been co-eternal with it, since it is formed of the substance of wisdom".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:723
verses.text: Of the same from the same letter:—  "So the body taken of Mary was human according to the scriptures, and real in that it was the same as our own.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:724
verses.text: For Mary was our sister, since we are all of Adam, a fact which no one could doubt who remembers the words of Luke".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:725
verses.text: Testimony of the holy Basil, bishop of Caesarea:—  From the interpretation of Psalm LX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:726
verses.text: "All strangers have stooped and been put under the yoke of Christ, wherefore also 'over Edom' does he 'cast out' his 'shoe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:727
verses.text: ' Now the shoe of the Godhead is the flesh which bore God whereby he came among men".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:728
verses.text: Of the same from his writings about the Holy Ghost to Amphilochius:—  "He uses the phrase 'of whom' instead of 'through whom;' as when Paul says 'made of a woman.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:729
verses.text: ' He clearly made this distinction for us in another place where he says that the being made of the man is proper to a woman, but to a man the being made by the woman, in the words 'For as the woman is of the man so is the man by the woman.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:730
verses.text: ' But with the object at once of pointing out the different use of these expressions, and of correcting obiter an error of certain men who supposed the body of the Lord to be spiritual, that he may shew how the God-bearing flesh was composed of human matter, he gives prominence to the more emphatic expression, for the expression 'by a woman' was in danger of suggesting that the sense of the word generation was merely in passing through, while the phrase 'of the woman' makes the common nature of the child and of the mother plain enough".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:731
verses.text: Testimony of the holy Gregory bishop of Nazianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:732
verses.text: From the former exposition to Cledonius:—  "If any one says that the flesh came down from heaven, and not from this earth, and from us, let him be Anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:733
verses.text: For the words 'The second man is from heaven,' and 'as is the heavenly such are they also that are heavenly' and 'no man hath ascended up to heaven but the son of man that came down from heaven,' and any other similar passage, must be understood to be spoken on account of the union with man, as also the statement that 'all things were made by Christ,' and that 'Christ dwells in our hearts,' must be understood not according to the sensible, but according to the intellectual conception of the Godhead, the terms being commingled together just as are the natures".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:734
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "Let us see from their own words what reason they give for the being made man, that is for the incarnation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:735
verses.text: If indeed it was that God otherwise not contained in space, might be contained in space and, as it were under a veil, might converse with men in the flesh, then their mask and their stage play are exquisite: not to say that it was possible for Him otherwise to converse with us, as of yore, in a burning bush and in human form, but if that He might undo the damnation of sin by taking like to like then just as He required flesh on account of the condemned flesh, and a soul on account of the soul, so too he required a mind on account of the mind, which in Adam not only fell but,—to employ a term which physicians are accustomed to use about diseases—was affected with original malady.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:736
verses.text: For that which did not keep the commandment was what had received the commandment; and that which dared transgression was what had not kept the commandment; and that which specially needed salvation was what had transgressed, and that which was assumed was what needed salvation; so the mind was assumed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:737
verses.text: Now this point has been demonstrated, whether they will or no, by proofs which are so to say mathematical and necessary.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:738
verses.text: But you are doing just as though, if a man were to have a diseased eye and a limping foot you were to cure the foot but leave the eye uncured; or, if a painter had painted a picture badly, were to alter the picture, but leave the painter alone, as though he were doing his work well.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:739
verses.text: But if they are so constrained by these arguments as to take refuge in the statement that it is possible for God to save man, even without a mind, why then clearly He might have done so even without flesh, by the mere expression of His will, just as He works and has worked in the universe without a body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:740
verses.text: Away then with the flesh as well as with the mind! Let there be no inconsistency in your absurdity".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:741
verses.text: Testimony of the Holy Gregory, bishop of Nyssa.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:742
verses.text: From his sermon on Abraham:—  "So the Word came down not naked, but after having been made flesh, not in the form of God, but in the form of a servant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:743
verses.text: This then is He who said that He could do nothing of Himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:744
verses.text: For the not being able is the part of powerlessness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:745
verses.text: For as darkness is opposed to light, and death to life, so is weakness to power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:746
verses.text: But yet Christ is Power of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:747
verses.text: Power is wholly inconsistent with not being able.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:748
verses.text: For if power were powerless what is powerful? When then the Word declares that He can do nothing it is plain that He does not attribute his powerlessness to the Godhead of the Only-begotten, but connects his not being able with the powerlessness of our nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:749
verses.text: The flesh is weak, as it is written, 'The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:750
verses.text: '"  Of the same from his Book "on the Perfection of Life":—  "Again the true lawgiver, of whom Moses was a type, hewed for Himself out of our earth the slabs of nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:751
verses.text: No wedlock fashioned for Him the flesh that was to receive the godhead, but He Himself is made the hewer of His own flesh, graven as it is by the finger of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:752
verses.text: For the Holy Ghost came upon the Virgin, and the power of the Highest overshadowed her.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:753
verses.text: And when this had come to pass, nature once again took its indestructible character, being made immortal by the marks of the divine finger".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:754
verses.text: Of the same from his Book against Eunomius:—  "We assert therefore that when He said above that wisdom built for herself a house, he intimates by the phrase the formation of the flesh of the Lord, for the very wisdom made its home in no strange dwelling, but built itself its dwelling of the Virgin's body".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:755
verses.text: Of the same from the same treatise:—  "The Word was before the ages, but the flesh was made in the last times, and no one would say on the contrary either that the flesh was before the ages, or the Word made in the last times".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:756
verses.text: Of the same from the same treatise:—  "The expression 'created me' is not to be understood of the divine and the undefiled, but, as has been said, of our created nature, according to the dispensation of the incarnation".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:757
verses.text: Of the same from the first discourse on the Beatitudes:—  "'Who being in the form of God, thought it not robbery to be equal with God, but emptied himself, and took the form of a servant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:758
verses.text: ' What poorer, in respect of God, than the form of a servant? What more lowly, in respect of the King of all, than approach to fellowship in our poor nature? The King of Kings and Lord of Lords voluntarily dons the form of servitude".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:759
verses.text: Testimony of the Holy Flavianus, bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:760
verses.text: From his sermon on John the Baptist:—  "Do not think of connexion in any physical sense, nor entertain the idea of conjugal intercourse.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:761
verses.text: For thy Creator is creating His own bodily temple now being born of thee".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:762
verses.text: Of the same from his book on "The Spirit of the Lord is upon me":—  "Hear Him saying, 'The Spirit is upon me because He hath anointed me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:763
verses.text: ' You do not know, He says, what you read, for I, the anointed with the Spirit, am come to you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:764
verses.text: Now what is akin to us, and not the invisible nature, is anointed with the Spirit".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:765
verses.text: Testimony of Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:766
verses.text: From his Discourse on "My Father is greater than I:"—  "Distinguish me now the natures, the Divine and the human.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:767
verses.text: For man was not made from God by falling away, nor was God made of man by advancement.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:768
verses.text: I am speaking of God and man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:769
verses.text: When, however, you attribute the passions to the flesh and the miracles to God, you of necessity and involuntarily assign the lowly titles to the man born of Mary, and the exalted and divine to the Word Who in the beginning was God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:770
verses.text: Wherefore in some cases I utter exalted words, in others lowly, to the end that by means of the lofty I may shew the nature of the indwelling Word, and by the lowly, own the weakness of the lowly flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:771
verses.text: Whence sometimes I call myself equal to the Father and sometimes greater than the Father, not contradicting myself, but shewing that I am God and man, for God is of the lofty, man of the lowly; but if you wish to know how my Father is greater than I, I spoke of the flesh and not of the person of the Godhead".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:772
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse on "The Son, can do nothing of Himself:"—  "How was Adam disobedient in Heaven, and how of heavenly body was he formed first-formed beside the first formation? But it was the Adam of the earth who was formed at the beginning; the Adam of the earth disobeyed; the Adam of the earth was assumed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:773
verses.text: Wherefore also the Adam of the earth was saved that thus the reason of the incarnation may be proved necessary and true".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:774
verses.text: Testimony of the Holy John Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:775
verses.text: From the speech which he made when the Gothic envoy had spoken before him:—  "See from the beginning what He does.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:776
verses.text: He clothes Himself in our nature, powerless and vanquished, that by its means He may fight and struggle and from the beginning He uproots the nature of rebellion".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:777
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse on The Festival of the Nativity:—  "For is it not of the very last stupidity for them to bring down their own gods into stones and cheap wooden images, shutting them up as it were in a kind of prison, and to fancy that there is nothing disgraceful in what they either say or do, and then to find fault with us for saying that God made a living temple for Himself of the Holy Ghost, by means of which he brought succour to the world? For if it is disgraceful for God to dwell in a human body, then in proportion as the stone and the wood are more worthless than man is it much more disgraceful for him to dwell in stone and wood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:778
verses.text: But perhaps mankind seems to them to be of less value than these senseless objects.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:779
verses.text: They bring down the substance of God into stones and into dogs; but many heretics into fouler things than these.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:780
verses.text: But we could never endure even to hear of these things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:781
verses.text: But what we say is that of a virgin's womb the Christ took pure flesh, holy and without spot, and made impervious to all sin, and restored the body that was His own".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:782
verses.text: A little further on: "And we assert that when the divine Word had fashioned for Himself a holy temple by its means he brought the heavenly state into our life".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:783
verses.text: Of the same from the oration: That the lowly words and deeds of Christ were not spoken and done through lack of power, but through distinctions of dispensation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:784
verses.text: "What then are the causes of many humble things having been said about Him both by Himself and by His apostles? The first and greatest cause is the fact of His having clothed Himself with flesh, and wishing all his contemporaries and all who have lived since, to believe that He was not a shadow, nor what was seen merely a form, but reality of nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:785
verses.text: For if when He Himself and His apostles had spoken about Him so often in humble and in human sense, the devil yet had power to persuade some wretched and miserable men to deny the reason of the incarnation, and dare to say that He did not take flesh and so to destroy all the ground of His love for man, how many would not have fallen into this abyss if He had never said anything of the kind?"  I have now produced for you a few out of many authorities of the heralds of the truth, not to stun you with too many.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:786
verses.text: They are quite enough to show the bent of the mind of the excellent writers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:787
verses.text: It is now for you to say what force their writings seem to have.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:788
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:789
verses.text: —They have all spoken in harmony with one another, and the workers in the vineyard of the West agree with them whose husbandry is done in the region of the rising sun.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:790
verses.text: Yet I perceived a considerable difference in their sayings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:791
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:792
verses.text: —They are successors of the divine apostles; some even of those apostles were privileged to hear the holy voice and see the goodly sight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:793
verses.text: The majority of them too were adorned with the crown of martyrdom.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:794
verses.text: Does it seem right for you to wag the tongue of blasphemy against them?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:795
verses.text: —I shrink from doing this; at the same time I do not approve of their great divergence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:796
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:797
verses.text: —But now I will bring you an unexpected remedy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:798
verses.text: I will adduce one of your own beautiful heresy—your teacher Apollinarius, and I will shew you that he understood the text "The Word was made flesh" just as the holy Fathers did.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:799
verses.text: Hear now what he wrote about it in his "Summary".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:800
verses.text: The testimony of Apollinarius from his "Summary":—  "If no one is turned into that which he assumes, and Christ assumed flesh, then He was not turned into flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:801
verses.text: And immediately afterward he continues:—  "For also He gave himself to us in relationship by means of the body to save us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:802
verses.text: Now that which saves is far more excellent than that which is being saved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:803
verses.text: Far more excellent then than we are, is He in the assumption of a body! But He would not have been more excellent had He been turned into flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:804
verses.text: A little further on he says:—  "The simple is one, but the complex cannot be one; he then that alleges that He was made flesh affirms the mutation of the one Word.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:805
verses.text: But if the complex is also one, as man, then he who on account of the union with the flesh says the Word was made flesh means the one in complexity".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:806
verses.text: And again a little further on he says—"To be made flesh is to be made empty, but the being made empty declares not man, but the Son of man, who 'emptied Himself' not by undergoing change, but by investiture".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:807
verses.text: There; you see the teacher of your own doctrines has introduced the word 'investiture' and indeed in his little work upon the faith he says—"We then believe that he was made flesh, while His Godhead remained unchanged for the renewal of the manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:808
verses.text: For in the holy power of God there has been neither alteration nor change of place, nor inclusion"—and then shortly again—"We worship God who took flesh of the blessed virgin, and on this account in the flesh is man, but in the spirit God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:809
verses.text: And in another exposition he says—"We confess the Son of God to have been made the Son of man, not nominally but verily, on taking flesh of the Virgin Mary".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:810
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:811
verses.text: —I did not suppose that Apollinarius held these sentiments.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:812
verses.text: I had other ideas about him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:813
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:814
verses.text: —Well; now you have learnt that not only the prophets and apostles, and they who after them were ordained teachers of the world, but even Apollinarius, the writer of heretical babbling, confesses the divine Word to be immutable, states that He was not turned into flesh but assumed flesh, and this over and over again, as you have heard.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:815
verses.text: Do not then struggle to throw your master's blasphemy into the shade by your own.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:816
verses.text: For, says the Lord "the disciple is not above his master".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:817
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:818
verses.text: —Yes, I confess that the divine Word of God is immutable and took flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:819
verses.text: It were the uttermost foolishness to withstand authorities so many and so great.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:820
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:821
verses.text: —Do you wish to have a solution of the rest of the difficulties?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:822
verses.text: —Let us put off their investigation until to-morrow.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:823
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:824
verses.text: —Very well; our synod is dismissed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 2:825
verses.text: Let us depart, and bear in mind what we have agreed upon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1
verses.text: Dialogue II.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:2
verses.text: —The Unconfounded.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:3
verses.text: Eranistes and Orthodoxus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:4
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:5
verses.text: —I am come as I promised.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:6
verses.text: 'Tis yours to adopt one of two alternatives, and either furnish a solution of my difficulties, or assent to what I and my friends lay down.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:7
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:8
verses.text: —I accept your challenge, for I think it right and fair.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:9
verses.text: But we must first recall to mind at what point we left off our discourse yesterday, and what was the conclusion of our argument.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:10
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:11
verses.text: —I will remind you of the end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:12
verses.text: I remember our agreeing that the divine Word remained immutable, and took flesh, and was not himself changed into flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:13
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:14
verses.text: —You seem to be content with the points agreed on, for you have faithfully called them to mind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:15
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:16
verses.text: —Yes, and I have already said that the man that withstands teachers so many and so great is indubitably out of his mind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:17
verses.text: I was moreover put to not a little shame to find that Apollinarius used the same terms as the orthodox, although in his books about the incarnation his drift has distinctly been in another direction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:18
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:19
verses.text: —Then we affirm that the Divine Word took flesh?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:20
verses.text: —We do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:21
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:22
verses.text: —And what do we mean by the flesh? A body only, as is the view of Arius and Eunomius, or body and soul?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:23
verses.text: —Body and soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:24
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:25
verses.text: —What kind of soul? The reasonable soul, or that which is by some termed the phytic, vegetable, that is, vital? for the fable-mongering quackery of the Apollinarians compels us to ask unseemly questions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:26
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:27
verses.text: —Does then Apollinarius make a distinction of souls?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:28
verses.text: —He says that man is composed of three parts, of a body, a vital soul, and further of a reasonable soul, which he terms mind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:29
verses.text: Holy Scripture on the contrary knows only one, not two souls; and this is plainly taught us by the formation of the first man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:30
verses.text: For it is written God took dust from the earth and "formed man," and "breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and man became a living soul".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:31
verses.text: And in the gospels the Lord said to the holy disciples "Fear not them which kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul; but rather fear him which is able to destroy both soul and body in hell".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:32
verses.text: And the very divine Moses when he told the tale of them that came down into Egypt and stated with whom each tribal chief had come in, added, "All the souls that came out of Egypt were seventy-five," reckoning one soul for each immigrant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:33
verses.text: And the divine apostle at Troas, when all supposed Eutychus to be dead, said "Trouble not yourselves for his soul is in him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:34
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:35
verses.text: —It is shewn clearly that each man has one soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:36
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:37
verses.text: —But Apollinarius says two; and that the Divine Word took the unreasonable, and that instead of the reasonable, he was made in the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:38
verses.text: It was on this account that I asked what kind of soul you assert to have been assumed with the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:39
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:40
verses.text: —I say the reasonable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:41
verses.text: For I follow the Divine Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:42
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:43
verses.text: —We agree then that the "form of a servant" assumed by the Divine Word was complete.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:44
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:45
verses.text: —Yes; complete.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:46
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:47
verses.text: —And rightly; for since the whole first man became subject to sin, and lost the impression of the Divine Image, and the race followed, it results that the Creator, with the intention of renewing the blurred image, assumed the nature in its entirety, and stamped an imprint far better than the first.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:48
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:49
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:50
verses.text: But now I beg you in the first place that the meaning of the terms employed may be made quite clear, that thus our discussion may advance without hindrance, and no investigation of doubtful points intervene to interrupt our conversation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:51
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:52
verses.text: —What you say is admirable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:53
verses.text: Ask now concerning whatever point you like.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:54
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:55
verses.text: —What must we call Jesus the Christ? Man?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:56
verses.text: —By neither name alone, but by both.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:57
verses.text: For the Divine Man after being made man was named Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:58
verses.text: "For," it is written, "Thou shalt call His name Jesus for he shall save His people from their sins," and unto you is born this day in the city of David Christ the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:59
verses.text: Now these are angels' voices.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:60
verses.text: But before the Incarnation he was named God, son of God, only begotten, Lord, Divine Word, and Creator.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:61
verses.text: For it is written "In the beginning was the Word, and the word was with God, and the word was God," and "all things were made by Him," and "He was life," and "He was the true light which lighteth every man that cometh into the world".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:62
verses.text: There are also other similar passages, declaring the divine nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:63
verses.text: But after the Incarnation He was named Jesus and Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:64
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:65
verses.text: —Therefore the Lord Jesus is God only.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:66
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:67
verses.text: —You hear that the divine Word was made man, and do you call him God only?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:68
verses.text: —Since He became man without being changed, but remained just what He was before, we must call Him just what He was.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:69
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:70
verses.text: —The divine Word was and is and will be immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:71
verses.text: But when He had taken man's nature He became man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:72
verses.text: It behoves us therefore to confess both natures, both that which took, and that which was taken.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:73
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:74
verses.text: —We must name Him by the nobler.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:75
verses.text: Orth—Man,—I mean man the animal,—is he a simple or a composite being?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:76
verses.text: —Composite.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:77
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:78
verses.text: —Composed of what component parts?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:79
verses.text: —Of a body and a soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:80
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:81
verses.text: —And of these natures whether is nobler?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:82
verses.text: —Clearly the soul, for it is reasonable and immortal, and has been entrusted with the sovereignty of the animal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:83
verses.text: But the body is mortal and perishable, and without the soul is unreasonable, and a corpse.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:84
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:85
verses.text: —Then the divine Scripture ought to have called the animal after its more excellent part.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:86
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:87
verses.text: —It does so call it, for it calls them that came out of Egypt souls.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:88
verses.text: For with seventy-five souls, it says, Israel came down into Egypt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:89
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:90
verses.text: —But does the divine Scripture never call any one after the body?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:91
verses.text: —It calls them that are the slaves of flesh, flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:92
verses.text: For "God," it is written, "said my spirit shall not always remain in these men, for they are flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:93
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:94
verses.text: —But without blame no one is called flesh?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:95
verses.text: —I do not remember.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:96
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:97
verses.text: —Then I will remind you, and point out to you that even the very saints are called "flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:98
verses.text: Answer now.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:99
verses.text: What would you call the apostles? Spiritual, or fleshly?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:100
verses.text: —Spiritual;—and leaders and teachers of the spiritual.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:101
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:102
verses.text: —Hear now the holy Paul when he says "But when it pleased God who separated me from my mother's womb, and called me by his grace, to reveal his son in me that I might preach him among the heathen, immediately I conferred not with flesh and blood neither went I up to them that were apostles before me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:103
verses.text: Does he so style the apostles because he blames them?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:104
verses.text: —Certainly not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:105
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:106
verses.text: —Is it not that he names them after their visible nature, and comparing the calling which is of men with that which is of heaven?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:107
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:108
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:109
verses.text: —Then hear too the psalmist David—"Unto thee shall all flesh come".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:110
verses.text: Hear too, the prophet Isaiah foretelling "All flesh shall see the salvation of our God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:111
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:112
verses.text: —It is made perfectly plain that Holy Scripture names human nature from the flesh without the least blame.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:113
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:114
verses.text: —I will proceed to give you the yet further proof.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:115
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:116
verses.text: —What further?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:117
verses.text: —The fact that sometimes when giving blame the divine Scripture uses only the name of soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:118
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:119
verses.text: —And where will you find this in holy Scripture?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:120
verses.text: —Hear the Lord God speaking through the prophet Ezekiel "The soul that sinneth it shall die".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:121
verses.text: Moreover through the great Moses He saith "If a soul sin—" And again "It shall come to pass that every soul that will not hear that prophet shall be cut off".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:122
verses.text: And many other passages of the same kind may be found.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:123
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:124
verses.text: —This is plainly proved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:125
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:126
verses.text: —In cases, then, where there is a certain natural union, and a combination of created things, and of beings connected by service and by time, it is not the custom of holy Scripture to use a name for this being derived only from the nobler nature; it names it indiscriminately both by the meaner and by the nobler.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:127
verses.text: If so, how can you find fault with us for calling Christ the Lord, man, after confessing Him to be God, when many things combine to compel us to do so?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:128
verses.text: —What is there to compel us to call the Saviour Christ, "man"?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:129
verses.text: —The diverse and mutually inconsistent opinions of the heretics.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:130
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:131
verses.text: —What opinions, and contrary to what?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:132
verses.text: —That of Arius to that of Sabellius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:133
verses.text: The one divides the substances: the other confounds the hypostases.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:134
verses.text: Arius introduces three substances, and Sabellius makes one hypostasis instead of three.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:135
verses.text: Tell me now, how ought we to heal both maladies? Must we apply the same drug for both ailments, or for each the proper one?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:136
verses.text: —For each the proper one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:137
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:138
verses.text: —We shall therefore endeavour to persuade Arius to acknowledge the substance of the Holy Trinity, and we shall adduce proofs of this position from Holy Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:139
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:140
verses.text: —Yes: this ought to be done.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:141
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:142
verses.text: —But in arguing with Sabellius we shall adopt the opposite course.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:143
verses.text: Concerning the substance we shall advance no argument, for even he acknowledges but one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:144
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:145
verses.text: —Plainly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:146
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:147
verses.text: —But we shall do our best to cure the unsound part of his doctrine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:148
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:149
verses.text: —We say that where he halts is about the hypostases.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:150
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:151
verses.text: —Since then he asserts there to be one hypostasis of the Trinity, we shall point out to him that the divine Scripture proclaims three hypostases.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:152
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:153
verses.text: —This is the course to take.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:154
verses.text: But we have wandered from the subject.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:155
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:156
verses.text: —Not at all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:157
verses.text: We are collecting proofs of it, as you will learn in a moment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:158
verses.text: But tell me, do you understand that all the heresies which derive their name from Christ, acknowledge both the Godhead of Christ and His manhood?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:159
verses.text: —By no means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:160
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:161
verses.text: —Do not some acknowledge the godhead alone, and some the manhood alone?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:162
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:163
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:164
verses.text: —And some but a part of the manhood?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:165
verses.text: —I think so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:166
verses.text: But it will be well for us to lay down the names of the holders of these different opinions, that the point under discussion may be made plainer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:167
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:168
verses.text: —I will tell you the names.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:169
verses.text: Simon, Menander, Marcion, Valentinus, Basilides, Bardesanes, Cerdo, and Manes, openly denied the humanity of Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:170
