verses.text: On the other hand Artemon, Theodotus, Sabellius, Paul of Samosata, Marcellus, and Photinus, fell into the diametrically opposite blasphemy; for they preach Christ to be man only, and deny the Godhead which existed before the ages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:171
verses.text: Arius and Eunomius make the Godhead of the only begotten a created Godhead, and maintain that He assumed only a body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:172
verses.text: Apollinarius confesses that the assumed body was a living body, but in his work deprives the reasonable soul alike of its honour and of its salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:173
verses.text: This is the contrariety of these corrupt opinions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:174
verses.text: But do you, with all due love of truth, tell us, must we institute a discussion with these men, or shall we let them go dashed down headlong and howling to their doom?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:175
verses.text: —It is inhuman to neglect the sick.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:176
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:177
verses.text: —Very well; then we must compassionate them, and do our best to heal them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:178
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:179
verses.text: —By all means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:180
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:181
verses.text: —If then you had scientifically learned how to cure the body, and round you stood many men asking you to cure them, and shewing their various ailments, such as arise from running at the eyes, injury to the ears, tooth-ache, contraction of the joints, palsy, bile, or phlegm, what would you have done? Tell me; would you have applied the same treatment to all, or to each that which was appropriate?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:182
verses.text: —I should certainly have given to each the appropriate remedy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:183
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:184
verses.text: —So by applying cold treatment to the hot, and heating the cold, and loosing the strained, and giving tension to the loose, and drying the moist, and moistening the dry, you would have driven out the diseases and restored the health which they had expelled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:185
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:186
verses.text: —This is the treatment prescribed by medical science, for contraries, it is said, are the remedies of contraries.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:187
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:188
verses.text: —If you were a gardener, would you give the same treatment to all plants? or their own to the mulberry and the fig, and so to the pear, to the apple, and to the vine what is fitting to each, and in a word to each plant its own proper culture?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:189
verses.text: —It is obvious that each plant requires its own treatment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:190
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:191
verses.text: —And if you undertook to be a ship builder, and saw that the mast wanted repair, would you try to mend it in the same way as you would the tiller? or would you give it the proper treatment of a mast?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:192
verses.text: —There is no question about these things: everything demands its own treatment, be it plant or limb or gear or tackle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:193
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:194
verses.text: —Then is it not monstrous to apply to the body and to things without life to each its own appropriate treatment, and not to keep this rule of treatment in the case of the soul?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:195
verses.text: —Most unjust; nay, rather stupid than unrighteous.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:196
verses.text: They who adopt any other method are quite unskilled in the healing art.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:197
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:198
verses.text: —Then in disputing against each heresy we shall use the appropriate remedy?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:199
verses.text: —By all means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:200
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:201
verses.text: —And it is fitting treatment to add what is wanting and to remove what is superfluous?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:202
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:203
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:204
verses.text: —In endeavouring then to cure Photinus and Marcellus and their adherents, in order to carry out the rule of treatment, what should we add?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:205
verses.text: —The acknowledgment of the Godhead of Christ, for it is this that they lack.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:206
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:207
verses.text: —But about the manhood we will say nothing to them, for they acknowledge the Lord Christ to be man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:208
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:209
verses.text: —You are right.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:210
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:211
verses.text: —And in arguing with Arius and Eunomius about the incarnation of the only begotten, what should we persuade them to add to their own confession?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:212
verses.text: —The assumption of the soul; for they say that the divine Word took only a body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:213
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:214
verses.text: —And what does Apollinarius lack to make his teaching accurate about the incarnation?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:215
verses.text: —Not to separate the mind from the soul, but to confess that, with the body, was assumed a reasonable soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:216
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:217
verses.text: —Then shall we dispute with him on this point?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:218
verses.text: —Certainly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:219
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:220
verses.text: —But under this head what did we assert to be confessed, and what altogether denied, by Marcion, Valentinus, Manes and their adherents?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:221
verses.text: —That they admitted their belief in the Godhead of Christ, but do not accept the doctrine of His manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:222
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:223
verses.text: —We shall therefore do our best to persuade them to accept also the doctrine of the manhood, and not to call the divine incarnation a mere appearance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:224
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:225
verses.text: —It will be well so to do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:226
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:227
verses.text: —We will therefore tell them that it is right to style the Christ not only God, but also man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:228
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:229
verses.text: —By all means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:230
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:231
verses.text: —And how is it possible for us to induce others to style the Christ 'man' while we excuse ourselves from doing so? They will not yield to our persuasion, but on the contrary will convict us of agreeing with them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:232
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:233
verses.text: —And how can we, confessing as we do that the divine Word took flesh and a reasonable soul, agree with them?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:234
verses.text: —If we confess the fact, why then shun the word?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:235
verses.text: —It is right to name the Christ from His nobler qualities.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:236
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:237
verses.text: —Keep this rule then.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:238
verses.text: Do not speak of Him as crucified, nor yet as risen from the dead, and so on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:239
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:240
verses.text: —But these are the names of the sufferings of salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:241
verses.text: Denial of the sufferings implies denial of the salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:242
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:243
verses.text: —And the name Man is the name of a nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:244
verses.text: Not to pronounce the name is to deny the nature: denial of the nature is denial of the sufferings, and denial of the sufferings does away with the salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:245
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:246
verses.text: —I hold it profitable to acknowledge the assumed nature; but to style the Saviour of the world man is to belittle the glory of the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:247
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:248
verses.text: —Do you then deem yourself wiser than Peter and Paul; aye, and than the Saviour Himself? For the Lord said to the Jews "Why do ye seek to kill me, a man that hath told you the truth, which I heard of my Father?" And He frequently called Himself Son of Man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:249
verses.text: And the meritorious Peter, in his sermon to the Jewish people, says,—"Ye men of Israel, hear these words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:250
verses.text: Jesus of Nazareth, a man approved of God among you".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:251
verses.text: And the blessed Paul, when bringing the message of salvation to the chiefs of the Areopagus, among many other things said this,—  "And the times of this ignorance God winked at; but now commandeth all men everywhere to repent: Because he hath appointed a day in the which he will judge the world in righteousness by that man whom he hath ordained, whereof he hath given assurance unto all men, in that he hath raised him from the dead".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:252
verses.text: He then who excuses himself from using the name appointed and preached by the Lord and his Apostles deems himself wiser than even these great instructors, aye, even than the very well-spring of the wisest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:253
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:254
verses.text: —They gave this instruction to the unbelievers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:255
verses.text: Now the greater part of the world has professed the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:256
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:257
verses.text: —But we have still among us Jews and pagans and of heretics systems innumerable, and to each of these we must give fit and appropriate teaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:258
verses.text: But, supposing we were all of one mind, tell me now, what harm is there in calling the Christ both God and man? Do we not behold in Him perfect Godhead, and manhood likewise lacking in nothing?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:259
verses.text: —This we have owned again and again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:260
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:261
verses.text: —Why then deny what we have again and again owned?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:262
verses.text: —I hold it unnecessary to call the Christ 'man,'—especially when believer is conversing with believer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:263
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:264
verses.text: —Do you consider the divine Apostle a believer?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:265
verses.text: —Yes: a teacher of all believers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:266
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:267
verses.text: —And do you deem Timothy worthy of being so styled?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:268
verses.text: —Yes: both as a disciple of the Apostle, and as a teacher of the rest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:269
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:270
verses.text: —Very well: then hear the teacher of teachers writing to his very perfect disciple.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:271
verses.text: "There is one God, and one mediator between God and man, the man Christ Jesus, who gave himself a ransom for all".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:272
verses.text: Do stop your idle prating, and laying down the law about divine names.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:273
verses.text: Moreover in this passage that very name 'mediator' stands indicative both of Godhead and of manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:274
verses.text: He is called a mediator because He does not exist as God alone; for how, if He had had nothing of our nature could He have mediated between us and God? But since as God He is joined with God as having the same substance, and as man with us, because from us He took the form of a servant, He is properly termed a mediator, uniting in Himself distinct qualities by the unity of natures of Godhead, I mean, and of manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:275
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:276
verses.text: —But was not Moses called a mediator, though only a man?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:277
verses.text: —He was a type of the reality: but the type has not all the qualities of the reality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:278
verses.text: Wherefore though Moses was not by nature God, yet, to fulfil the type, he was called a god.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:279
verses.text: For He says "See, I have made thee a god to Pharaoh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:280
verses.text: And then directly afterwards he assigns him also a Prophet as though to God, for "Aaron thy brother," He says, "shall be thy Prophet".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:281
verses.text: But the reality is by nature God, and by nature man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:282
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:283
verses.text: —But who would call one not having the distinct characteristics of the archetype, a type?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:284
verses.text: —The imperial images, it seems, you do not call images of the emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:285
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:286
verses.text: —Yes, I do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:287
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:288
verses.text: —Yet they have not all the characteristics which their archetype has.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:289
verses.text: For in the first place they have neither life nor reason; secondly they have no inner organs, heart, I mean, and belly and liver and the adjacent parts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:290
verses.text: Further they present the appearance of the organs of sense, but perform none of their functions, for they neither hear, nor speak, nor see; they cannot write; they cannot walk, nor perform any other human action; and yet they are called imperial statues.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:291
verses.text: In this sense Moses was a mediator and Christ was a mediator; but the former as an image and type and the latter as reality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:292
verses.text: But that I may make this point clearer to you from yet another authority, call to mind the words used of Melchisedec in the Epistle to the Hebrews.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:293
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:294
verses.text: —What words?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:295
verses.text: —Those in which the divine Apostle comparing the Levitical priesthood with that of the Christ likens Melchisedec in other respects to the Lord Christ, and says that the Lord had the priesthood after the order of Melchisedec.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:296
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:297
verses.text: —I think the words of the divine Apostle are as follows;—"For this Melchisedec, king of Salem, priest of the most high God who met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings, and blessed him; to whom also Abraham gave a tenth part of all; first being by interpretation king of righteousness, and after that also king of Salem, which is king of peace; without father, without mother, without descent, having neither beginning of days, nor end of life; but made like unto the son of God; abideth a priest continually".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:298
verses.text: I presume you spoke of this passage.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:299
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:300
verses.text: —Yes, I spoke of this; and I must praise you for not mutilating it, but for quoting the whole.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:301
verses.text: Tell me now, does each one of these points fit Melchisedec in nature and reality?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:302
verses.text: —Who has the audacity to deny a fitness where the divine apostle has asserted it?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:303
verses.text: —Then you say that all this fits Melchisedec by nature?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:304
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:305
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:306
verses.text: —Do you say that he was a man, or assumed some other nature?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:307
verses.text: —A man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:308
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:309
verses.text: —Begotten or unbegotten?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:310
verses.text: —You are asking very absurd questions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:311
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:312
verses.text: —The fault lies with you for openly opposing the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:313
verses.text: Answer then.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:314
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:315
verses.text: —There is one only unbegotten, who is God and Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:316
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:317
verses.text: —Then we assert that Melchisedec was begotten?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:318
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:319
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:320
verses.text: —But the passage about him teaches the opposite.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:321
verses.text: Remember the words which you quoted a moment ago, "Without father, without mother, without descent, having neither beginning of days nor end of life".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:322
verses.text: How then do the words "Without father and without mother" fit him; and how the statement that he neither received beginning of existence nor end, since all this transcends humanity?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:323
verses.text: —These things do in fact overstep the limits of human nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:324
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:325
verses.text: —Then shall we say that the Apostle told lies?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:326
verses.text: —God forbid.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:327
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:328
verses.text: —How then is it possible both to testify to the truth of the Apostle, and apply the supernatural to Melchisedec?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:329
verses.text: —The passage is a very difficult one, and requires much explanation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:330
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:331
verses.text: —For any one willing to consider it with attention it will not be hard to attain perception of the meaning of the words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:332
verses.text: After saying "without father, without mother, without descent, having neither beginning of days nor end of life," the divine Apostle adds "made like unto the Son of God, abideth a priest continually".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:333
verses.text: Here he plainly teaches us that the Lord Christ is archetype of Melchisedec in things concerning the human nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:334
verses.text: And he speaks of Melchisedec as "made like unto the Son of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:335
verses.text: Now let us examine the point in this manner;—do you say that the Lord had a father according to the flesh?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:336
verses.text: —Certainly not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:337
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:338
verses.text: —Why?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:339
verses.text: —He was born of the holy Virgin alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:340
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:341
verses.text: —He is therefore properly styled "without father"?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:342
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:343
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:344
verses.text: —Do you say that according to the divine Nature He had a mother?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:345
verses.text: —Certainly not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:346
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:347
verses.text: —For He was begotten of the Father alone before the ages?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:348
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:349
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:350
verses.text: —And yet, as the generation He has of the Father is ineffable, He is spoken of as "without descent".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:351
verses.text: "Who" says the prophet "shall declare His generation?"  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:352
verses.text: —You are right.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:353
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:354
verses.text: —Thus it becomes Him to have neither beginning of days nor end of life; for He is without beginning, indestructible, and, in a word, eternal, and coeternal with the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:355
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:356
verses.text: —This is my view too.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:357
verses.text: But we must now consider how this fits the admirable Melchisedec.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:358
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:359
verses.text: —As an image and type.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:360
verses.text: The image, as we have just observed, has not all the properties of the archetype.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:361
verses.text: Thus to the Saviour these qualities are proper both by nature and in reality; but the story of the origin of the race has attributed them to Melchisedec.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:362
verses.text: For after telling us of the father of the patriarch Abraham, and of the father and mother of Isaac, and in like manner of Jacob and of his sons, and exhibiting the pedigree of our first forefathers, of Melchisedec it records neither the father nor the mother, nor does it teach that he traced his descent from any one of Noah's sons, to the end that he may be a type of Him who is in reality without father, and without mother.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:363
verses.text: And this is what the divine Apostle would have us understand, for in this very passage he says further, "But he whose descent is not counted from them received tithes of Abraham, and blessed him that had the promises".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:364
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:365
verses.text: —Then, since Holy Scripture has not mentioned his parents, can he be called without father and without mother?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:366
verses.text: —If he had really been without father and without mother, he would not have been an image, but a reality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:367
verses.text: But since these are his qualities not by nature, but according to the dispensation of the Divine Scripture, he exhibits the type of the reality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:368
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:369
verses.text: —The type must have the character of the archetype.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:370
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:371
verses.text: —Is man called an image of God?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:372
verses.text: —Man is not an image of God, but was made in the image of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:373
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:374
verses.text: —Listen then to the Apostle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:375
verses.text: He says: "For a man indeed ought not to cover his head, forasmuch as he is the image and glory of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:376
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:377
verses.text: —Granted, then, that he is an image of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:378
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:379
verses.text: —According to your argument then he must needs have plainly preserved the characters of the archetype, and have been uncreate, uncompounded, and infinite.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:380
verses.text: He ought in like manner to have been able to create out of the non existent, he ought to have fashioned all things by his word and without labour, in addition to this to have been free from sickness, sorrow, anger, and sin, to have been immortal and incorruptible and to possess all the qualities of the archetype.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:381
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:382
verses.text: —Man is not an image of God in every respect.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:383
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:384
verses.text: —Though truly an image in the qualities in which you would grant him to be so, you will find that he is separated by a wide interval from the reality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:385
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:386
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:387
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:388
verses.text: —Consider now too this point.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:389
verses.text: The divine Apostle calls the Son the image of the Father; for he says "Who is the image of the invisible God?"  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:390
verses.text: —What then; has not the Son all the qualities of the Father?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:391
verses.text: —He is not Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:392
verses.text: He is not uncaused.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:393
verses.text: He is not unbegotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:394
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:395
verses.text: —If He were He would not be Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:396
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:397
verses.text: —Then does not what I said hold good; the image has not all the qualities of the archetype?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:398
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:399
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:400
verses.text: —Thus too the divine Apostle said that Melchisedec is made like unto the Son of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:401
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:402
verses.text: —Suppose we grant that he is without Father and without Mother and without descent, as you have said.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:403
verses.text: But how are we to understand his having neither beginning of days nor end of life?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:404
verses.text: —The holy Moses when writing the ancient genealogy tells us how Adam being so many years old begat Seth, and when he had lived so many years he ended his life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:405
verses.text: So too he writes of Seth, of Enoch, and of the rest, but of Melchisedec he mentions neither beginning of existence nor end of life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:406
verses.text: Thus as far as the story goes he has neither beginning of days nor end of life, but in truth and reality the only begotten Son of God never began to exist and shall never have an end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:407
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:408
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:409
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:410
verses.text: —Then, so far as what belongs to God and is really divine is concerned, Melchisedec is a type of the Lord Christ; but as far as the priesthood is concerned, which belongs rather to man than to God, the Lord Christ was made a priest after the order of Melchisedec.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:411
verses.text: For Melchisedec was a high priest of the people, and the Lord Christ for all men has made the right holy offering of salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:412
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:413
verses.text: —We have spent many words on this matter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:414
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:415
verses.text: —Yet more were needed, as you know, for you said the point was a difficult one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:416
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:417
verses.text: —Let us return to the question before us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:418
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:419
verses.text: —What was the question?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:420
verses.text: —On my remarking that Christ must not be called man, but only God, you yourself besides many other testimonies adduced also the well known words of the Apostle which he has used in his epistle Timothy—"One God, one mediator between God and men, the man, Christ Jesus, who gave himself a ransom for all to be testified in due time".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:421
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:422
verses.text: —I remember from what point we diverged into this digression.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:423
verses.text: It was when I had said that the name of mediator exhibits the two natures of the Saviour, and you said that Moses was called a mediator though he was only a man and not God and man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:424
verses.text: I was therefore under the necessity of following up these points to show that the type has not all the qualities of the archetype.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:425
verses.text: Tell me, then, whether you allow that the Saviour ought also to be called man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:426
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:427
verses.text: —I call Him God, for He is God's Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:428
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:429
verses.text: —If you call him God, because you have learnt that he is God's Son, call him also man, for he often called Himself "Son of Man".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:430
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:431
verses.text: —The name man does not apply to Him in the same way as the name God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:432
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:433
verses.text: —As not really belonging to Him or for some other reason?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:434
verses.text: —God is his name by nature; man is the designation of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:435
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:436
verses.text: —But are we to look on the Incarnation as real, or as something imaginary and false?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:437
verses.text: —As real.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:438
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:439
verses.text: —If then the grace of the Incarnation is real, and what we call Incarnation is the divine Word's being made man, then the name man is real; for after taking man's nature He is called man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:440
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:441
verses.text: —Before His passion He was styled man, but afterward He was no longer so styled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:442
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:443
verses.text: —But it was after the Passion and the Resurrection that the divine Apostle wrote the Epistle to Timothy wherein he speaks of the Saviour Christ as man, and writing after the Passion and the Resurrection to the Corinthians he exclaims "For since by man came death, by man came also the resurrection of the dead".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:444
verses.text: And in order to make his meaning clear he adds, "For as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:445
verses.text: And after the Passion and the Resurrection the divine Peter, in his address to the Jews, called Him man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:446
verses.text: And after His being taken up into heaven, Stephen the victorious, amid the storm of stones, said to the Jews, "Behold, I see the heavens opened, and the Son of man standing on the right hand of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:447
verses.text: Are we to suppose ourselves wiser than the illustrious heralds of the truth?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:448
verses.text: —I do not suppose myself wiser than the holy doctors, but I fail to find the use of the name.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:449
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:450
verses.text: —How then could you persuade them that deny the incarnation of the Lord, Marcionists, I mean, and Manichees, and all the rest who are thus unsound, to accept the teaching of the truth, unless you adduce these and similar proofs with the object of shewing that the Lord Christ is not God only but also man?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:451
verses.text: —Perhaps it is necessary to adduce them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:452
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:453
verses.text: —Why not then teach the faithful the reality of the doctrine? Are you forgetful of the apostolic precept enjoining us to be "ready to give an answer".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:454
verses.text: Now let us look at the matter in this light.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:455
verses.text: Does the best general engage the enemy, attack with arrows and javelins, and endeavour to break their column all alone, or does he also arm his men, and marshal them, and rouse their hearts to play the man?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:456
verses.text: —He ought rather to do this latter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:457
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:458
verses.text: —Yes; for it is not the part of a general to expose his own life, and take his place in the ranks, and let his men go fast asleep, but rather to keep them awake for their work at their post.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:459
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:460
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:461
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:462
verses.text: —This is what the divine Paul did, for in writing to them who had made profession of their faith he said, "Take unto you the whole armour of God that ye be able to stand against the wiles of the Devil".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:463
verses.text: And again, "Stand therefore with your loins girt about with truth," and so on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:464
verses.text: Bear in mind too what we have already said, that a physician supplies what nature lacks.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:465
verses.text: Does he find the cold redundant? He supplies the hot, and so on with the rest; and this is what the Lord does.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:466
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:467
verses.text: —And where will you show that the Lord has done this?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:468
verses.text: —In the holy gospels.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:469
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:470
verses.text: —Show me then and fulfil your promise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:471
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:472
verses.text: —What did the Jews consider our Saviour Christ?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:473
verses.text: —A man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:474
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:475
verses.text: —And that He was also God they were wholly ignorant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:476
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:477
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:478
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:479
verses.text: —Was it not then necessary for the ignorant to learn?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:480
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:481
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:482
verses.text: —Listen to Him then saying to them: "Many good works have I shewed you from my Father; for which of these works do ye stone me?" And when they replied: "For a good work we stone thee not, but for blasphemy, and because that thou being a man makest thyself God," He added "It is written in your law I said ye are gods.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:483
verses.text: If he called them gods unto whom the word of God came and the scripture cannot be broken, say ye of Him whom the Father hath sanctified and sent into the world thou blasphemest, because I said I am the Son of God? If I do not the works of my father believe me not…that I am in the Father and the Father is in me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:484
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:485
verses.text: —In the passages you have just read you have shewn that the Lord shewed Himself to the Jews to be God and not man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:486
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:487
verses.text: —Yes, for they did not need to learn what they knew; that He was a man they knew, but they did not know that He was from the beginning God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:488
verses.text: He adopted this same course in the case of the Pharisees; for when He saw them accosting Him as a mere man He asked them "What think ye of Christ? Whose son is He?" And when they said "Of David" He went on "How then doth David calling him Lord say 'The Lord said unto my Lord sit thou on my right hand.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:489
verses.text: '" Then He goes on to argue, "If then He is His Lord how is He His Son?"  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:490
verses.text: —You have brought testimony against yourself, for the Lord plainly taught the Pharisees to call Him not "Son of David" but "Lord of David".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:491
verses.text: Wherefore He is distinctly shown wishing to be called God and not man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:492
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:493
verses.text: —I am afraid you have not attended to the divine teaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:494
verses.text: He did not repudiate the name of "Son of David," but He added that He ought also to be believed to be Lord of David.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:495
verses.text: This He clearly shews in the words "If He is his Lord how is He then his Son?" He did not say "if He is Lord He is not Son," but "how is He his Son?" instead of saying in one respect He is Lord and in another Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:496
verses.text: These passages both distinctly show the Godhead and the manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:497
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:498
verses.text: —There is no need of argument.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:499
verses.text: The Lord distinctly teaches that He does not wish to be called Son of David.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:500
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:501
verses.text: —Then He ought to have told the blind men and the woman of Canaan and the multitude not to call Him Son of David, and yet the blind men cried out "Thou Son of David have mercy on us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:502
verses.text: And the woman of Canaan "Have mercy on me O Son of David; my daughter is grievously vexed with a Devil".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:503
verses.text: And the multitude: "Hosanna to the Son of David! Blessed is He that cometh in the name of the Lord".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:504
verses.text: And not only did He not take it ill, but even praised their faith; for the blind He freed from their long weary night and granted them the power of sight; the maddened and distraught daughter of the woman of Canaan He healed and drove out the wicked demon; and when the chief priests and Pharisees were offended at them that shouted "Hosanna to the Son of David" He did not merely not prevent them from shouting, but even sanctioned their acclamation, for, said He, "I tell you that if these should hold their peace the stones would immediately cry out".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:505
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:506
verses.text: —He put up with this style of address before the resurrection in condescension to the weakness of them that had not yet properly believed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:507
verses.text: But after the resurrection these names are needless.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:508
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:509
verses.text: —Where shall we rank the blessed Paul? among the perfect or the imperfect?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:510
verses.text: —It is wrong to joke about serious things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:511
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:512
verses.text: —It is wrong to make light of the reading of the divine oracles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:513
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:514
verses.text: —And who is such a wretch as to despise his own salvation?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:515
verses.text: —Answer my question, and then you will learn your ignorance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:516
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:517
verses.text: —What question?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:518
verses.text: —Where are we to rank the divine Apostle?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:519
verses.text: —Plainly among the most perfect, and one of the perfect teachers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:520
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:521
verses.text: —And when did he begin his teaching?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:522
verses.text: —After the ascension of the Saviour, the coming of the Spirit, and the stoning of the victorious Stephen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:523
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:524
verses.text: —Paul, at the very end of his life, when writing his last letter to his disciple Timothy, and in giving him, as it were, his paternal inheritance by will, added "Remember that Jesus Christ of the seed of David was raised from the dead according to my gospel".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:525
verses.text: Then he went on to mention his sufferings on behalf of the gospel, and thus showed its truth saying, "Wherein I suffer trouble as an evil doer even unto bonds".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:526
verses.text: It were easy for me to adduce many similar testimonies, but I have judged it needless to do so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:527
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:528
verses.text: —You promised to prove that the Lord supplied the lacking instruction to them that needed, and you have shown that He discoursed about His own Godhead to the Pharisees, and to the rest of the Jews.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:529
verses.text: But that He gave also His instruction about the flesh you have not shewn.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:530
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:531
verses.text: —It would have been quite superfluous to have discoursed about the flesh which was before their eyes, for He was plainly seen eating and drinking and toiling and sleeping.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:532
verses.text: Furthermore, to omit the many and various events before the passion, after His resurrection He proved to His disbelieving disciples not His Godhead but His manhood; for He said, "Behold my hands and my feet that it is I myself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:533
verses.text: Handle me and see for a spirit hath not flesh and bones as ye see me have".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:534
verses.text: Now I have fulfilled my promise, for we have proved the giving of instruction about the Godhead to them that were ignorant of the Godhead, and about the resurrection of the flesh to them that denied this latter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:535
verses.text: Cease therefore from contending, and confess the two natures of the Saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:536
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:537
verses.text: —There were two before the union, but, after combining, they made one nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:538
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:539
verses.text: —When do you say that the union was effected?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:540
verses.text: —I say at the exact moment of the conception.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:541
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:542
verses.text: —And do you deny that the divine Word existed before the conception?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:543
verses.text: —I say that He was before the ages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:544
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:545
verses.text: —And that the flesh was co-existent with Him?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:546
verses.text: —By no means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:547
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:548
verses.text: —But was formed, after the salutation of the angel, of the Holy Ghost?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:549
verses.text: —So I say.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:550
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:551
verses.text: —Therefore before the union there were not two natures but only one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:552
verses.text: For if the Godhead pre-existed, but the manhood was not co-existent, being formed after the angelic salutation, and the union being coincident with the formation, then before the union there was one nature, that which exists always and existed before the ages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:553
verses.text: Now let us again consider this point.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:554
verses.text: Do you understand the making of flesh or becoming man to be anything other than the union?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:555
verses.text: —No.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:556
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:557
verses.text: —For when He took flesh He was made flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:558
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:559
verses.text: —Plainly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:560
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:561
verses.text: —And the union coincides with the taking flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:562
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:563
verses.text: —So I say.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:564
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:565
verses.text: —So before the making man there was one nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:566
verses.text: For if both union and making man are identical, and He was made man by taking man's nature, and the form of God took the form of a servant, then before the union the divine nature was one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:567
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:568
verses.text: —And how are the union and the making man identical?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:569
verses.text: —A moment ago you confessed that there is no distinction between these terms.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:570
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:571
verses.text: —You led me astray by your arguments.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:572
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:573
verses.text: —Then, if you like, let us go over the same ground again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:574
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:575
verses.text: —We had better so do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:576
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:577
verses.text: —Is there a distinction between the incarnation and the union, according to the nature of the transaction?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:578
verses.text: —Certainly; a very great distinction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:579
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:580
verses.text: —Explain fully the character of this distinction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:581
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:582
verses.text: —Even the sense of the terms shows the distinction, for the word "incarnation" shows the taking of the flesh, while the word "union" indicates the combination of distinct things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:583
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:584
verses.text: —Do you represent the incarnation to be anterior to the union?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:585
verses.text: —By no means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:586
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:587
verses.text: —You say that the union took place in the conception?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:588
verses.text: —I do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:589
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:590
verses.text: —Therefore if not even the least moment of time intervened between the taking of flesh and the union, and the assumed nature did not precede the assumption and the union, then incarnation and union signify one and the same thing, and so before the union and incarnation there was one nature, while after the incarnation we speak properly of two, of that which took and of that which was taken.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:591
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:592
verses.text: —I say that Christ was of two natures, but I deny two natures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:593
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:594
verses.text: —Explain to us then in what sense you understand the expression "of two natures;" like gilded silver? like the composition of electron? like the solder made of lead and tin?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:595
verses.text: —I deny that the union is like any of these; it is ineffable, and passes all understanding.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:596
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:597
verses.text: —I too confess that the manner of the union cannot be comprehended.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:598
verses.text: But I have at all events been instructed by the divine Scripture that each nature remains unimpaired after the union.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:599
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:600
verses.text: —And where is this taught in the divine Scripture?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:601
verses.text: —It is all full of this teaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:602
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:603
verses.text: —Give proof of what you assert.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:604
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:605
verses.text: —Do you not acknowledge the properties of each nature?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:606
verses.text: —No: not, that is, after the union.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:607
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:608
verses.text: —Let us then learn this very point from the divine Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:609
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:610
verses.text: —I am ready to obey the divine Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:611
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:612
verses.text: —When, then, you hear the divine John exclaiming "In the beginning was the word, and the word was with God, and the word was God" and "By Him all things were made" and the rest of the parallel passages, do you affirm that the flesh, or the divine Word, begotten before the ages of the Father, was in the beginning with God, and was by nature God, and made all things?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:613
verses.text: —I say that these things belong to God the Word.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:614
verses.text: But I do not separate Him from the flesh made one with Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:615
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:616
verses.text: —Neither do we separate the flesh from God the Word, nor do we make the union a confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:617
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:618
verses.text: —I recognise one nature after the union.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:619
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:620
verses.text: —When did the Evangelists write the gospel? Was it before the union, or a very long time after the union?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:621
verses.text: —Plainly after the union, the nativity, the miracles, the passion, the resurrection, the taking up into heaven, and the coming of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:622
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:623
verses.text: —Hear then John saying "In the beginning was the word, and the word was with God, and the word was God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:624
verses.text: He was in the beginning with God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:625
verses.text: All things were made by Him, and without Him was not anything made" and so on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:626
verses.text: Hear too Matthew, "The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, Son of David,—Son of Abraham,"—and so on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:627
verses.text: Luke too traced His genealogy to Abraham and David.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:628
verses.text: Now make the former and the latter quotation fit one nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:629
verses.text: You will find it impossible, for existence in the beginning, and descent from Abraham,—the making of all things, and derivation from a created forefather, are inconsistent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:630
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:631
verses.text: —By thus arguing you divide the only begotten son into two Persons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:632
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:633
verses.text: —One Son of God I both know and adore, the Lord Jesus Christ; but I have been taught the difference between His Godhead and his manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:634
verses.text: You, however, who say that there is only one nature after the union, do you make this agree with the introductions of the Evangelists.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:635
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:636
verses.text: —You appear to assume the proposition to be hard, nay impossible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:637
verses.text: Be it, I beg, short and easy;—only solve our question.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:638
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:639
verses.text: —Both qualities are proper to the Lord Christ,—existence from the beginning, and generation, according to the flesh, from Abraham and David.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:640
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:641
verses.text: —You laid down the law that after the union it is not right to speak of one nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:642
verses.text: Take heed lest in mentioning the flesh you transgress your own law.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:643
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:644
verses.text: —Even without mentioning the flesh it is quite easy to explain the point in question, for I am applying both to the Saviour Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:645
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:646
verses.text: —I too assert that both these qualities belong to the Lord Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:647
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:648
verses.text: —Yes; but you do so in contemplation of two natures in Him, and applying to each its own properties.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:649
verses.text: But if the Christ is one nature, how is it possible to attribute to it properties which are inconsistent with one another? For to have derived origin from Abraham and David, and still more to have been born many generations after David, is inconsistent with existence in the beginning.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:650
verses.text: Again to have sprung from created beings is inconsistent with being Creator of all things; to have had human fathers with existence derived from God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:651
verses.text: In short the new is inconsistent with the eternal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:652
verses.text: Let us also look at the matter in this way.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:653
verses.text: Do we say that the divine Word is Creator of the Universe?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:654
verses.text: —So we have learnt to believe from the divine Scriptures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:655
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:656
verses.text: —And how many days after the creation of heaven and earth are we told that Adam was formed?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:657
verses.text: —On the sixth day.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:658
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:659
verses.text: —And from Adam to Abraham how many generations went by?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:660
verses.text: —I think twenty.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:661
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:662
verses.text: —And from Abraham to Christ our Saviour how many generations are reckoned by the Evangelist Matthew.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:663
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:664
verses.text: —Forty-two.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:665
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:666
verses.text: —If then the Lord Christ is one nature how can He be Creator of all things visible and invisible and, at the same time, after so many generations, have been formed by the Holy Ghost in a virgin's womb? And how could He be at one and the same time Creator of Adam and Son of Adam's descendants?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:667
verses.text: —I have already said that both these properties are appropriate to Him as God made flesh, for I recognise one nature made flesh of the Word.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:668
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:669
verses.text: —Nor yet, my good sir, do we say that two natures of the divine Word were made flesh, for we know that the nature of the divine Word is one, but we have been taught that the flesh of which He availed Himself when He was incarnate is of another nature, and here I think that you too agree with me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:670
verses.text: Tell me now; after what manner do you say that the making flesh took place?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:671
verses.text: —I know not the manner, but I believe that He was made flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:672
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:673
verses.text: —You make a pretext of your ignorance unfairly, and after the fashion of the Pharisees.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:674
verses.text: For they when they beheld the force of the Lord's enquiry, and suspecting that they were on the point of conviction, uttered their reply "We do not know".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:675
verses.text: But I proclaim quite openly that the divine incarnation is without change.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:676
verses.text: For if by any variation or change He was made flesh, then after the change all that is divine in His names and in His deeds is quite inappropriate to Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:677
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:678
verses.text: —We have agreed again and again that God the Word is immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:679
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:680
verses.text: —He was made flesh by taking flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:681
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:682
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:683
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:684
verses.text: —The nature of God the Word made flesh is different from that of the flesh, by assumption of which the nature of the divine Word was made flesh and became man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:685
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:686
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:687
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:688
verses.text: —Was He then changed into flesh?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:689
verses.text: —Certainly not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:690
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:691
verses.text: —If then He was made flesh, not by mutation, but by taking flesh, and both the former and the latter qualities are appropriate to Him as to God made flesh, as you said a moment ago, then the natures were not confounded, but remained unimpaired.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:692
verses.text: And as long as we hold thus we shall perceive too the harmony of the Evangelists, for while the one proclaims the divine attributes of the one only begotten—the Lord Christ—the other sets forth His human qualities.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:693
verses.text: So too Christ our Lord Himself teaches us, at one time calling Himself Son of God and at another Son of man: at one time He gives honour to His Mother as to her that gave Him birth; at another He rebukes her as her Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:694
verses.text: At one time He finds no fault with them that style Him Son of David; at another He teaches the ignorant that He is not only David's Son but also David's Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:695
verses.text: He calls Nazareth and Capernaum His country, and again He exclaims "Before Abraham was I am".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:696
verses.text: You will find the divine Scripture full of similar passages, and they all point not to one nature but to two.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:697
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:698
verses.text: —He who contemplates two natures in the Christ divides the one only begotten into two sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:699
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:700
verses.text: —Yes; and he who says Paul is made up of soul and body makes two Pauls out of one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:701
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:702
verses.text: —The analogy does not hold good.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:703
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:704
verses.text: —I know it does not, for here the union is a natural union of parts that are coaeval, created, and fellow slaves, but in the case of the Lord Christ all is of good will, of love to man, and of grace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:705
verses.text: Here too, though the union is natural, the proper qualities of the natures remain unimpaired.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:706
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:707
verses.text: —If the proper qualities of the natures remain distinct, how does the soul together with the body crave for food?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:708
verses.text: —The soul does not crave for food.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:709
verses.text: How could it when it is immortal? But the body, which derives its vital force from the soul, feels its need, and desires to receive what is lacking.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:710
verses.text: So after toil it longs for rest, after waking for sleep, and so with the rest of its desires.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:711
verses.text: So forthwith after its dissolution, since it has no longer its vital energy, it does not even crave for what is lacking, and, ceasing to receive it, it undergoes corruption.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:712
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:713
verses.text: —You see that to thirst and to hunger and similar appetites belong to the soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:714
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:715
verses.text: —Did these belong to the soul it would suffer hunger and thirst, and the similar wants, even after its release from the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:716
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:717
verses.text: —What then do you say to be proper to the soul?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:718
verses.text: —The reasonable, the absolute, the immortal, the invisible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:719
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:720
verses.text: —And what of the body?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:721
verses.text: —The complex, the visible, the mortal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:722
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:723
verses.text: —And we say that man is composed of these?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:724
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:725
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:726
verses.text: —Then we define man as a mortal reasonable being.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:727
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:728
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:729
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:730
verses.text: —And we give names to him from both these attributes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:731
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:732
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:733
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:734
verses.text: —As then in this case we make no distinction, but call the same man both reasonable and mortal, so also should we do in the case of the Christ, and apply to Him both the divine and the human.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:735
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:736
verses.text: —This is our argument, although you do not accurately express it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:737
verses.text: For look you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:738
verses.text: When we are pursuing the argument about the human soul, do we only mention what is appropriate to its energy and nature?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:739
verses.text: —This only.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:740
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:741
verses.text: —And when our discussion is about the body, do we not only recall what is appropriate to it?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:742
verses.text: —Quite so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:743
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:744
verses.text: —But, when our discourse touches the whole being, then we have no difficulty in adducing both sets of qualities, for the properties both of the body and of the soul are applicable to man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:745
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:746
verses.text: —Unquestionably.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:747
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:748
verses.text: —Well; just in this way should we speak of the Christ, and, when arguing about His natures, give to each its own, and recognise some as belonging to the Godhead, and some as to the manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:749
verses.text: But when we are discussing the Person we must then make what is proper to the natures common, and apply both sets of qualities to the Saviour, and call the same Being both God and Man, both Son of God and Son of Man—both David's Son and David's Lord, both Seed of Abraham and Creator of Abraham, and so on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:750
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:751
verses.text: —That the person of the Christ is one, and that both the divine and the human are attributable to Him, you have quite rightly said, and I accept this definition of the Faith; but your real position, that in discussing the natures we must give to each its own properties, seems to me to dissolve the union.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:752
verses.text: It is for this reason that I object to accept these and similar arguments.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:753
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:754
verses.text: —Yet when we were enquiring about soul and body you thought the distinction of these terms admirable, and forthwith gave it your approbation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:755
verses.text: Why then do you refuse to receive the same rule in the case of the Godhead and manhood of the Lord Christ? Do you go so far as to object to comparing the Godhead and the manhood of the Christ to soul and body? So, while you grant an unconfounded union to soul and body, do you venture to say that the Godhead and manhood of the Christ have undergone commixture and confusion?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:756
verses.text: —I hold the Godhead of the Christ aye, and His flesh too, to be infinitely higher in honour than soul and body; but after the union I do assert one nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:757
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:758
verses.text: —But now is it not impious and shocking, while maintaining that a soul united to a body is in no way subject to confusion, to deny to the Godhead of the Lord of the universe the power to maintain its own nature unconfounded or to keep within its proper bounds the humanity which He assumed? Is it not, I say, impious to mix the distinct, and to commingle the separate? The idea of one nature gives ground for suspicion of this confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:759
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:760
verses.text: —I am equally anxious to avoid the term confusion, but I shrink from asserting two natures lest I fall into a dualism of sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:761
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:762
verses.text: —I am equally anxious to escape either horn of the dilemma, both the impious confusion and the impious distinction; for to me it is alike an unhallowed thought to split the one Son in two and to gainsay the duality of the natures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:763
verses.text: But now in truth's name tell me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:764
verses.text: Were one of the faction of Arius or Eunomius to endeavour, while disputing with you, to belittle the Son, and to describe Him as less than and inferior to the Father, by the help of all their familiar arguments and citations from the divine Scripture of the text "Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me" and that other, "Now is my soul troubled" and other like passages, how would you dispose of his objections? How could you show that the Son is in no way diminished in dignity by these expressions and is not of another substance, but begotten of the substance of the Father?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:765
verses.text: —I should say that the divine Scripture uses some terms according to the theology and some according to the oeconomy, and that it is wrong to apply what belongs to the oeconomy to what belongs to the theology.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:766
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:767
verses.text: —But your opponent would retort that even in the Old Testament the divine Scripture says many things oeconomically, as for instance, "Adam heard the voice of the Lord God walking," and "I will go down now and see whether they have done altogether according to the cry of it which has come to me; and if not I will know," and again, "Now I know that thou fearest God" and the like.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:768
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:769
verses.text: —I might answer to this that there is a great distinction between the oeconomies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:770
verses.text: In the Old Testament there is an oeconomy of words; in the New Testament of deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:771
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:772
verses.text: —Then your opponent would ask of what deeds?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:773
verses.text: —He shall straightway hear of the deeds of the making flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:774
verses.text: For the Son of God on being made man both in word and deed at one time exhibits the flesh, at another the Godhead: as of course, in the passage quoted, He shews the weakness of the flesh and of the soul, the sense namely of fear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:775
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:776
verses.text: —But if he were to go on to say, "But he did not take a soul but only a body; for the Godhead instead of a soul being united to the body performed all the functions of the soul," with what arguments could you meet his objections?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:777
verses.text: —I could bring proofs from the divine Scripture shewing how God the Word took not only flesh but also soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:778
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:779
verses.text: —And what proofs of this shall we find in Scripture?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:780
verses.text: —Have you not heard the Lord saying "I have power to lay it down, and I have power to take it again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:781
verses.text: …I lay it down of myself that I might take it again".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:782
verses.text: And again, "Now is my soul troubled".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:783
verses.text: And again, "My soul is exceeding sorrowful even unto death," and again David's words as interpreted by Peter "His soul was not left in hell neither did His flesh see corruption".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:784
verses.text: These and similar passages clearly point out that God the Word assumed not only a body but also a soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:785
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:786
verses.text: —You have quoted this testimony most appositely and properly, but your opponent might reply that even before the incarnation God said to the Jews, "Fasting and holy day and feasts my soul hateth".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:787
verses.text: Then he might go on to argue that as in the Old Testament He mentioned a soul, though He had not a soul, so He does in the New.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:788
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:789
verses.text: —But he shall be told again how the divine Scripture, when speaking of God, mentions even parts of the body as "Incline thine ear and hear" and "Open thine eyes and see" and "The mouth of the Lord hath spoken it" and "Thy hands have made me and fashioned me" and countless other passages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:790
verses.text: If then after the incarnation we are forbidden to understand soul to mean soul, it is equally forbidden to hold body to mean body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:791
verses.text: Thus the great mystery of the oeconomy will be found to be mere imagination; and we shall in no way differ from Marcion, Valentinus and Manes, the inventors of all these figments.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:792
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:793
verses.text: —But if a follower of Apollinarius were suddenly to intervene in our discussion and were to ask "Most excellent Sir; what kind of soul do you say that Christ assumed?" what would you answer?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:794
verses.text: —I should first of all say that I know only one soul of man; then I should answer, "But if you reckon two souls, the one reasonable and the other without reason, I say that the soul assumed was the reasonable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:795
verses.text: Yours it seems is the unreasonable, inasmuch as you think that our salvation was incomplete".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:796
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:797
verses.text: —But suppose he were to ask for proof of what you say?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:798
