Of the same from the same work:—  "Wherefore not before the passion, but after the passion, the Lord stood in the midst of the disciples when the doors were shut, that thou mayest know that thy natural body after being sown is 'raised a spiritual body,' and that thou mayest not suppose the body that is raised to be a different body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1261
verses.text: When Thomas after the resurrection doubted, He shews him the prints of the nails, He shews him the marks of the spears.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1262
verses.text: But had He not power to heal Himself after the resurrection too, when even before the resurrection He had healed all men? But by shewing the prints of the nails He shews that it is this very body; by coming in when the doors were shut He shews that it has not the same qualities; the same body to fulfil the work of the incarnation by raising that which had become a corpse, but a changed body that it fall not again under corruption nor be subject again to death".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1263
verses.text: Testimony of the blessed Theophilus, bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1264
verses.text: From his work against Origen:—  "Our likeness which He assumed is not changed into the nature of Godhead nor is His Godhead turned into our likeness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1265
verses.text: For He remains what He was from the beginning God, and He so remains preserving our subsistence in Himself".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1266
verses.text: Of the same from the same treatise:—  "But you persist continually in your blasphemies attacking the Son of God, and using these words 'as the Son and the Father are one, so also are the soul which the Son took and the Son Himself one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1267
verses.text: ' You are ignorant that the Son and the Father are one on account of their one substance and the same Godhead; but the soul and the Son are each of a different substance and different nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1268
verses.text: For if the soul of the Son and the Son Himself are one in the same sense in which the Father and the Son are one, then the Father and the Soul will be one and the soul of the Son shall one day say 'He that hath seen Me hath seen the Father;' but this is not so; God forbid.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1269
verses.text: For the Son and the Father are one because there is no distinction between their qualities, but the soul and the Son are distinguished alike in nature and substance, in that the soul which is naturally of one substance with us was made by Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1270
verses.text: For if the soul and the Son are one in the same manner in which the Father and the Son are one, as Origen would have it, then the soul equally with the Son will be 'the brightness of God's glory and express image of His person.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1271
verses.text: ' But this is impossible; impossible that the Son and the soul should be one as He and the Father are one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1272
verses.text: And what will Origen do when again he attacks himself? For he writes, never could the soul distressed and 'exceeding sorrowful' be the 'firstborn of every creature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1273
verses.text: ' For God the Word, as being stronger than the soul, the Son Himself, says 'I have power to lay it down and I have power to take it again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1274
verses.text: ' If then the Son is stronger than His own soul, as is agreed, how can His soul be equal to God and in the form of God? For we say that 'He emptied Himself and took upon Him the form of a servant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1275
verses.text: ' In the extravagance of his impieties Origen surpasses all other heretics, as we have shewn, for if the Word exists in the form of God and is equal to God and if he supposes thus daring to write the soul of the Saviour to be in the form of God and equal with God, how can the equal be greater, when the inferior in nature testifies to the superiority of what is beyond it?"  Testimony of the Holy John Chrysostom, bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1276
verses.text: From the Discourse held in the Great Church:—  "Thy Lord exalted man to heaven, and thou wilt not even give him a share of the agora.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1277
verses.text: But why do I say 'to heaven'? He seated man on a kingly throne.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1278
verses.text: Thou expellest him from the city".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1279
verses.text: Of the same, on the beginning of Ps.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1280
verses.text: xlii.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1281
verses.text: :—  "Up to this day Paul does not cease to say 'We are ambassadors for Christ as though God did beseech you by us; we pray you in Christ's stead, be ye reconciled to God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1282
verses.text: ' Nor did He stand here, but taking the first fruits of thy nature He sat down 'above all principality and power and might, and every name that is named not only in this world but in the world to come.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1283
verses.text: ' What could be equal to this honour? The first fruits of our race which has so much offended and is so dishonoured sits so high and enjoys honour so vast".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1284
verses.text: Of the same about the division of tongues:—  "For bethink thee what it is to see our nature riding on the Cherubim and all the power of heaven mustered round about it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1285
verses.text: Consider too Paul's wisdom and how many terms he searches for that he may set forth the love of Christ to men, for he does not say simply the grace, nor yet simply the riches, but the 'exceeding great riches of His grace in His kindness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1286
verses.text: '"  Of the same from his Dogmatic Oration, on the theme that the word spoken and deeds done in humility by Christ were not so spoken and done on account of infirmity, but on account of differences of dispensation:—  "And after His resurrection, when He saw His disciple disbelieving, He did not shrink from shewing him both wound and print of nails, and letting him lay his hand upon the scars, and said 'Examine and see, for a spirit hath not flesh and bones.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1287
verses.text: ' The reason of His not assuming the manhood of full age from the beginning, and of His deigning to be conceived, to be born, to be suckled, and to live so long upon the earth, was that by the long period of the time and all the other circumstances, He might give a warranty for this very thing".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1288
verses.text: Of the same against those who assert that demons rule human affairs:—  "Nothing was more worthless than man and than man nothing has become more precious.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1289
verses.text: He was the last part of the reasonable creation, but the feet have been made the head, and through the firstfruits have been borne up to the kingly throne.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1290
verses.text: Just as some man noble and bountiful, on seeing a wretch escaped from shipwreck who has saved nothing but his bare body from the waves, welcomes him with open hands, clothes him in a radiant robe, and exalts him to the highest honour, so too hath God done towards our nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1291
verses.text: Man had lost all that he had, his freedom, his intercourse with God, his abode in Paradise, his painless life, whence he came forth like a man all naked from a wreck, but God received him and straightway clothed him, and, taking him by the hand, led him onward step by step and brought him up to heaven".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1292
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "But God made the gain greater than the loss, and exalted our nature to the royal throne.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1293
verses.text: So Paul exclaims 'And have raised us up together and made us sit together in heavenly places' at His right hand".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1294
verses.text: Of the same from his IIIrd oration against the Jews:—  "He opened the heavens; of foes he made friends; He introduced them into heaven; He seated our nature on the right hand of the throne; He gave us countless other good things".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1295
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse on the Ascension:—  "To this distance and height did He exalt our nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1296
verses.text: Look where low it lay, and where it mounted up.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1297
verses.text: Lower it was impossible to descend than where man descended; higher it was impossible to rise than where He exalted him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1298
verses.text: Of the same from his interpretation of the Epistle to the Ephesians:—  "According to His good pleasure, which He had proposed in himself, that is which He earnestly desired, He was as it were in labour to tell us the mystery.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1299
verses.text: And what is this mystery? That He wishes to seat man on high; as in truth came to pass".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1300
verses.text: Of the same from the same interpretation:—  "God of our Lord Jesus Christ speaks of this and not of God the Word".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1301
verses.text: Of the same from the same interpretation:—  "'And when we were dead in sins He quickened us together in Christ;' again Christ stands in the midst, and the work is wonderful.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1302
verses.text: If the first fruits live we live also.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1303
verses.text: He quickened both Him and us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1304
verses.text: Seest thou that all these things are spoken according to the flesh?"  Of the same from the gospel according to St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1305
verses.text: John:—  "Why does he add 'and dwelt among us'? It is as though he said: Imagine nothing absurd from the phrase 'was made.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1306
verses.text: ' For I have not mentioned any change in that unchangeable nature, but of tabernacling and of inhabiting.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1307
verses.text: Now that which tabernacles is not identical with the tabernacle, but one thing tabernacles in another; otherwise there would be no tabernacling.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1308
verses.text: Nothing inhabits itself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1309
verses.text: I spoke of a distinction of substance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1310
verses.text: For by the union and the conjunction God the Word and the flesh are one without confusion or destruction of the substances, but by ineffable and indescribable union".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1311
verses.text: Of the same from the gospel according to St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1312
verses.text: Matthew:—  "Just as one standing in the space between two that are separated from one another, stretches out both his hands and joins them, so too did He, joining the old and the new, the divine nature and the human, His own with ours".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1313
verses.text: Of the same from the Ascension of Christ:—  "For so when two champions stand ready for the fight, some other intervening between them, at once stops the struggle, and puts an end to their ill will, so too did Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1314
verses.text: As God He was wroth, but we made light of His wrath, and turned away our faces from our loving Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1315
verses.text: Then Christ flung Himself in the midst, and restored both natures to mutual love, and Himself took on Him the weight of the punishment laid by the Father on us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1316
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "Lo He brought the first fruits of our nature to the Father and the Father Himself approved the gift, alike on account of the high dignity of Him that bought it and of the faultlessness of the offering.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1317
verses.text: He received it in His own hands, He made a chair of His own throne; nay more He seated it on His own right hand, let us then recognise who it was to whom it was said 'Sit thou on my right hand' and what was that nature to which God said 'Dust thou art and to dust thou shalt return.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1318
verses.text: '"  Of the same a little further on:—  "What arguments to use, what words to utter I cannot tell; the nature which was rotten, worthless, declared lowest of all, vanquished everything and overcame the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1319
verses.text: To-day it hath been thought worthy to be made higher than all, to-day it hath received what from old time angels have desired; to-day it is possible for archangels to be made spectators of what has been for ages longed for, and they contemplate our nature, shining on the throne of the King in the glory of His immortality".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1320
verses.text: Testimony of St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1321
verses.text: Flavianus, bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1322
verses.text: From the Gospel according to St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1323
verses.text: Luke:—  "In all of us the Lord writes the express image of His holiness, and in various ways shows our nature the way of salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1324
verses.text: Many and clear proofs does He give us both of His bodily advent and of His Godhead working by a body's means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1325
verses.text: For He wished to give us assurance of both His natures".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1326
verses.text: Of the same on the Theophany:—  "'Who can express the noble acts of the Lord, or shew forth all His praise?' who could express in words the greatness of His goodness toward us? Human nature is joined to Godhead, while both natures remain independent".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1327
verses.text: Testimony of Cyril, bishop Jerusalem.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1328
verses.text: From his fourth catechetical oration concerning the ten dogmas.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1329
verses.text: Of the birth from a virgin:—  "Believe thou that this only begotten Son of God, on account of our sins, came down from heaven to earth, having taken on Him this manhood of like passions with us, and being born of holy Virgin and of Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1330
verses.text: This incarnation was effected, not in seeming and unreality, but in reality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1331
verses.text: He did not only pass through the Virgin, as through a channel, but was verily made flesh of her.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1332
verses.text: Like us He really ate, and of the Virgin was really suckled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1333
verses.text: For if the incarnation was an unreality, then our salvation is a delusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1334
verses.text: The Christ was twofold—the visible man, the invisible God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1335
verses.text: He ate as man, verily like ourselves, for the flesh that He wore was of like passions with us; He fed the five thousand with five loaves as God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1336
verses.text: As man He really died.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1337
verses.text: As God He raised the dead on the fourth day.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1338
verses.text: As man He slept in the boat.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1339
verses.text: As God He walked upon the waters".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1340
verses.text: Testimony of Antiochus, bishop of Ptolemais:—  "Do not confound the natures and you will have a lively apprehension of the incarnation".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1341
verses.text: Testimony of the holy Hilarius, bishop and confessor,in his ninth book, "de Fide":  "He who knoweth not Jesus the Christ as very God and as very man, knoweth not in reality his own life, for we incur the same peril if we deny Christ Jesus or God the spirit, or the flesh of our own body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1342
verses.text: 'Whosoever therefore shall confess me before men him will I confess also before my Father which is in Heaven, but whosoever shall deny me before men him will I also deny before my Father which is in Heaven.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1343
verses.text: ' These things spoke the Word made flesh; these things the man Christ Jesus, Lord of Glory, taught, being made Mediator for the salvation of the Church in the very mystery whereby He mediated between God and men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1344
verses.text: Both being made one out of the natures united for this very purpose, He was one and the same through either nature, but so that in both He fell short in neither, lest haply by being born as man He should cease to be God, or by remaining God should not be man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1345
verses.text: Therefore this is the blessedness of the true faith among men to preach both God and man, to confess both word and flesh, to recognise that God was also man, and not to be ignorant that the flesh is also Word".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1346
verses.text: Of the same from the same book:—  "So the only begotten God being born man of a Virgin and in the fulness of the time, being Himself ordained to work out the advance of man to God, observed this order of things, through all the words of the gospels, that He might teach belief in Himself, as Son of God, and keep us in mind to preach Him as Son of Man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1347
verses.text: As being man He always spoke and acted as is proper to man, but in such a manner as never to speak in this same mode of speech as touching both save with the intention of signifying both God and Man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1348
verses.text: But hence the heretics derive a pretext for catching in their traps simple and ignorant men: what was spoken by our Lord in accordance with His manhood they falsely assert to have been uttered in the weakness of His divine nature, and since one and the same person spake all the words He used they urged that all He uttered He uttered about Himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1349
verses.text: Now even we do not deny that all His extant words are of His own nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1350
verses.text: But granted that the one Christ is man and God; granted that when man He was not then first God; granted that when man He was then also God, granted that after the assumption of the manhood in the Lord, the Word was man and the Word was God, it follows of necessity that there is one and the same mystery of His words as there is of His generation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1351
verses.text: Whenever in Him, as occasion may require, you distinguish the manhood from the Godhead, then also endeavour to separate the words of God from the words of man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1352
verses.text: And whenever you confess God and man, then discern the words of God and man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1353
verses.text: And when the words are spoken of God and man, and again of man wholly and wholly of God, consider carefully the occasion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1354
verses.text: If anything was spoken to signify what was appropriate to a particular occasion, apply the words to the occasion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1355
verses.text: A distinction must be observed between God before the manhood, man and God, man wholly and God wholly after the union of the manhood and Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1356
verses.text: Take heed therefore not to confuse the mystery of the incarnation in the words and acts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1357
verses.text: For it must needs be that according to the quality of the kinds of natures a distinction lies in the manner of speech, before the manhood was born, in accordance with the mystery when it was still approaching death, and again when it was everlasting.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1358
verses.text: 'For if in His birth and in His passion and in His death He acted in accordance with our nature He nevertheless effected all this by the power of His own nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1359
verses.text: '"  Of the same in the same book:—  "Do you then see that thus God and man are confessed, so that death is predicated of man, and the resurrection of the flesh, of God; for consider the nature of God and the power of the resurrection, and recognise in the death the oeconomy as touching man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1360
verses.text: And since both death and resurrection have been brought about in their own natures, bear in mind, I beg you, the one Christ Jesus, who was of both.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1361
verses.text: I have shortly demonstrated these points to you to the end that we may remember both natures to have been in our Lord Jesus Christ 'for being in the form of God He took the form of a servant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1362
verses.text: '"  Testimony of the very holy bishop Augustinus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1363
verses.text: From his letter to Volusianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1364
verses.text: Epistle III:  "But now He appeared as Mediator between God and man, so as in the unity of His person to conjoin both natures, by combining the wonted with the unwonted, and the unwonted with the wonted".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1365
verses.text: Of the same from his exposition of the Gospel according to John:—  "What then, O heretic? Since Christ is also man, He speaks as man; and dost thou slander God? He in Himself lifts man's nature on high, and thou hast the hardihood to cheapen His divine nature".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1366
verses.text: Of the same from his book on the Exposition at the Faith:—  "It is ours to believe, but His to know, and so let God the Word Himself, after receiving all that is proper to man, be man, and let man after His assumption and reception of all that is God, be no other than God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1367
verses.text: It must not be supposed because He is said to have been incarnate and mixed that therefore His substance was diminished.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1368
verses.text: God knows that He mixes Himself without the natural corruption, and He is mixed in reality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1369
verses.text: He knows also that He so received in Himself as that no addition of increment accrues to Himself, as also He knows He infused His whole self so as to incur no diminution.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1370
verses.text: Let us not then, in accordance with our weak intelligence, and forming conjectures on the teaching of experience and the senses, suppose that God and man are mixed after the manner of things created and equal mixed together, and that from such a confusion as this of the Word and of the flesh a body as it were was made.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1371
verses.text: God forbid that this should be our belief, lest we should suppose that after the manner of things which are confounded together two natures were brought into one hypostasis.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1372
verses.text: For a mention of this kind implies destruction of both parts; but Christ Himself, containing but not contained, who examines us but is Himself beyond examination, making full but not made full, everywhere at one and the same time being Himself whole and pervading the universe, through His pouring out His own power, as being moved with mercy, was mingled with the nature of man, though the nature of man was not mingled with the divine".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1373
verses.text: Testimony of Severianus, bishop of Gabala.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1374
verses.text: From "the Nativity of Christ":—  "O mystery truly heavenly and yet on earth—mystery seen and not apparent for so was the Christ after His birth; heavenly and yet on earth; holding and not held; seen and invisible; of Heaven as touching the nature of the Godhead, on earth as touching the nature of the manhood; seen in the flesh, invisible in the spirit; held as to the body not to be holden as to the Word".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1375
verses.text: Testimony of Atticus, bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1376
verses.text: From his letter to Eupsychius:—  "How then did it behove the Most Wise to act? By mediation of the flesh assumed, and by union of God the Word with man born of Mary, He is made of either nature, so that the Christ made one of both, as constituted in Godhead, abides in the proper dignity of His impassible nature, but in flesh, being brought near to death, at one and the same time shews the kindred nature of the flesh how through death to despise death, and by His death confirms the righteousness of the new covenant".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1377
verses.text: Testimony of Cyril, bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1378
verses.text: From his letter to Nestorius:—  "The natures which have been brought together in the true unity are distinct, and of both there is one God and Son, but the difference of the natures has not been removed in consequence of the union".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1379
verses.text: Of the same from his letter against the Orientals:—  "There is an union of two natures, wherefore we acknowledge one Christ, one Son, one Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1380
verses.text: In accordance with this perception of the unconfounded union we acknowledge the Holy Virgin as Mother of God because the Word of God was made flesh and was made man, and from the very conception united to Himself the temper taken from her".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1381
verses.text: Of the same:—  "There is one Lord Jesus Christ, even if the difference be recognised of the natures of which we assert the ineffable union to have been made".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1382
verses.text: Of the same:—  "Therefore, as I said, while praising the manner of the incarnation, we see that two natures came together in inseparable union without confusion and without division, for the flesh is flesh and no kind of Godhead, although it was made flesh of God; in like manner the Word is God, and not flesh, although He made the flesh His own according to the oeconomy".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1383
verses.text: Of the same from his interpretation of the Epistle to the Hebrews:—  "For although the natures which came together in unity are regarded as different and unequal with one another, I mean of flesh and of God, nevertheless the Son, Who was made of both, is one".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1384
verses.text: Of the same from his interpretation of the same Epistle:—  "Yet though the only begotten Word of God is said to be united in hypostasis to flesh, we deny there was any confusion of the natures with one another, and declare each to remain what it is".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1385
verses.text: Of the same from his commentaries:—  "The Father's Word, born of the Virgin, is named man, though being by nature God as partaking of flesh and blood like us for thus He was seen by men upon earth, without getting rid of His own nature, but assuming our Manhood perfect according to its own reason".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1386
verses.text: Of the same concerning the Incarnation (Schol.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1387
verses.text: c.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1388
verses.text: ):—  "Then before the incarnation there is one Very God, and in manhood He remains what He was and is and will be; the one Lord Jesus Christ then must not be separated into man apart and into God apart, but recognising the difference of the natures and preserving them unconfounded with one another, we assert that there is one and the same Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1389
verses.text: Of the same after other commentaries:—  "There is plain perception of one thing dwelling in another, namely the divine nature in manhood, without undergoing commixture or any confusion, or any change into what it was not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1390
verses.text: For what is said to dwell in another does not become the same as that in which it dwells, but is rather regarded as one thing in another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1391
verses.text: But in the nature of the Word and of the manhood the difference points out to us a difference of natures alone, for of both is perceived one Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1392
verses.text: Therefore he says that the Word 'Tabernacled among us,' carefully observing the freedom from confusion, for he recognises one only begotten Son who was made flesh and became man".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1393
verses.text: Now, my dear sir, you have heard the great lights of the world; you have seen the beams of their teaching, and you have received exact instruction how, not only after the nativity, but after the passion which wrought salvation, and the resurrection, and the ascension, they have shewn the union of the Godhead and of the manhood to be without confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1394
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1395
verses.text: —I did not suppose that they distinguished the natures after the union, but I have found an infinite amount of distinction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1396
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1397
verses.text: —It is mad and rash against those noble champions of the faith so much as to wag your tongue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1398
verses.text: But I will adduce for you the words of Apollinarius, in order that you may know that he too asserts the union to be without confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1399
verses.text: Now hear his words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1400
verses.text: Testimony of Apollinarius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1401
verses.text: From his summary:—  "There is an union between what is of God and what is of the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1402
verses.text: On the one side is the adorable Creator Who is wisdom and power eternal; these are of the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1403
verses.text: On the other hand is the Son of Mary, born at the last time, worshipping God, advancing in wisdom, strengthened in power; these are of the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1404
verses.text: The suffering on behalf of sin and the curse came and will not pass away nor yet be changed into the incorporeal".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1405
verses.text: And again a little further on:—  "Men are consubstantial with the unreasoning animals as far as the unreasoning body is concerned; they are of another substance in so far forth as they are reasonable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1406
verses.text: Just so God who is consubstantial with men according to the flesh is of another substance in so far forth as He is Word and Man".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1407
verses.text: And in another place he says:—  "Of things which are mingled together the qualities are mixed and not destroyed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1408
verses.text: Thus it comes to pass that some are separate from the mixed parts as wine from water, nor yet is there mingling with a body, nor yet as of bodies with bodies, but the mingling preserves also the unmixed, so that, as each occasion may require, the energy of the Godhead either acts independently or in conjunction, as was the case when the Lord fasted, for the Godhead being in conjunction in proportion to its being above need, hunger was hindered, but when it no longer opposed to the craving its superiority to need, then hunger arose, to the undoing of the devil.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1409
verses.text: But if the mixture of the bodies suffered no change, how much more that of the Godhead?"  And in another place he says:—  "If the mixture with iron which makes the iron itself fire does not change its nature, so too the union of God with the body implies no change of the body, even though the body extend its divine energies to what is within its reach".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1410
verses.text: To this he immediately adds:—  "If a man has both soul and body, and these remain in unity, much more does the Christ, who has Godhead and body, keep both secure and unconfounded".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1411
verses.text: And again a little further on:—  "For human nature is partaker of the divine energy, as far as it is capable, but it is as distinct as the least from the greatest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1412
verses.text: Man is a servant of God, but God is not servant of man, nor even of Himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1413
verses.text: Man is a creature of God, but God is not a creature of man, nor even of Himself".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1414
verses.text: And again:—  "If any one takes in reference to Godhead and not in reference to flesh the passage the 'Son doeth what He seeth the Father do,' wherein He Who was made flesh is distinct from the Father Who was not made flesh, divides two divine energies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1415
verses.text: But there is no division.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1416
verses.text: So He does not speak in reference to Godhead".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1417
verses.text: Again he says:—  "As man is not an unreasoning being, on account of the contact of the reasoning and the unreasoning, just so the Saviour is not a creature on account of the contact of the creature with God uncreate".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1418
verses.text: To this he also adds:—  "The invisible which is united to a visible body and thereby is beheld, remains invisible, and it remains without composition because it is not circumscribed with the body, and the body, remaining in its own measure, accepts the union with God in accordance with its being quickened, nor is it that which is quickened which quickens".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1419
verses.text: And a little further on he says:—  "If the mixture with soul and body, although from the beginning they coalesce, does not make the soul visible on account of the body, nor change it into the other properties of the body, so as to allow of its being cut or lessened, how much rather God, who is not of the same nature as the body, is united to the body without undergoing change, if the body of man remains in its own nature, and this when it is animated by a soul, then in the case of Christ the commingling does not so change the body as that it is not a body".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1420
verses.text: And further on he says again:—  "He who confesses that soul and body are constituted one by the Scripture, is inconsistent with himself when he asserts that this union of the Word with the body is a change, such change being not even beheld in the case of a soul".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1421
verses.text: Listen to him again exclaiming clearly:—  "If they are impious who deny that the flesh of the Lord abides, much more are they who refuse wholly to accept His incarnation".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1422
verses.text: And in his little book about the Incarnation he has written:—  "The words 'Sit thou on my right hand' He speaks as to man, for they are not spoken to Him that sits ever on the throne of glory, as God the Word after His ascension from earth, but they are said to Him who hath now been exalted to the heavenly glory as man, as the Apostles say 'for David is not ascended into the heavens, but he saith himself the Lord said unto my Lord sit thou on my right hand.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1423
verses.text: ' The order is human, giving a beginning to the sitting; but it is a divine dignity to sit together with God 'to whom thousand thousands minister and before whom ten thousand times ten thousand stand.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1424
verses.text: '"  And again a little further on:—  "He does not put His enemies under Him as God but as man, but so that the God who is seen and man are the same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1425
verses.text: Paul too teaches us that the words 'until I make thy foes thy footstool' are spoken to men, describing the success as His own of course in accordance with His divinity 'According to the working whereby He is able even to subdue all things unto Himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1426
verses.text: ' Behold Godhead and manhood existing inseparably in One Person".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1427
verses.text: And again:—  "'Glorify me with thine own self with the glory which I had with thee before the world was.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1428
verses.text: ' The word 'glorify' He uses as man, but His having this glory before the ages He reveals as God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1429
verses.text: And again:—  "But let us not be humiliated as thinking the worship of the Son of God humiliation, even in His human likeness, but as though honouring some king appearing in poor raiment with his royal glory, and above all seeing that the very garb in which He is clad is glorified, as became the body of God and of the world's Saviour which is seed of eternal life, instrument of divine deeds, destroyer of all wickedness, slayer of death and prince of resurrection; for though it had its nature from man it derived its life from God, and its power and divine virtue from heaven".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1430
verses.text: And again:—  "Whence we worship the body as the Word; we partake of the body as of the spirit".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1431
verses.text: Now it has been plainly shewn you that the author who was first to introduce the mixture of the natures openly uses the argument of a distinction between them; thus he has called the body garb, creature and instrument; he even went so far as to call it slave, which none of us has ever ventured to do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1432
verses.text: He also says that it was deemed worthy of the seat on the right hand, and uses many other expressions which are rejected by your vain heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1433
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1434
verses.text: —But why then did he who was the first to introduce the mixture insert so great a distinction in his arguments?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1435
verses.text: —The power of truth forces even them that vehemently fight against her to agree with what she says, but, if you will, let us now begin a discussion about the impassibility of the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1436
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1437
verses.text: —You know that musicians are accustomed to give their strings rest, and they slacken them by turning the pegs; if then things altogether void of reason and soul stand in need of some recreation, we who partake of both shall do nothing absurd if we mete out our labour in proportion to our power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1438
verses.text: Let us then put it off till tomorrow.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1439
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 3:1440
verses.text: —The divine David charges us to give heed to the divine oracles by night and by day; but let it be as you say, and let us keep the investigation of the remainder of our subject till to-morrow.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1
verses.text: Dialogue III.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:2
verses.text: —The Impassible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:3
verses.text: Orthodoxus and Eranistes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:4
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:5
verses.text: —In our former discussions we have proved that God the Word is immutable, and became incarnate not by being changed into flesh, but by taking perfect human nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:6
verses.text: The divine Scripture, and the teachers of the churches and luminaries of the world have clearly taught us that, after the union, He remained as He was, unmixed, impassible, unchanged, uncircumscribed; and that He preserved unimpaired the nature which He had taken.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:7
verses.text: For the future then the subject before us is that of His passion, and it will be a very profitable one, for thence have been brought to us the waters of salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:8
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:9
verses.text: —I am also of opinion that this discourse will be beneficial.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:10
verses.text: I shall not however consent to our former method, but I propose myself to ask questions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:11
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:12
verses.text: —And I will answer, without making any objection to the change of method.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:13
verses.text: He who has truth on his side, not only when he questions but also when he is questioned, is supported by the might of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:14
verses.text: Ask then what you will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:15
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:16
verses.text: —Who, according to your view, suffered the passion?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:17
verses.text: —Our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:18
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:19
verses.text: —Then a man gave us our salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:20
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:21
verses.text: —No; for have we confessed that our Lord Jesus Christ was only man?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:22
verses.text: —Now define what you believe Christ to be.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:23
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:24
verses.text: —Incarnate Son of the living God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:25
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:26
verses.text: —And is the Son of God God?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:27
verses.text: —God, having the same substance as the God Who begat Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:28
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:29
verses.text: —Then God underwent the passion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:30
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:31
verses.text: —If He was nailed to the cross without a body, apply the passion to the Godhead; but if he was made man by taking flesh, why then do you exempt the passible from the passion and subject the impassible to it?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:32
verses.text: —But the reason why He took flesh was that the impassible might undergo the passion by means of the passible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:33
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:34
verses.text: —You say impassible and apply passion to Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:35
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:36
verses.text: —I said that He took flesh to suffer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:37
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:38
verses.text: —If He had had a nature capable of the Passion He would have suffered without flesh; so the flesh becomes superfluous.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:39
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:40
verses.text: —The divine nature is immortal, and the nature of the flesh mortal, so the immortal was united with the mortal, that through it He might taste of death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:41
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:42
verses.text: —That which is by nature immortal does not undergo death, even when conjoined with the mortal; this is easy to see.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:43
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:44
verses.text: —Prove it; and remove the difficulty.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:45
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:46
verses.text: —Do you assert that the human soul was immortal, or mortal?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:47
verses.text: —Immortal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:48
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:49
verses.text: —And is the body mortal or immortal?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:50
verses.text: —Indubitably mortal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:51
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:52
verses.text: —And do we say that man consists of these natures?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:53
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:54
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:55
verses.text: —So the immortal is conjoined with the mortal?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:56
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:57
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:58
verses.text: —But when the connexion or union is at an end, the mortal submits to the law of death, while the soul remains immortal though sin has introduced death, or do you not hold death to be a penalty?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:59
verses.text: —So divine Scripture teaches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:60
verses.text: For we learn that when God forbade Adam to partake of the tree of knowledge He added "on the day that ye eat thereof ye shall surely die".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:61
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:62
verses.text: —Then death is the punishment of them that have sinned?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:63
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:64
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:65
verses.text: —Why then, when soul and body have both sinned together, does the body alone undergo the punishment of death?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:66
verses.text: —It was the body that cast its evil eye upon the tree, and stretched forth its hands, and plucked the forbidden fruit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:67
verses.text: It was the mouth that bit it with the teeth, and ground it small, and then the gullet committed it to the belly, and the belly digested it, and delivered it to the liver; and the liver turned what it had received into blood and passed it on to the hollow vein and the vein to the adjacent parts and they through the rest, and so the theft of the forbidden food pervaded the whole body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:68
verses.text: Very properly then the body alone underwent the punishment of sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:69
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:70
verses.text: —You have given us a physiological disquisition on the nature of food, on all the parts that it goes through and on the modifications to which it is subject before it is assimilated with the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:71
verses.text: But there is one point that you have refused to observe, and that is that the body goes through none of these processes which you have mentioned without the soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:72
verses.text: When bereft of the soul which is its yoke mate the body lies breathless, voiceless, motionless; the eye sees neither wrong nor aright; no sound of voices reaches the ears, the hands cannot stir; the feet cannot walk; the body is like an instrument without music.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:73
verses.text: How then can you say that only the body sinned when the body without the soul cannot even take a breath?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:74
verses.text: —The body does indeed receive life from the soul, and it furnishes the soul with the penal possession of sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:75
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:76
verses.text: —How, and in what manner?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:77
verses.text: —Through the eyes it makes it see amiss; through the ears it makes it hear unprofitable sounds; and through the tongue utter injurious words, and through all the other parts act ill.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:78
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:79
verses.text: —Then I suppose we may say Blessed are the deaf; blessed are they that have lost their sight and have been deprived of their other faculties, for the souls of men so incapacitated have neither part nor lot in the wickedness of the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:80
verses.text: And why, O most sagacious sir, have you mentioned those functions of the body which are culpable, and said nothing about the laudable? It is possible to look with eyes of love and of kindliness; it is possible to wipe away a tear of compunction, to hear oracles of God, to bend the ear to the poor, to praise the Creator with the tongue, to give good lessons to our neighbour, to move the hand in mercy, and in a word to use the parts of the body for complete acquisition of goodness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:81
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:82
verses.text: —This is all true.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:83
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:84
verses.text: —Therefore the observance and transgression of law is common to both soul and body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:85
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:86
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:87
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:88
verses.text: —It seems to me that the soul takes the leading part in both, since it uses reasoning before the body acts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:89
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:90
verses.text: —In what sense do you say this?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:91
verses.text: —First of all the mind makes, as it were, a sketch of virtue or of vice, and then gives to one or the other form with appropriate material and colour, using for its instruments the parts of the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:92
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:93
verses.text: —So it seems.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:94
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:95
verses.text: —If then the soul sins with the body; nay rather takes the lead in the sin, for to it is entrusted the bridling and direction of the animal part, why, as it shares the sin, does it not also share the punishment?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:96
verses.text: —But how were it possible for the immortal soul to share death?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:97
verses.text: —Yet it were just that after sharing the transgression, it should share the chastisement.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:98
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:99
verses.text: —Yes, just.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:100
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:101
verses.text: —But it did not do so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:102
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:103
verses.text: —Certainly not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:104
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:105
verses.text: —At least in the life to come it will be sent with the body to Gehenna.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:106
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:107
verses.text: —So He said "Fear not them which kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul; but rather fear him which is able to destroy both soul and body in hell".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:108
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:109
verses.text: —Therefore in this life it escapes death, as being immortal; in the life to come, it will be punished, not by undergoing death, but by suffering chastisement in life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:110
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:111
verses.text: —That is what the divine Scripture says.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:112
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:113
verses.text: —It is then impossible for the immortal nature to undergo death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:114
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:115
verses.text: —So it appears.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:116
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:117
verses.text: —How then do you say, God the Word tasted death? For if that which was created immortal is seen to be incapable of becoming mortal, how is it possible for him that is without creation and eternally immortal, Creator of mortal and immortal natures alike, to partake of death?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:118
verses.text: —We too know that His nature is immortal, but we say that He shared death in the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:119
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:120
verses.text: —But we have plainly shewn that it is in no wise possible for that which is by nature immortal to share death, for even the soul created together with, and conjoined with, the body and sharing in its sin, does not share death with it, on account of the immortality of its nature alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:121
verses.text: But let us look at this same position from another point of view.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:122
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:123
verses.text: —There is every reason why we should leave no means untried to arrive at the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:124
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:125
verses.text: —Let us then examine the matter thus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:126
verses.text: Do we assert that of virtue and vice some are teachers and some are followers?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:127
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:128
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:129
verses.text: —And do we say that the teacher of virtue deserves greater recompense?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:130
verses.text: —Certainly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:131
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:132
verses.text: —And similarly the teacher of vice deserves twofold and threefold punishment?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:133
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:134
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:135
verses.text: —And what part shall we assign to the devil, that of teacher or disciple?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:136
verses.text: —Teacher of teachers, for he himself is father and teacher of all iniquity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:137
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:138
verses.text: —And who of men became his first disciples?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:139
verses.text: —Adam and Eve.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:140
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:141
verses.text: —And who received the sentence of death?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:142
verses.text: —Adam and all his race.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:143
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:144
verses.text: —Then the disciples were punished for the bad lessons they had learnt, but the teacher, whom we have just declared to deserve two-fold and three-fold chastisement, got off the punishment?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:145
verses.text: —Apparently.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:146
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:147
verses.text: —And though this so came about we both acknowledge and declare that the Judge is just.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:148
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:149
verses.text: —Certainly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:150
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:151
verses.text: —But, being just, why did He not exact an account from him of his evil teaching?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:152
verses.text: —He prepared for him the unquenchable flame of Gehenna, for, He says, "Depart from me ye cursed into everlasting fire prepared for the devil and his angels".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:153
verses.text: And the reason why he did not here share death with his disciples is because he has an immortal nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:154
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:155
verses.text: —Then even the greatest transgressors cannot incur death if they have an immortal nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:156
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:157
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:158
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:159
verses.text: —If then even the very inventor and teacher of iniquity did not incur death on account of the immortality of his nature, do you not shudder at the thought of saying that the fount of immortality and righteousness shared death?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:160
verses.text: —Had we said that he underwent the passion involuntarily, there would have been some just ground for the accusation which you bring against us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:161
verses.text: But if the passion which is preached by us was spontaneous and the death voluntary, it becomes you, instead of accusing us, to praise the immensity of His love to man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:162
verses.text: For He suffered because He willed to suffer, and shared death because He wished it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:163
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:164
verses.text: —You seem to me to be quite ignorant of the divine nature, for the Lord God wishes nothing inconsistent with His nature, and is able to do all that He wishes, and what He wishes is appropriate and agreeable to His own nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:165
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:166
verses.text: —We have learnt that all things are possible with God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:167
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:168
verses.text: —In expressing yourself thus indefinitely you include even what belongs to the Devil, for to say absolutely all things is to name together not only good, but its opposite.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:169
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:170
verses.text: —But did not the noble Job speak absolutely when he said "I know that thou canst do all things and with thee nothing is impossible"?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:171
verses.text: —If you read what the just man said before, you will see the meaning of the one passage from the other, for he says "Remember, I beseech thee, that thou hast made me as the clay and wilt thou bring me into dust again? Hast thou not poured me out as milk and curdled me like cheese? Thou hast clothed me with skin and flesh and hast fenced me with bones and sinews, thou hast granted me life and favour".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:172
verses.text: And then he adds:—  "Having this in myself I know that thou canst do all things and that with thee nothing is impossible".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:173
verses.text: Is it not therefore all that belongs to these things that he alleges to belong to the incorruptible nature, to the God of the universe?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:174
verses.text: —Nothing is impossible to Almighty God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:175
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:176
verses.text: —Then according to your definition sin is possible to Almighty God?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:177
verses.text: —By no means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:178
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:179
verses.text: —Wherefore?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:180
verses.text: —Because He does not wish it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:181
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:182
verses.text: —Wherefore does He not wish it?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:183
verses.text: —Because sin is foreign to His nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:184
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:185
verses.text: —Then there are many things which He cannot do, for there are many kinds of transgression.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:186
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:187
verses.text: —Nothing of this kind can be wished or done by God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:188
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:189
verses.text: —Nor can those things which are contrary to the divine nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:190
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:191
verses.text: —What are they?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:192
verses.text: —As, for instance, we have learnt that God is intelligent and true Light.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:193
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:194
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:195
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:196
verses.text: —And we could not call Him darkness or say that He wished to become, or could become, darkness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:197
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:198
verses.text: —By no means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:199
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:200
verses.text: —Again, the Divine Scripture calls His nature invisible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:201
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:202
verses.text: —It does.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:203
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:204
verses.text: —And we could never say that It is capable of being made visible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:205
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:206
verses.text: —No, surely.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:207
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:208
verses.text: —Nor comprehensible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:209
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:210
verses.text: —No; for He is not so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:211
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:212
verses.text: —No; for He is incomprehensible, and altogether unapproachable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:213
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:214
verses.text: —You are right.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:215
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:216
verses.text: —And He that is could never become non-existent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:217
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:218
verses.text: —Away with the thought!  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:219
verses.text: —Nor yet could the Father become Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:220
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:221
verses.text: —Impossible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:222
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:223
verses.text: —Nor yet could the unbegotten become begotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:224
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:225
verses.text: —How could He.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:226
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:227
verses.text: —And the Father could never become Son?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:228
verses.text: —By no means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:229
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:230
verses.text: —Nor could the Holy Ghost ever become Son or Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:231
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:232
verses.text: —All this is impossible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:233
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:234
verses.text: —And we shall find many other things of the same kind, which are similarly impossible, for the Eternal will not become of time, nor the Uncreate created and made, nor the infinite finite, and the like.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:235
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:236
verses.text: —None of these is possible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:237
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:238
verses.text: —So we have found many things which are impossible to Almighty God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:239
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:240
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:241
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:242
verses.text: —But not to be able in any of these respects is proof not of weakness, but of infinite power, and to be able would certainly be proof not of power but of impotence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:243
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:244
verses.text: —How do you say this?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:245
verses.text: —Because each one of these proclaims the unchangeable and invariable character of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:246
verses.text: For the impossibility of good becoming evil signifies the immensity of the goodness; and that He that is just should never become unjust, nor He that is true a liar, exhibits the stability and the strength that there is in truth and righteousness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:247
verses.text: Thus the true light could never become darkness; He that is could never become nonexistent, for the existence is perpetual and the light is naturally invariable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:248
verses.text: And so, after examining all other examples, you will find that the not being able is declaratory of the highest power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:249
verses.text: That things of this kind are impossible in the case of God, the divine Apostle also both perceived and laid down, for in his Epistle to the Hebrews he says, "that by two immutable things, in which it was impossible for God to lie we might have a strong consolation".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:250
verses.text: He shews that this incapacity is not weakness, but very power, for he asserts Him to be so true that it is impossible for there to be even a lie in Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:251
verses.text: So the power of truth is signified through its want of power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:252
verses.text: And writing to the blessed Timothy, the Apostle adds "It is a faithful saying, for if we be dead with Him we shall also live with Him, if we suffer we shall also reign with Him; if we deny Him He will also deny us, if we believe not yet He abideth faithful, He cannot deny Himself".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:253
verses.text: Again then the phrase "He cannot" is indicative of infinite power, for even though all men deny Him He says God is Himself, and cannot exist otherwise than in His own nature, for His being is indestructible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:254
verses.text: This is what is meant by the words "He cannot deny Himself".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:255
verses.text: Therefore the impossibility of change for the worse proves infinity of power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:256
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:257
verses.text: —This is quite true and in harmony with the divine words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:258
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:259
verses.text: —Granted then that with God many things are impossible,—everything, that is, which is repugnant to the divine nature,—how comes it that while you omit all the other qualities which belong to the divine nature, goodness, righteousness, truth, invisibility, incomprehensibility, infinity, and eternity, and the rest of the attributes which we assert to be proper to God, you maintain that His immortality and impassibility alone are subject to change, and in them concede the possibility of variation and give to God a capacity indicative of weakness?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:260
verses.text: —We have learnt this from the divine Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:261
verses.text: The divine John exclaims "God so loved the world that He gave His only begotten Son," and the divine Paul, "For if when we were enemies we were reconciled to God by the death of His Son, much more being reconciled we shall be saved by His life".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:262
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:263
verses.text: —Of course all this is true, for these are divine oracles, but remember what we have often confessed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:264
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:265
verses.text: —What?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:266
verses.text: —We have confessed that God the Word the Son of God did not appear without a body, but assumed perfect human nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:267
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:268
verses.text: —Yes; this we have confessed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:269
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:270
verses.text: —And He was called Son of Man because He took a body and human soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:271
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:272
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:273
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:274
verses.text: —Therefore the Lord Jesus Christ is verily our God; for of these two natures the one was His from everlasting and the other He assumed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:275
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:276
verses.text: —Indubitably.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:277
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:278
verses.text: —While, then, as man He underwent the passion, as God He remained incapable of suffering.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:279
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:280
verses.text: —How then does the divine Scripture say that the Son of God suffered?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:281
verses.text: —Because the body which suffered was His body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:282
verses.text: But let us look at the matter thus; when we hear the divine Scripture saying "And it came to pass when Isaac was old his eyes were dim so that he could not see," whither is our mind carried and on what does it rest, on Isaac's soul or on his body?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:283
verses.text: —Of course on his body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:284
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:285
verses.text: —Do we then conjecture that his soul also shared in the affection of blindness?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:286
verses.text: —Certainly not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:287
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:288
verses.text: —We assert that only his body was deprived of the sense of sight?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:289
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:290
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:291
verses.text: —And again when we hear Amaziah saying to the prophet Amos, "Oh thou seer go flee away into the land of Judah," and Saul enquiring: "Tell me I pray thee where the seer's house is," we understand nothing bodily.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:292
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:293
verses.text: —Certainly not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:294
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:295
verses.text: —And yet the words used are significant of the health of the organ of sight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:296
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:297
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:298
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:299
verses.text: —Yet we know that the power of the Spirit when given to purer souls inspires prophetic grace and causes them to see even hidden things, and, in consequence of their thus seeing, they are called seers and beholders.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:300
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:301
verses.text: —What you say is true.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:302
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:303
verses.text: —And let us consider this too.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:304
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:305
verses.text: —What?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:306
verses.text: —When we hear the story of the divine evangelists narrating how they brought to God a man sick of the palsy, laid upon a bed, do we say that this was paralysis of the parts of the soul or of the body?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:307
verses.text: —Plainly of the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:308
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:309
verses.text: —And when while reading the Epistle to the Hebrews we light upon the passage where the Apostle says "Wherefore lift up the hands which hang down and the feeble knees and make straight paths for your feet lest that which is lame be turned out of the way, but let it rather be healed," do we say that the divine Apostle said these things about the parts of the body?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:310
verses.text: —No.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:311
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:312
verses.text: —Shall we say that he was for removing the feebleness and infirmity of the soul and stimulating the disciples to manliness?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:313
verses.text: —Obviously.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:314
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:315
verses.text: —But we do not find these things distinguished in the divine Scripture, for in describing the blindness of Isaac he made no reference to the body, but spoke of Isaac as absolutely blind, nor in describing the prophets as seers and beholders did he say that their souls saw and beheld what was hidden, but mentioned the persons themselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:316
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:317
verses.text: —Yes; this is so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:318
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:319
verses.text: —And he did not point out that the body of the paralytic was palsied, but called the man a paralytic.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:320
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:321
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:322
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:323
verses.text: —And even the divine Apostle made no special mention of the souls, though it was these that he purposed to strengthen and to rouse.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:324
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:325
verses.text: —No; he did not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:326
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:327
verses.text: —But when we examine the meaning of the words, we understand which belongs to the soul and which to the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:328
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:329
verses.text: —And very naturally; for God made us reasonable beings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:330
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:331
verses.text: —Then let us make use of this reasoning faculty in the case of our Maker and Saviour, and let us recognise what belongs to His Godhead and what to His manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:332
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:333
verses.text: —But by doing this we shall destroy the supreme union.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:334
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:335
verses.text: —In the case of Isaac, of the prophets, of the man sick of the palsy, and of the rest, we did so without destroying the natural union of the soul and of the body; we did not even separate the souls from their proper bodies, but by reason alone distinguished what belonged to the soul and what to the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:336
verses.text: Is it not then monstrous that while we take this course in the case of souls and bodies, we should refuse to do so in the case of our Saviour, and confound natures which differ not in the same proportion as soul from body, but in as vast a degree as the temporal from the eternal and the Creator from the created?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:337
verses.text: —The divine Scripture says that the Son of God underwent the passion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:338
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:339
verses.text: —We deny that it was suffered by any other, but none the less, taught by the divine Scripture, we know that the nature of the Godhead is impassible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:340
verses.text: We are told of impassibility and of passion, of manhood and of Godhead, and we therefore attribute the passion to the passible body, and confess that no passion was undergone by the nature that was impassible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:341
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:342
verses.text: —Then a body won our salvation for us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:343
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:344
