verses.text: —Yes; but not a mere man's body, but that of our Lord Jesus Christ, the only begotten Son of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:345
verses.text: If you regard this body as insignificant and of small account, how can you hold its type to be an object of worship and a means of salvation? and how can the archetype be contemptible and insignificant of that of which the type is adorable and honourable?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:346
verses.text: —I do not look on the body as of small account, but I object to dividing it from the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:347
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:348
verses.text: —We, my good sir, do not divide the union but we regard the peculiar properties of the natures, and I am sure that in a moment you will take the same view.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:349
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:350
verses.text: —You talk like a prophet.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:351
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:352
verses.text: —No; not like a prophet, but as knowing the power of truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:353
verses.text: But now answer me this.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:354
verses.text: When you hear the Lord saying "I and my Father are one," and "He that hath seen me hath seen the Father," do you say that this refers to the flesh or to the Godhead?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:355
verses.text: —How can the flesh and the Father possibly be of one substance?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:356
verses.text: —Then these passages indicate the Godhead?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:357
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:358
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:359
verses.text: —And so with the text, "In the beginning was the Word and the Word was God," and the like.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:360
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:361
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:362
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:363
verses.text: —Again when the divine Scripture says, "Jesus therefore being wearied with his journey sat thus on the well," of what is the weariness to be understood, of the Godhead or of the body?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:364
verses.text: —I cannot bear to divide what is united.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:365
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:366
verses.text: —Then it seems you attribute the weariness to the divine nature?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:367
verses.text: —I think so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:368
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:369
verses.text: —But then you directly contradict the exclamation of the prophet "He fainteth not neither is weary; there is no searching of His understanding.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:370
verses.text: He giveth power to the faint and to them that have no might he increaseth strength".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:371
verses.text: And a little further on "But they that wait upon the Lord shall renew their strength, they shall mount up with wings as eagles, they shall run and not be weary and they shall walk and not faint".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:372
verses.text: Now how can He who bestows upon others the boon of freedom from weariness and want, possibly be himself subject to hunger and thirst?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:373
verses.text: —I have said over and over again that God is impassible, and free from all want, but after the incarnation He became capable of suffering.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:374
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:375
verses.text: —But did He do this by admitting the sufferings in His Godhead, or by permitting the passible nature to undergo its natural sufferings and by suffering proclaim that what was seen was no unreality, but was really assumed of human nature? But now let us look at the matter thus: we say that the divine nature was uncircumscribed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:376
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:377
verses.text: —Aye.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:378
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:379
verses.text: —And uncircumscribed nature is circumscribed by none.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:380
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:381
verses.text: —Of course not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:382
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:383
verses.text: —It therefore needs no transition for it is everywhere.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:384
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:385
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:386
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:387
verses.text: —And that which needs no transition needs not to travel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:388
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:389
verses.text: —That is clear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:390
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:391
verses.text: —And that which does not travel does not grow weary.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:392
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:393
verses.text: —No.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:394
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:395
verses.text: —It follows then that the divine nature, which is uncircumscribed, and needs not to travel, was not weary.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:396
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:397
verses.text: —But the divine Scripture says that Jesus was weary, and Jesus is God; "And our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom are all things".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:398
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:399
verses.text: —But the exact expression of the divine Scripture is that Jesus "was wearied" not "is wearied".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:400
verses.text: We must consider how one and the other can be applied to the same person.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:401
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:402
verses.text: —Well; try to point this out, for you are always for forcing on us the distinction of terms.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:403
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:404
verses.text: —I think that even a barbarian might easily make this distinction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:405
verses.text: The union of unlike natures being conceded, the person of Christ on account of the union receives both; to each nature its own properties are attributed; to the uncircumscribed immunity from weariness, to that which is capable of transition and travel weariness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:406
verses.text: For travelling is the function of the feet; of the muscles to be strained by over exercise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:407
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:408
verses.text: —There is no controversy about these being bodily affections.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:409
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:410
verses.text: —Well then; the prediction which I made, and you scoffed at, has come true; for look; you have shewn us what belongs to manhood, and what belongs to Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:411
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:412
verses.text: —But I have not divided one son into two.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:413
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:414
verses.text: —Nor do we, my friend; but giving heed to the difference of the natures, we consider what befits godhead, and what is proper to a body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:415
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:416
verses.text: —This distinction is not the teaching of the divine Scripture; it says that the Son of God died.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:417
verses.text: So the Apostle;—"For if when we were enemies we were reconciled to God by the death of His Son".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:418
verses.text: And he says that the Lord was raised from the dead for "God" he says "raised the Lord from the dead".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:419
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:420
verses.text: —And when the divine Scripture says "And devout men carried Stephen to his burial and made great lamentation over him" would any one say that his soul was committed to the grave as well as his body?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:421
verses.text: —Of course not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:422
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:423
verses.text: —And when you hear the Patriarch Jacob saying "Bury me with my Fathers," do you suppose this refers to the body or to the soul?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:424
verses.text: —To the body; without question.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:425
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:426
verses.text: —Now read what follows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:427
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:428
verses.text: —"There they buried Abraham and Sarah his wife.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:429
verses.text: There they buried Isaac and Rebekah his wife and there I buried Leah".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:430
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:431
verses.text: —Now, in the passages which you have just read, the divine Scripture makes no mention of the body, but as far as the words used go, signifies soul as well as body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:432
verses.text: We however make the proper distinction and say that the souls of the patriarchs were immortal, and that only their bodies were buried in the double cave.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:433
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:434
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:435
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:436
verses.text: —And when we read in the Acts how Herod slew James the brother of John with a sword, we are not likely to hold that his soul died.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:437
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:438
verses.text: —No; how could we? We remember the Lord's warning "Fear not them which kill the body but are not able to kill the soul".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:439
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:440
verses.text: —But does it not seem to you impious and monstrous in the case of mere men to avoid the invariable connexion of soul and body, and in the case of scriptural references to death and burial, to distinguish in thought the soul from the body and connect them only with the body, while in trust in the teaching of the Lord you hold the soul to be immortal, and then when you hear of the passion of the Son of God to follow quite a different course? Are you justified in making no mention of the body to which the passion belongs, and in representing the divine nature which is impassible, immutable and immortal as mortal and passible? While all the while you know that if the nature of God the Word is capable of suffering, the assumption of the body was superfluous.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:441
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:442
verses.text: —We have learnt from the Divine Scriptures that the Son of God suffered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:443
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:444
verses.text: —But the divine apostle interprets the Passion, and shews what nature suffered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:445
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:446
verses.text: —Show me this at once and clear the matter up.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:447
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:448
verses.text: —Are you not acquainted with the passage in the Epistle to the Hebrews in which the divine Paul says "For which cause He is not ashamed to call them brethren saying 'I will declare thy name unto my brethren, in the midst of the Church will I sing praise unto Thee.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:449
verses.text: ' And again, 'Behold I and the children which God hath given me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:450
verses.text: '"  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:451
verses.text: —Yes, I know this, but this does not give us what you promised.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:452
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:453
verses.text: —Yes: even these suggest what I promised to shew.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:454
verses.text: The word brotherhood signifies kinship, and the kinship is due to the assumption of the nature, and the assumption openly proclaims the impassibility of the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:455
verses.text: But to understand this the more plainly read what follows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:456
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:457
verses.text: —"Forasmuch then as the children are partakers of flesh and blood, He also Himself likewise took part of the same that through death He might destroy him that hath the power of death…and deliver them who through fear of death were all their life subject to bondage".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:458
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:459
verses.text: —This, I think, needs no explanation; it teaches clearly the mystery of the oeconomy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:460
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:461
verses.text: —I see nothing here of what you promised to prove.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:462
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:463
verses.text: —Yet the divine Apostle teaches plainly that the Creator, pitying this nature not only seized cruelly by death, but throughout all life made death's slave, effected the resurrection through a body for our bodies, and, by means of a mortal body, undid the dominion of death; for since His own nature was immortal He righteously wished to stay the sovereignty of death by taking the first fruits of them that were subject to death, and while He kept these first fruits (i-e: the body) blameless and free from sin, on the one hand He gave death license to lay hands on it and so satisfy its insatiability, while on the other, for the sake of the wrong done to this body, he put a stop to the unrighteous sovereignty usurped over all the rest of men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:464
verses.text: These firstfruits unrighteously engulfed He raised again and will make the race to follow them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:465
verses.text: Set this explanation side by side with the words of the Apostle, and you will understand the impassibility of the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:466
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:467
verses.text: —In what has been read there is no proof of the divine impassibility.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:468
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:469
verses.text: —Nay: does not the statement of the divine Apostle, that the reason of His making the children partakers of the flesh and blood was that through death He might destroy him that hath the power of death, distinctly signify the impassibility of the Godhead, and the passibility of the flesh, and that because the divine nature could not suffer He assumed the nature that could and through it destroyed the power of the devil?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:470
verses.text: —How did He destroy the power of the devil and the dominion of death through the flesh?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:471
verses.text: —What arms did the devil use at the beginning when he enslaved the nature of men?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:472
verses.text: —The means by which he took captive him who had been constituted citizen of Paradise, was sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:473
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:474
verses.text: —And what punishment did God assign for the transgression of the commandment?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:475
verses.text: —Death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:476
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:477
verses.text: —Then sin is the mother of death, and the devil its father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:478
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:479
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:480
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:481
verses.text: —War then was waged against human nature by sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:482
verses.text: Sin seduced them that obeyed it to slavery, brought them to its vile father, and delivered them to its very bitter offspring.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:483
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:484
verses.text: —That is plain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:485
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:486
verses.text: —So with reason the Creator, with the intention of destroying either power, assumed the nature against which war was being waged, and, by keeping it clear of all sin, both set it free from the sovereignty of the devil, and, by its means, destroyed the devil's dominion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:487
verses.text: For since death is the punishment of sinners, and death unrighteously and against the divine law seized the sinless body of the Lord, He first raised up that which was unlawfully detained, and then promised release to them that were with justice imprisoned.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:488
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:489
verses.text: —But how do you think it just that the resurrection of Him who was unlawfully detained should be shared by the bodies which had been righteously delivered to death?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:490
verses.text: —And how do you think it just that, when it was Adam who transgressed the commandment, his race should follow their forefather?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:491
verses.text: —Although the race had not participated in the famous transgression, yet it committed other sins, and for this cause incurred death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:492
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:493
verses.text: —Yet not sinners only but just men, patriarchs, prophets, apostles, and men who have shone bright in many kinds of virtue have come into death's meshes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:494
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:495
verses.text: —Yes; for how could a family sprung of mortal parents remain immortal? Adam after the transgression and the divine sentence, and after coming under the power of death, knew his wife, and was called father; having himself become mortal he was made father of mortals; reasonably then all who have received mortal nature follow their forefather.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:496
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:497
verses.text: —You have shewn very well the reason of our being partakers of death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:498
verses.text: The same however must be granted about the resurrection, for the remedy must be meet for the disease.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:499
verses.text: When the head of the race was doomed, all the race was doomed with him, and so when the Saviour destroyed the curse, human nature won freedom; and just as they that shared Adam's nature followed him in his going down into Hades, so all the nature of men will share in newness of life with the Lord Christ in His resurrection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:500
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:501
verses.text: —The decrees of the Church must be given not only declaratorily but demonstratively.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:502
verses.text: Tell me then how these doctrines are taught in the divine Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:503
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:504
verses.text: —Listen to the Apostle writing to the Romans, and through them teaching all mankind: "For if through the offence of one many be dead, much more the grace of God, and the gift by grace, which is by one man, Jesus Christ, hath abounded unto many.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:505
verses.text: And not as it was by one that sinned, so is the gift; for the judgment was by one to condemnation, but the free gift is of many offences unto justification.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:506
verses.text: For if by one man's offence death reigned by one; much more they which receive abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness shall reign in life by one, Jesus Christ" and again: "Therefore as by the offence of one judgment came upon all men to condemnation; even so by the righteousness of one the free gift came upon all men unto justification of life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:507
verses.text: For as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners so by the obedience of one shall many be made righteous".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:508
verses.text: And when introducing to the Corinthians his argument about the resurrection he shortly reveals to them the mystery of the oeconomy, and says: "But now is Christ risen from the dead and become the first fruits of them which slept.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:509
verses.text: For since by man came death by man came also the resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:510
verses.text: For as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:511
verses.text: So I have brought you proofs from the divine oracles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:512
verses.text: Now look at what belongs to Adam compared with what belongs to Christ, the disease with the remedy, the wound with the salve, the sin with the wealth of righteousness, the ban with the blessing, the doom with the delivery, the transgression with the observance, the death with the life, hell with the kingdom, Adam with Christ, the man with the Man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:513
verses.text: And yet the Lord Christ is not only man but eternal God, but the divine Apostle names Him from the nature which He assumed, because it is in this nature that he compares Him with Adam.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:514
verses.text: The justification, the struggle, the victory, the death, the resurrection are all of this human nature; it is this nature which we share with Him; in this nature they who have exercised themselves beforehand in the citizenship of the kingdom shall reign with Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:515
verses.text: Of this nature I spoke, not dividing the Godhead, but referring to what is proper to the manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:516
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:517
verses.text: —You have gone through long discussions on this point, and have strengthened your argument by scriptural testimony, but if the passion was really of the flesh, how is it that when he praises the divine love to men, the Apostle exclaims, "He that spared not His own Son but delivered Him up for us all," what son does he say was delivered up?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:518
verses.text: —Watch well your words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:519
verses.text: There is one Son of God, wherefore He is called only begotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:520
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:521
verses.text: —If then there is one Son of God, the divine Apostle called him own Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:522
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:523
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:524
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:525
verses.text: —Then he says that He was delivered up.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:526
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:527
verses.text: —Yes, but not without a body, as we have agreed again and again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:528
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:529
verses.text: —It has been agreed again and again that He took body and soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:530
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:531
verses.text: —Therefore the Apostle spoke of what relates to the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:532
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:533
verses.text: —The divide Apostle says distinctly "Who spared not his own Son".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:534
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:535
verses.text: —When then you hear God saying to Abraham "Because thou hast not withheld thy son thy only son," do you allege that Isaac was slain?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:536
verses.text: —Of course not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:537
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:538
verses.text: —And yet God said "Thou hast not withheld," and the God of all is true.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:539
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:540
verses.text: —The expression "thou hast not withheld" refers to the readiness of Abraham, for he was ready to sacrifice the lad, but God prevented it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:541
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:542
verses.text: —Well; in the story of Abraham you were not content with the letter, but unfolded it and made the meaning clear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:543
verses.text: In precisely the same manner examine the meaning of the words of the Apostle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:544
verses.text: You will then see that it was by no means the divine nature which was not withheld, but the flesh nailed to the Cross.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:545
verses.text: And it is easy to perceive the truth even in the type.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:546
verses.text: Do you regard Abraham's sacrifice as a type of the oblation offered on behalf of the world?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:547
verses.text: —Not at all, nor yet can I make words spoken rhetorically in the churches a rule of faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:548
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:549
verses.text: —You ought by all means to follow teachers of the Church, but, since you improperly oppose yourself to these, hear the Saviour Himself when addressing the Jews; "Your Father Abraham rejoiced to see my day and he saw it and was glad".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:550
verses.text: Note that the Lord calls His passion "a day".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:551
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:552
verses.text: —I accept the Lord's testimony and do not doubt the type.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:553
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:554
verses.text: —Now compare the type with the reality and you will see the impassibility of the Godhead even in the type.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:555
verses.text: Both in the former and in the latter there is a Father; both in the former and the latter a well beloved Son, each bearing the material for the sacrifice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:556
verses.text: The one bore the wood, the other the cross upon his shoulders.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:557
verses.text: It is said that the top of the hill was dignified by the sacrifice of both.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:558
verses.text: There is a correspondence moreover between the number of days and nights and the resurrection which followed, for after Isaac had been slain by his father's willing heart, on the third day after the bountiful God had ordered the deed to be done, he rose to new life at the voice of Him who loves mankind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:559
verses.text: A lamb was seen caught in a thicket, furnishing an image of the cross, and slain instead of the lad.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:560
verses.text: Now if this is a type of the reality, and in the type the only begotten Son did not undergo sacrifice, but a lamb was substituted and laid upon the altar and completed the mystery of the oblation, why then in the reality do you hesitate to assign the passion to the flesh, and to proclaim the impassibility of the Godhead?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:561
verses.text: —In your observations upon this type you represent Isaac as living again at the divine command.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:562
verses.text: There is nothing therefore unseemly if, fitting the reality to the type, we declare that God the Word suffered and came to life again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:563
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:564
verses.text: —I have said again and again that it is quite impossible for the type to match the archetypal reality in every respect, and this may also be easily understood in the present instance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:565
verses.text: Isaac and the lamb, as touching the difference of their natures, suit the image, but as touching the separation of their divided persons they do so no longer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:566
verses.text: We preach so close an union of Godhead and of manhood as to understand one person undivided, and to acknowledge the same to be both God and man, visible and invisible, circumscribed and uncircumscribed, and we apply to one of the persons all the attributes which are indicative alike of Godhead and of manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:567
verses.text: Now since the lamb, an unreasoning being, and not gifted with the divine image, could not possibly prefigure the restoration to life, the two divide between them the type of the mystery of the oeconomy, and while one furnishes the image of death, the other supplies that of the resurrection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:568
verses.text: We find precisely the same thing in the Mosaic sacrifices, for in them too may be seen a type outlined in anticipation of the passion of salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:569
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:570
verses.text: —What Mosaic sacrifice foreshadows the reality?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:571
verses.text: —All the Old Testament, so to say, is a type of the New.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:572
verses.text: It is for this reason that the divine Apostle plainly says—"the Law having a shadow of good things to come" and again "now all these things happened unto them for ensamples".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:573
verses.text: The image of the archetype is very distinctly exhibited by the lamb slain in Egypt, and by the red heifer burned without the camp, and moreover referred to by the Apostle in the Epistle to the Hebrews, where he writes "Wherefore Jesus also that he might sanctify the people with his own blood, suffered without the gate".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:574
verses.text: But of this no more for the present.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:575
verses.text: I will however mention the sacrifice in which two goats were offered, the one being slain, and the other let go.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:576
verses.text: In these two goats there is an anticipative image of the two natures of the Saviour;—in the one let go, of the impassible Godhead, in the one slain, of the passible manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:577
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:578
verses.text: —Do you not think it irreverent to liken the Lord to goats?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:579
verses.text: —Which do you think is a fitter object of avoidance and hate, a serpent or a goat?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:580
verses.text: —A serpent is plainly hateful, for it injures those who come within its reach, and often hurts people who do it no harm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:581
verses.text: A goat on the other hand comes, according to the Law, in the list of animals that are clean and may be eaten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:582
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:583
verses.text: —Now hear the Lord likening the passion of salvation to the brazen serpent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:584
verses.text: He says: "As Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness even so must the Son of man be lifted up: that whosoever believeth in Him should not perish, but have eternal life".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:585
verses.text: If a brazen serpent was a type of the crucified Saviour, of what impropriety are we guilty in comparing the passion of salvation with the sacrifice of the goats?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:586
verses.text: —Because John called the Lord "a lamb," and Isaiah called Him "lamb" and "sheep".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:587
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:588
verses.text: —But the blessed Paul calls Him "sin" and "curse".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:589
verses.text: As curse therefore He satisfies the type of the accursed serpent; as sin He explains the figure of the sacrifice of the goats, for on behalf of sin, in the Law, a goat, and not a lamb, was offered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:590
verses.text: So the Lord in the Gospels likened the just to lambs, but sinners to kids; and since He was ordained to undergo the passion not only on behalf of just men, but also of sinners, He appropriately foreshadows His own offering through lambs and goats.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:591
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:592
verses.text: —But the type of the two goats leads us to think of two persons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:593
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:594
verses.text: —The passibility of the manhood and the impassibility of the Godhead could not possibly be prefigured both at once by one goat.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:595
verses.text: The one which was slain could not have shewn the living nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:596
verses.text: So two were taken in order to explain the two natures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:597
verses.text: The same lesson may well be learnt from another sacrifice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:598
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:599
verses.text: —From which?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:600
verses.text: —From that in which the lawgiver bids two pure birds be offered—one to be slain, and the other, after having been dipped in the blood of the slain, to be let go.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:601
verses.text: Here also we see a type of the Godhead and of the manhood—of the manhood slain and of the godhead appropriating the passion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:602
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:603
verses.text: —You have given us many types, but I object to enigmas.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:604
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:605
verses.text: —Yet the divine Apostle says that the narratives are types.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:606
verses.text: Hagar is called a type of the old covenant; Sarah is likened to the heavenly Jerusalem; Ishmael is a type of Israel, and Isaac of the new people.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:607
verses.text: So you must accuse the loud trumpet of the Spirit for giving its enigmas for us all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:608
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:609
verses.text: —Though you urge any number of arguments, you will never induce me to divide the passion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:610
verses.text: I have heard the voice of the angel saying to Mary and her companions, "Come, see the place where the Lord lay".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:611
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:612
verses.text: —This is quite in accordance with our common customs; we speak of the part by the name which belongs to all the parts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:613
verses.text: When we go into the churches where are buried the holy apostles or prophets or martyrs, we ask from time to time, "Who is it who lies in the shrine?" and those who are able to give us information say in reply, Thomas, it may be, the Apostle, or John the Baptist, or Stephen the protomartyr, or any other of the saints, mentioning them by name, though perhaps only a few scanty relics of them lie here.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:614
verses.text: But no one who hears these names which are common to both body and soul will imagine that the souls also are shut up in the chests; everybody knows that the chests contain only the bodies or even small portions of the bodies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:615
verses.text: The holy angel spoke in precisely the same manner when he described the body by the name of the person.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:616
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:617
verses.text: —But how can you prove that the angel spoke to the women about the Lord's body?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:618
verses.text: —In the first place, the tomb itself suffices to settle the question, for to a tomb is committed neither soul nor Godhead whose nature is uncircumscribed; tombs are made for bodies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:619
verses.text: Furthermore this is plainly taught by the divine Scripture, for so the holy Matthew narrates the event, "When the even was come there came a rich man of Arimathaea named Joseph who also himself was Jesus' disciple: he went to Pilate and begged the body of Jesus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:620
verses.text: Then Pilate commanded the body to be delivered, and when Joseph had taken the body, he wrapped it in a clean linen cloth, and laid it in his own new tomb, which he had hewn out in the rock: and he rolled a great stone to the door of the sepulchre and departed".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:621
verses.text: See how often he mentions the body in order to stop the mouths of them who blaspheme the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:622
verses.text: The same course is pursued by the thrice blessed Mark, whose narrative I will also quote.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:623
verses.text: "And now when the even was come, because it was the preparation, that is, the day before the Sabbath, Joseph of Arimathaea, an honourable counsellor, which also waited for the kingdom of God, came, and went in boldly unto Pilate, and craved the body of Jesus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:624
verses.text: And Pilate marvelled if He were already dead; and calling unto him the centurion, he asked him whether He had been any while dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:625
verses.text: And when he knew it of the centurion, he gave the body to Joseph, and he brought fine linen, and took him down, and wrapped Him in the linen, and laid Him in a sepulchre," and so on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:626
verses.text: Observe with admiration, the harmony of terms, and how consistently and continuously the word body is introduced.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:627
verses.text: The illustrious Luke, too, relates just in the same way how Joseph begged the body and after he had received it treated it with due rites.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:628
verses.text: By the divine John we are told yet more, "Joseph of Arimathaea being a disciple of Jesus, but secretly for fear of the Jews, besought Pilate that he might take away the body of Jesus; and Pilate gave him leave.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:629
verses.text: He came therefore and took the body of Jesus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:630
verses.text: And there came also Nicodemus, which at the first came to Jesus by night, and brought a mixture of myrrh and aloes about a hundred pound weight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:631
verses.text: Then took they the body of Jesus and wound it in linen clothes with the spices, as the manner of the Jews is to bury.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:632
verses.text: Now in the place where He was crucified there was a garden; and in the garden a new sepulchre, wherein was never man yet laid.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:633
verses.text: There laid they Jesus therefore because of the Jews' preparation day, for the sepulchre was nigh at hand".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:634
verses.text: Observe how often mention is made of the body; how the Evangelist shows that it was the body which was nailed to the cross, the body begged by Joseph of Pilate, the body taken down from the tree, the body wrapped in linen clothes with the myrrh and aloes, and then the name of the person given to it; and Jesus said to have been laid in a tomb.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:635
verses.text: Thus the angel said, "Come see the place where the Lord lay," naming the part by the name of the whole; and we constantly do just the same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:636
verses.text: In this place, we say, such an one was buried; not the body of such an one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:637
verses.text: Every one in his senses knows that we are speaking of the body, and such a mode of speech is customary in divine Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:638
verses.text: Aaron, we read, died and they buried him on Mount Hor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:639
verses.text: Samuel died and they buried him at Ramah, and there are many similar instances.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:640
verses.text: The same use is followed by the divine Apostle when speaking of the death of the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:641
verses.text: "I delivered unto you first of all," he writes, "that which I also received how that Christ died for our sins according to the Scriptures; and that He was buried, and that He rose again the third day according to the Scriptures," and so on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:642
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:643
verses.text: —In the passages we have just now read the Apostle does not mention a body, but Christ the Saviour of us all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:644
verses.text: You have brought evidence against your own side, and wounded yourself with your own weapon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:645
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:646
verses.text: —You seem to have very quickly forgotten the long discourse in which I proved to you over and over again that the body is spoken of by the name of the person.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:647
verses.text: This is what is now done by the divine Apostle, and it can easily be proved from this very passage.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:648
verses.text: Now let us look at it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:649
verses.text: Why did the divine writer write thus to the Corinthians?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:650
verses.text: —They had been deceived by some into believing that there is no resurrection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:651
verses.text: When the teacher of the world learnt this he furnished them with his arguments about the resurrection of the bodies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:652
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:653
verses.text: —Why then does he introduce the resurrection of the Lord, when he wishes to prove the resurrection of the bodies?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:654
verses.text: —As sufficient to prove the resurrection of us all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:655
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:656
verses.text: —In what is His death like the death of the rest; that by His resurrection may be proved the resurrection of all?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:657
verses.text: —The reason of the incarnation, suffering, and death of the only begotten Son of God, was that He might destroy death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:658
verses.text: Thus, after rising, by His own resurrection He preaches the resurrection of all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:659
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:660
verses.text: —But who, hearing of a resurrection of God, would ever believe that the resurrection of all men would be exactly like it? The difference of the natures does not allow of our believing in the argument of the resurrection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:661
verses.text: He is God and they are men, and the difference between God and men is incalculable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:662
verses.text: They are mortal, and subject to death, like to the grass and to the flower.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:663
verses.text: He is almighty.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:664
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:665
verses.text: —But after His incarnation God the Word had a body, and through this He proved His likeness to men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:666
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:667
verses.text: —Yes; and for this reason the suffering and the death and the resurrection are all of the body, and in proof of this the divine Apostle in another place promises renewal of life to all, and to them that believe in the resurrection of their Saviour, yet look upon the general resurrection of all as fable, he exclaims, "Now if Christ be preached that He rose from the dead, how say some among you that there is no resurrection of the dead? But if there is no resurrection of the dead, then is Christ not risen, and if Christ he not risen…your faith is vain, you are yet in your sins".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:668
verses.text: And from the past he confirms the future, and from what is disbelieved he disproves what is believed, for he says, If the one seems impossible to you, then the other will be false; if the one seems real and true, then let the other in like manner seem true, for here too a resurrection of the body is preached, and this body is called the first fruits of those.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:669
verses.text: The resurrection of this body after many arguments he affirms directly, "But now is Christ risen from the dead and become the firstfruits of them that slept, for since by man came death, by man came also the resurrection of the dead, for as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive," and he does not only confirm the argument of the resurrection, but also reveals the mystery of the oeconomy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:670
verses.text: He calls Christ man that he may prove the remedy to be appropriate to the disease.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:671
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:672
verses.text: —Then the Christ is only a man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:673
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:674
verses.text: —God forbid.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:675
verses.text: On the contrary, we have again and again confessed that He is not only man but eternal God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:676
verses.text: But He suffered as man, not as God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:677
verses.text: And this the divine Apostle clearly teaches us when he says "For since by man came death, by man came also the resurrection of the dead".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:678
verses.text: And in his letter to the Thessalonians, he strengthens his argument concerning the general resurrection by that of our Saviour in the passage "For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, even them also which sleep in Jesus will God bring with him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:679
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:680
verses.text: —The Apostle proves the general resurrection by means of the Lord's resurrection, and it is clear that in this case also what died and rose was a body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:681
verses.text: For he would never have attempted to prove the general resurrection by its means unless there had been some relation between the substance of the one and the other.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:682
verses.text: I shall never consent to apply the passion to the human nature alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:683
verses.text: It seems agreeable to my view to say that God the Word died in the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:684
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:685
verses.text: —We have frequently shewn that what is naturally immortal can in no way die.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:686
verses.text: If then He died He was not immortal; and what perils lie in the blasphemy of the words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:687
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:688
verses.text: —He is by nature immortal, but He became man and suffered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:689
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:690
verses.text: —Therefore He underwent change, for how otherwise could He being immortal submit to death? But we have agreed that the substance of the Trinity is immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:691
verses.text: Having therefore a nature superior to change, He by no means shared death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:692
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:693
verses.text: —The divine Peter says "Christ hath suffered for us in the flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:694
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:695
verses.text: —This agrees with what we have said, for we have learnt the rule of dogmas from the divine Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:696
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:697
verses.text: —How then can you deny that God the Word suffered in the flesh?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:698
verses.text: —Because we have not found this expression in the divine Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:699
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:700
verses.text: —But I have just quoted you the utterance of the great Peter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:701
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:702
verses.text: —You seem to ignore the distinction of the terms.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:703
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:704
verses.text: —What terms? Do you not regard the Lord Christ as God the Word?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:705
verses.text: —The term Christ in the case of our Lord and Saviour signifies the incarnate Word the Immanuel, God with us, both God and man, but the term "God the Word" so said signifies the simple nature before the world, superior to time, and incorporeal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:706
verses.text: Wherefore the Holy Ghost that spake through the holy Apostles nowhere attributes passion or death to this name.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:707
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:708
verses.text: —If the passion is attributed to the Christ, and God the Word after being made man was called Christ, I hold that he who states God the Word to have suffered in the flesh is in no way unreasonable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:709
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:710
verses.text: —Hazardous and rash in the extreme is such an attempt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:711
verses.text: But let us look at the question in this way.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:712
verses.text: Does the divine Scripture state God the Word to be of God and of the Father?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:713
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:714
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:715
verses.text: —And it describes the Holy Ghost as being in like manner of God?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:716
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:717
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:718
verses.text: —But it calls God the Word only begotten Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:719
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:720
verses.text: —It does.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:721
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:722
verses.text: —It nowhere so names the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:723
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:724
verses.text: —No.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:725
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:726
verses.text: —Yet the Holy Ghost also has Its subsistence of the Father and God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:727
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:728
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:729
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:730
verses.text: —We grant then that both the Son and the Holy Ghost are both of God the Father; but would you dare to call the Holy Ghost Son?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:731
verses.text: —Certainly not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:732
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:733
verses.text: —Why?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:734
verses.text: —Because I do not find this term in the divine Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:735
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:736
verses.text: —Or begotten?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:737
verses.text: —No.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:738
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:739
verses.text: —Wherefore?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:740
verses.text: —Because I no more learn this in the divine Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:741
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:742
verses.text: —But what name can properly be given to that which is neither begotten nor created?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:743
verses.text: —We style it uncreated and unbegotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:744
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:745
verses.text: —And we say that the Holy Ghost is neither created nor begotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:746
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:747
verses.text: —By no means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:748
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:749
verses.text: —Would you then dare to call the Holy Ghost unbegotten?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:750
verses.text: —No.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:751
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:752
verses.text: —But why refuse to call that which is naturally uncreate, but not begotten, unbegotten?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:753
verses.text: —Because I have not learnt so from the divine Scripture, and I am greatly afraid of saying, or using language which Scripture does not use.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:754
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:755
verses.text: —Then, my good sir, I maintain the same caution in the case of the passion of salvation; do you too avoid all the divine names which Scripture has avoided in the case of the passion, and do not attribute the passion to them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:756
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:757
verses.text: —What names?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:758
verses.text: —The passion is never connected with the name "God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:759
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:760
verses.text: —But even I do not affirm that God the Word suffered apart from a body, but say that He suffered in flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:761
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:762
verses.text: —You affirm then a mode of passion, not impassibility.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:763
verses.text: No one would ever say this even in the case of a human body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:764
verses.text: For who not altogether out of his senses would say that the soul of Paul died in flesh? This could never be said even in the case of a great villain; for the souls even of the wicked are immortal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:765
verses.text: We say that such or such a murderer has been slain, but no one would ever say that his soul had been killed in the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:766
verses.text: But if we describe the souls of murderers and violators of sepulchres as free from death, far more right is it to acknowledge as immortal the soul of our Saviour, in that it never tasted sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:767
verses.text: If the souls of them who have most greatly erred have escaped death on account of their nature, how could that soul, whose nature was immortal and who never received the least taint of sin, have taken death's hook?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:768
verses.text: —It is quite useless for you to give me all these long arguments.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:769
verses.text: We are agreed that the soul of the Saviour is immortal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:770
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:771
verses.text: —But of what punishment are you not deserving, you who say that the soul, which is by nature created, is immortal, and are for making the divine substance mortal for the Word; you who deny that the soul of the Saviour tasted death in the flesh, and dare to maintain that God the Word, Creator of all things, underwent the passion?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:772
verses.text: —We say that He underwent the passion impassibly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:773
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:774
verses.text: —And what man in his senses would ever put up with such ridiculous riddles? Who ever heard of an impassible passion, or of an immortal mortality? The impassible has never undergone passion, and what has undergone passion could not possibly be impassible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:775
verses.text: But we hear the exclamation of the divine Paul: "Who only hath immortality dwelling in the light which no man can approach unto".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:776
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:777
verses.text: —Why then do we say that the invisible powers too and the souls of men, aye and the very devils, are immortal?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:778
verses.text: —We do say so; that God is absolutely immortal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:779
verses.text: He is immortal not by partaking of substance, but in substance; He does not possess an immortality which He has received of another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:780
verses.text: It is He Himself who has bestowed their immortality on the angels and on them that thou hast just now mentioned.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:781
verses.text: How, moreover, when the divine Paul styles Him immortal and says that He only hath immortality, can you attribute to Him the passion of death?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:782
verses.text: —We say that He tasted death after the incarnation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:783
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:784
verses.text: —But over and over again we have confessed Him immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:785
verses.text: If being previously immortal He afterwards underwent death through the flesh, a change having preceded His undergoing death; if His life left Him for three days and three nights, how do such statements fall short of the most extreme impiety? For I think that not even they that are struggling against impiety can venture to let such words fall from their lips without peril.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:786
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:787
verses.text: —Cease from charging us with impiety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:788
verses.text: Even we say that not the divine nature suffered but the human; but we do say that the divine shared with the body in suffering.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:789
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:790
verses.text: —What can you mean by sharing in suffering? Do you mean that when the nails were driven into the body the divine nature felt the sense of pain?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:791
verses.text: —I do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:792
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:793
verses.text: —Both now and in our former investigations we have shewn that the soul does not share all the faculties of the body but that the body while it receives vital force has the sense of suffering through the soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:794
verses.text: And even supposing us to grant that the soul shares in pain with the body we shall none the less find the divine nature to be impassible, for it was not united to the body instead of a soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:795
verses.text: Or do you not acknowledge that He assumed a soul?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:796
verses.text: —I have often acknowledged it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:797
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:798
verses.text: —And that He assumed a reasonable Soul?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:799
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:800
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:801
verses.text: —If then together with the body He assumed the soul, and we grant that the soul shared in suffering with the body, then the soul, not the Godhead, shared the passion with the body; it shared the passion, receiving pangs by means of the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:802
verses.text: But possibly somebody might agree to the soul sharing suffering with the body, but might deny its sharing death, because of its having an immortal nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:803
verses.text: On this account the Lord said "Fear not them which kill the body but are not able to kill the soul".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:804
verses.text: If then we deny that the soul of the Saviour shared death with the body, how could any one accept the blasphemy you and your friends presumptuously promulgate when you dare to say that the divine nature participated in death? This is the more inexcusable when the Lord points out at one time that the body was being offered, at another that the soul was being troubled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:805
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:806
verses.text: —And where doth the Lord shew that the body was being offered? Or are you going to bring me once more that well worn passage "Destroy this temple and in three days I will raise it up"? Or with your conceited self-sufficiency are you going to quote me the words of the Evangelist? "But He spake of the temple of his body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:807
verses.text: When therefore He was risen from the dead His disciples remembered that He had said this unto them and they believed the Scripture and the words which He had said".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:808
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:809
verses.text: —If you have such a detestation of the divine words which preach the mystery of the incarnation, why, like Marcion and Valentinus and Manes, do you not destroy texts of this kind? For this is what they have done.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:810
verses.text: But if this seems to you rash and impious, do not turn the Lord's words into ridicule, but rather follow the Apostles in their belief after the resurrection that the Godhead raised again the temple which the Jews had destroyed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:811
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:812
verses.text: —If you have any good evidence to adduce, give over gibing and fulfil your promise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:813
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:814
verses.text: —Remember specially those words of the gospels in which the Lord made a comparison between manna and the true bread.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:815
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:816
verses.text: —I remember.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:817
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:818
verses.text: —In that passage after speaking at some length about the bread of life, he added, "The bread that I will give is my flesh which I will give for the life of the world".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:819
verses.text: In these words may be understood alike the bounty of the Godhead and the boon of the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:820
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:821
verses.text: —One quotation is not enough to settle the question.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:822
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:823
verses.text: —The Ethiopian eunuch had not read much of the Bible, but when he had found one witness from the prophets he was guided by it to salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:824
verses.text: But not all Apostles and prophets and all the preachers of the truth who have lived since then are enough to convince you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:825
verses.text: Nevertheless I will bring you some further testimony about the Lord's body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:826
verses.text: You cannot but know that passage in the Gospel history where, after eating the passover with His disciples, our Lord pointed to the death of the typical lamb and taught what body corresponded with that shadow.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:827
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:828
verses.text: —Yes I know it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:829
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:830
verses.text: —Remember then what it was which our Lord took and broke, and what He called it when He had taken it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:831
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:832
verses.text: —I will answer in mystic language for the sake of the uninitiated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:833
verses.text: After taking and breaking it and giving it to His disciples He said, "This is my body which was given for you" or according to the apostle "broken" and again, "This is my blood of the New Testament which is shed for many".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:834
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:835
verses.text: —Then when exhibiting the type of the passion He did not mention the Godhead?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:836
verses.text: —No.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:837
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:838
verses.text: —But He did mention the body and blood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:839
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:840
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:841
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:842
verses.text: —And the body was nailed to the Cross?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:843
verses.text: —Even so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:844
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:845
verses.text: —Come, then; look at this.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:846
verses.text: When after the resurrection the doors were shut and the Lord came to the holy disciples and beheld them affrighted, what means did He use to destroy their fear and instead of fear to infuse faith?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:847
verses.text: —He said to them "Behold my hands and my feet that it is I myself; handle me and see; for a spirit hath not flesh and bones as ye see me have".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:848
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:849
verses.text: —So when they disbelieved He shewed them the body?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:850
verses.text: —He did.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:851
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:852
verses.text: —Therefore the body rose?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:853
verses.text: —Clearly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:854
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:855
verses.text: —And I suppose what rose was what had died?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:856
verses.text: —Even so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:857
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:858
verses.text: —And what had died was what was nailed to the cross?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:859
verses.text: —Of necessity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:860
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:861
verses.text: —Then according to your own argument the body suffered?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:862
verses.text: —Your series of arguments forces us to this conclusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:863
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:864
verses.text: —Consider this too.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:865
verses.text: Now I will be questioner, and do you answer as becomes a lover of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:866
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:867
verses.text: —I will answer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:868
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:869
verses.text: —When the Holy Ghost came down upon the Apostles, and that wonderful sight and sound collected thousands to the house, what did the chief of the apostles in the speech he then made say concerning the Lord's resurrection?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:870
verses.text: —He quoted the divine David, and said that he had received promises from God that the Lord Christ should be born of the fruit of his loins and that in trust in these promises he prophetically foresaw His resurrection, and plainly said that His soul was not left in Hades and that His flesh did not see corruption.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:871
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:872
verses.text: —His resurrection therefore is of these.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:873
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:874
verses.text: —How can any one in his senses say that there is a resurrection of the soul which never died?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:875
verses.text: —How comes it that you who attribute the passion, the death and the resurrection to the immutable and uncircumscribed Godhead have suddenly appeared before us in your right mind and now object to connecting the word resurrection with the soul?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:876
verses.text: —Because the word resurrection is applicable to what has fallen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:877
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:878
verses.text: —But the body does not obtain resurrection apart from a soul, but being renewed by the divine will, and conjoined with its yokefellow, it receives life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:879
verses.text: Was it not thus that the Lord raised Lazarus?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:880
verses.text: —It is plain that not the body alone rises.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:881
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:882
verses.text: —This is more distinctly taught by the divine Ezekiel, for he points out how the Lord commanded the bones to come together, and how all of them were duly fitted together, and how He made sinews and veins and arteries grow with all the flesh pertaining to them and the skin that clothes them all, and then ordered the souls to come back to their own bodies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:883
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:884
verses.text: —This is true.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:885
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:886
verses.text: —But the Lord's body did not undergo this corruption, but remained unimpaired, and on the third day recovered its own soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:887
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:888
verses.text: —Agreed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:889
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:890
verses.text: —Then the death was of what had suffered?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:891
verses.text: —Without question.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:892
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:893
verses.text: —And when the great Peter mentioned the resurrection, and the divine David too, they said that His soul was not left in Hell, but that His body did not undergo corruption?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:894
verses.text: —They did.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:895
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:896
verses.text: —Then it was not the Godhead which underwent death, but the body by severance from the soul?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:897
verses.text: —I cannot brook these absurdities.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:898
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:899
verses.text: —But you are fighting against your own arguments; it is your own words which you are calling absurd.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:900
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:901
verses.text: —You slander me; not one of these words is mine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:902
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:903
verses.text: —Suppose any one to ask what is the animal which is at once reasonable and mortal, and suppose some one else to answer—man; which of the two would you call interpreter of the saying? The questioner or the answerer?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:904
verses.text: —The answerer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:905
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:906
verses.text: —Then I was quite right in calling the arguments yours? For you, I ween, in your answers, by rejecting some points and accepting others, confirmed them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:907
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:908
verses.text: —Then I will not answer any longer; do you answer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:909
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:910
verses.text: —I will answer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:911
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:912
verses.text: —What do you say to those words of the Apostle "Had they known it they would not have crucified the Lord of glory"? in this passage he mentions neither body nor soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:913
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:914
verses.text: —Therefore you must not put the words "in the flesh" in it,—for this is your ingenious invention for decrying the Godhead of the Word—but must attribute the passion to the bare Godhead of the Word.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:915
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:916
verses.text: —No; no.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:917
verses.text: He suffered in the flesh, but His incorporeal nature was not capable of suffering by itself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:918
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:919
verses.text: —Ah! but nothing must be added to the Apostle's words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:920
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:921
verses.text: —When we know the Apostle's meaning there is nothing absurd in adding what is left out.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:922
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:923
verses.text: —But to add anything to the divine words is wild and rash.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:924
verses.text: To explain what is written and reveal the hidden meaning is holy and pious.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:925
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:926
verses.text: —Quite right.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:927
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:928
verses.text: —We two then shall do nothing unreasonable and unholy in examining the mind of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:929
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:930
verses.text: —No.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:931
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:932
verses.text: —Let us then look together into what seems to be hidden.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:933
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:934
verses.text: —By all means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:935
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:936
verses.text: —Did the great Paul call the divine James the Lord's brother?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:937
verses.text: —He did.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:938
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:939
verses.text: —But in what sense are we to regard him as brother? By relationship of His godhead or of His manhood?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:940
verses.text: —I will not consent to divide the united natures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:941
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:942
verses.text: —But you have often divided them in our previous investigations, and you shall do the same thing now.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:943
verses.text: Tell me; do you say that God the Word was only begotten Son?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:944
verses.text: —I do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:945
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:946
verses.text: —And only begotten means only Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:947
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:948
verses.text: —Certainly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:949
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:950
