verses.text: —And the only begotten cannot have a brother?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:951
verses.text: —Of course not, for if He had had a brother He would not be called the only begotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:952
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:953
verses.text: —Then they were wrong in calling James the brother of the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:954
verses.text: For the Lord was only begotten, and the only begotten cannot have a brother.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:955
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:956
verses.text: —No, but the Lord is not incorporeal and the proclaimers of the truth are referring only to what touches the godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:957
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:958
verses.text: —How then would you prove the word of the apostle true?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:959
verses.text: —By saying that James was of kin with the Lord according to the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:960
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:961
verses.text: —See how you have brought in again that division which you object to.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:962
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:963
verses.text: —It was not possible to explain the kinship in any other way.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:964
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:965
verses.text: —Then do not find fault with those who cannot explain similar difficulties in any other way.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:966
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:967
verses.text: —Now you are getting the argument off the track because you want to shirk the question.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:968
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:969
verses.text: —Not at all, my friend.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:970
verses.text: That will be settled too by the points we have investigated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:971
verses.text: Now look; when you were reminded of James the brother of the Lord, you said that the relationship referred not to the Godhead but to the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:972
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:973
verses.text: —I did.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:974
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:975
verses.text: —Well, now that you are told of the passion of the cross, refer this too to the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:976
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:977
verses.text: —The Apostle called the crucified "Lord of Glory," and the same Apostle called the Lord "brother of James".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:978
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:979
verses.text: —And it is the same Lord in both cases.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:980
verses.text: If then you are right in referring the relationship to the flesh you must also refer the passion to the flesh, for it is perfectly ridiculous to regard the relationship without distinction and to refer the passion to Christ without distinction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:981
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:982
verses.text: —I follow the Apostle who calls the crucified "Lord of glory".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:983
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:984
verses.text: —I follow too, and believe that He was "Lord of glory".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:985
verses.text: For the body which was nailed to the wood was not that of any common man but of the Lord of glory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:986
verses.text: But we must acknowledge that the union makes the names common.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:987
verses.text: Once more: do you say that the flesh of the Lord came down from heaven?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:988
verses.text: —Of course not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:989
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:990
verses.text: —But was formed in the Virgin's womb?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:991
verses.text: —Yes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:992
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:993
verses.text: —How, then, does the Lord say "If ye shall see the Son of man ascend up where He was before," and again "No man hath ascended up to heaven but He that came down from heaven, even the Son of man which is in heaven?"  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:994
verses.text: —He is speaking not of the flesh, but of the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:995
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:996
verses.text: —Yes; but the Godhead is of the God and Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:997
verses.text: How then does He call him Son of man?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:998
verses.text: —The peculiar properties of the natures are shared by the person, for on account of the union the same being is both Son of man and Son of God, everlasting and of time, Son of David and Lord of David, and so on with the rest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:999
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1000
verses.text: —Very right.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1001
verses.text: But it is also important to recognise the fact that no confusion of natures results from both having one name.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1002
verses.text: Wherefore we are endeavouring to distinguish how the same being is Son of God and also Son of man, and how He is "the same yesterday, to-day, and for ever," and by the reverent distinction of terms we find that the contradictions are in agreement.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1003
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1004
verses.text: —You are right.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1005
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1006
verses.text: —You say that the divine nature came down from heaven and that in consequence of the union it was called the Son of man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1007
verses.text: Thus it behoves us to say that the flesh was nailed to the tree, but to hold that the divine nature even on the cross and in the tomb was inseparable from this flesh, though from it it derived no sense of suffering, since the divine nature is naturally incapable of undergoing both suffering and death and its substance is immortal and impassible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1008
verses.text: It is in this sense that the crucified is styled Lord of Glory, by attribution of the title of the impassible nature to the passible, since, as we know, a body is described as belonging to this latter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1009
verses.text: Now let us examine the matter thus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1010
verses.text: The words of the divine Apostle are "Had they known it they would not have crucified the Lord of Glory".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1011
verses.text: They crucified the nature which they knew, not that of which they were wholly ignorant: had they known that of which they were ignorant they would not have crucified that which they knew: they crucified the human because they were ignorant of the divine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1012
verses.text: Have you forgotten their own words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1013
verses.text: "For a good work we stone thee not but for blasphemy, and because that thou, being a man, makest thyself God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1014
verses.text: These words are a plain proof that they recognised the nature they saw, while of the invisible they were wholly ignorant: had they known that nature they would not have crucified the Lord of glory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1015
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1016
verses.text: —That is very probable, but the exposition of the faith laid down by the Fathers in council at Nicaea says that the only begotten Himself, very God, of one substance with the Father, suffered and was crucified.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1017
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1018
verses.text: —You seem to forget what we have agreed on again and again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1019
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1020
verses.text: —What do you mean?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1021
verses.text: —I mean that after the union the holy Scripture applies to one person terms both of exaltation and of humiliation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1022
verses.text: But possibly you are also ignorant that the illustrious Fathers first mentioned His taking flesh and being made man, and then afterwards added that He suffered and was crucified, and thus spoke of the passion after they had set forth the nature capable of passion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1023
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1024
verses.text: —The Fathers said that the Son of God, Light of Light, of the substance of the Father, suffered and was crucified.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1025
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1026
verses.text: —I have observed more than once that both the Divine and the human are ascribed to the one Person.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1027
verses.text: It is in accordance with this position that the thrice blessed Fathers, after teaching how we should believe in the Father, and then passing on to the person of the Son, did not immediately add "and in the Son of God," although it would have very naturally followed that after defining what touches God the Father they should straightway have introduced the name of Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1028
verses.text: But their object was to give us at one and the same time instruction on the theology and on the oeconomy, lest there should be supposed to be any distinction between the Person of the Godhead and the Person of the Manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1029
verses.text: On this account they added to their statement concerning the Father that we must believe also in our Lord Jesus Christ, the Son of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1030
verses.text: Now after the incarnation God the Word is called Christ, for this name includes alike all that is proper to the Godhead and to the manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1031
verses.text: We recognise nevertheless that some properties belong to the one nature and some to the others, and this may at once be understood from the actual terms of the Creed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1032
verses.text: For tell me: to what do you apply the phrase "of the substance of the Father"? to the Godhead, or to the nature that was fashioned of the seed of David?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1033
verses.text: —To the Godhead, as is plain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1034
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1035
verses.text: —And the clause "Very God of very God"; to which do you hold this belongs, to the Godhead or to the manhood?  Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1036
verses.text: —To the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1037
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1038
verses.text: —Therefore neither the flesh nor the soul is of one substance with the Father, for they are created, but the Godhead which formed all things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1039
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1040
verses.text: —True.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1041
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1042
verses.text: —Very well, then.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1043
verses.text: And when we are told of passion and of the cross we must recognise the nature which submitted to the passion; we must avoid attributing it to the impassible, and must attribute it to that nature which was assumed for the distinct purpose of suffering.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1044
verses.text: The acknowledgment on the part of the most excellent Fathers that the divine nature was impassible; and their attribution of the passion to the flesh is proved by the conclusion of the creed, which runs "But they who state there was a time when He was not, and before He was begotten He was not, and He was made out of the non-existent, or who allege that the Son of God was of another essence or substance mutable or variable, these the holy catholic and apostolic Church anathematizes".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1045
verses.text: See then what penalties are denounced against them that attribute the passion to the divine nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1046
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1047
verses.text: —They are speaking in this place of mutation and variation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1048
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1049
verses.text: —But what is the passion but mutation and variation? For if, being impassible before His incarnation, He suffered after His incarnation, He assuredly suffered by undergoing mutation; and if being immortal before He became man, He tasted death, as you say, after being made man, He underwent a complete alteration by being made mortal after being immortal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1050
verses.text: But expressions of this kind, and their authors with them, have all been expelled by the illustrious Fathers from the bounds of the Church, and cut off like rotten limbs from the sound body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1051
verses.text: We therefore exhort you to fear the punishment and abhor the blasphemy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1052
verses.text: Now I will show you that in their own writings the holy Fathers have held the opinions we have expressed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1053
verses.text: Of the witnesses I shall bring forward some took part in that great Council; some flourished in the Church after their time; some illuminated the world long before.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1054
verses.text: But their harmony is broken neither by difference of periods nor by diversity of language; like the harp their strings are several and separate but like the harp they make one harmonious music.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1055
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1056
verses.text: —I was anxious for and shall be delighted at such citations.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1057
verses.text: Instruction of this kind cannot be gainsaid, and is most useful.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1058
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1059
verses.text: —Now; open your ears and receive the streams that flow from the spiritual springs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1060
verses.text: Testimony of the holy Ignatius, bishop of Antioch, and martyr.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1061
verses.text: From his Epistle to the Smyrnaeans:—  "They do not admit Eucharists and oblations, because they do not confess the Eucharist to be flesh of our Saviour Jesus Christ which suffered for our sins and which of His goodness the Father raised".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1062
verses.text: Testimony of Irenaeus, bishop of Lyons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1063
verses.text: From his third book against heresies (Chap.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1064
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1065
verses.text: ):—  "It is clear then that Paul knew no other Christ save Him that suffered and was buried and rose and was born, whom he calls man, for after saying, 'If Christ be preached that He rose from the dead,' he adds, giving the reason of His incarnation, 'For since by man came death by man came also the resurrection of the dead,' and on all occasions in reference to the passion, the manhood and the dissolution of the Lord, he uses the name of Christ as in the text, 'Destroy not him with thy meat for whom Christ died,' and again, 'But now in Christ ye who sometimes were far off are made nigh in the blood of Christ,' and again, 'Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us: for it is written, Cursed is every one that hangeth on a tree.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1066
verses.text: '"  Of the same from the same work.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1067
verses.text: (Chapter xxi.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1068
verses.text: ):—  "For as He was Man that He might be tempted, so was He Word that He might be glorified.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1069
verses.text: In His temptation, His crucifixion and His dying, the Word was inoperative; but in His victory, His patience, His goodness, His resurrection and His assumption it was co-operative with the manhood".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1070
verses.text: Of the same from the fifth book of the same work:—  "When with His own blood the Lord had ransomed us, and given His soul on behalf of our souls, and His flesh instead of our flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1071
verses.text: The testimony of the holy Hippolytus, bishop and martyr.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1072
verses.text: From his letter to a certain Queen:—  "So he calls Him 'The firstfruits of them that slept,' and 'The first born of the dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1073
verses.text: ' When He had risen and was wishful to show that what had risen was the same body which died, when the Apostles doubted, He called to Him Thomas and said 'Handle me and see; for a spirit hath not flesh and bones as ye see me have.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1074
verses.text: '"  Of the same from the same letter:—  "By calling Him firstfruits He bore witness to what we have said, that the Saviour, after taking the flesh of the same material, raised it, making it firstfruits of the flesh of the just, in order that all we that believe might have expectation of our resurrection through trust in Him that is risen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1075
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse on the two thieves:—  "The body of the Lord gave both to the world,—the holy blood and the sacred water".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1076
verses.text: Of the same from the same discourse:—  "And the body being, humanly speaking, a corpse, has in itself great power of life, for there flowed from it what does not flow from dead bodies—blood and water,—that we might know what vital force lies in the indwelling power in the body, so that it is a corpse evidently unlike others, and is able to pour forth for us causes of life".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1077
verses.text: Of the same from the same discourse:—  "Not a bone of the holy Lamb is broken.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1078
verses.text: The type shews that the passion cannot touch the power, for the bones are the power of the body".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1079
verses.text: Testimony of the holy Eustathius, bishop of Antioch, and confessor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1080
verses.text: From his book on the soul:—  "Their impious calumny can be refuted in a few words; they may be right, unless He voluntarily gave up His own body to the destruction of death for the sake of the salvation of men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1081
verses.text: First of all they attribute to Him extraordinary infirmity in not being able to repel His enemies assault".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1082
verses.text: Of the same from the same book:—  "Why do they, in the concoction of their earth-born deceits, make much of proving that the Christ assumed a body without a soul? In order that if they could seduce any to lay down that this is the case, then, by attributing to the divine Spirit variations of affection, they might easily persuade them that the mutable is not begotten of the immutable nature".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1083
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse on "the Lord created me in the beginning of His ways":—  "The man Who died rose on the third day, and, when Mary was eager to lay hold of His holy limbs, He objected and cried 'Touch me not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1084
verses.text: For I am not yet ascended to my Father; but go to my brethren and say unto them, I ascend unto my Father and your Father and to my God and your God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1085
verses.text: ' Now the words 'I am not yet ascended to my Father,' were not spoken by the Word and God, who came down from heaven, and was in the bosom of the Father, nor by the Wisdom which contains all created things, but were uttered by the man who was compacted of various limbs, who had risen from the dead, who had not yet after His death gone back to the Father, and was reserving for Himself the first fruits of His progress".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1086
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "As he writes he expressly describes the man who was crucified as Lord of Glory, declaring Him to be Lord and Christ, just as the Apostles with one voice when speaking to Israel in the flesh say 'Therefore let all the house of Israel know assuredly that God hath made that same Jesus, Whom ye have crucified, both Lord and Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1087
verses.text: ' He so made Jesus Christ who suffered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1088
verses.text: He did not so make the Wisdom nor yet the Word who has the might of dominion from the beginning, but Him who was lifted up on high and stretched out His hands upon the Cross".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1089
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "For if He is incorporeal and not subject to manual contact, nor apprehended by eyes of flesh, He undergoes no wound, He is not nailed by nails, He has no part in death, He is not hidden in the ground, He is not shut in a grave, He does not rise from a tomb".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1090
verses.text: Of the same from the same book:—  "'No man taketh it from me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1091
verses.text: …I have power to lay it down and I have power to take it again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1092
verses.text: ' If as God He had the double power, He yet yielded to them who were striving of evil counsel to destroy the temple, but by His resurrection He restored it in greater splendour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1093
verses.text: It is proved by incontrovertible evidence that He of Himself rose and renewed His own house, and the great work of the Son is to be ascribed to the divine Father; for the Son does not work without the Father, as is declared in the unimpeachable utterances of the holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1094
verses.text: Wherefore at one time the divine Parent is described as having raised the Christ from the dead, at another time the Son promises to raise His own temple.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1095
verses.text: If then from what has previously been laid down the divine spirit of the Christ is proved to be impassible, in vain do the accursed assail the apostolic definitions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1096
verses.text: If Paul says that the Lord of Glory was crucified, clearly referring to the manhood, we must not on this account refer suffering to the divine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1097
verses.text: Why then do they put these two things together, saying that the Christ was crucified from infirmity?"  Of the same from the same work:—  "But had it been becoming to attribute to Him any kind of infirmity, any one might have said that it was natural to attach these qualities to the manhood, though not to the fulness of the Godhead, or to the dignity of the highest wisdom, or to Him who according to Paul is described as God over all".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1098
verses.text: Of the same from the same book:—  "This then is the manner of the infirmity according to which He is described by Paul as coming to death, for the man lives by God's power when plainly associated with God's spirit, since from the preceding statements He who is believed to be in Him is proved to be also the power of the Most High".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1099
verses.text: Of the same from the same:—  "As by entering the Virgin's womb He did not lessen His power, so neither by the fastening of His body to the wood of the cross is His spirit defiled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1100
verses.text: For when the body was crucified on high the divine Spirit of wisdom dwelt even within the body, trod in heavenly places, filled all the earth, reigned over the depths, visited and judged the soul of every man, and continued to do all that God continually does, for the wisdom that is on high is not prisoned and contained within bodily matter, just as moist and dry material are contained within their vessels and are contained by but do not contain them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1101
verses.text: But this wisdom, being a divine and ineffable power, embraces and confirms alike all that is within and all that is without the temple, and thence proceeding beyond comprehends and sways at once all matter".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1102
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "But if the sun being a visible body, apprehended by the senses, endures everywhere such adverse influences without changing its order, or feeling any blow, be it small or great; can we suppose the incorporeal Wisdom to be defiled and to change its nature because its temple is nailed to the cross or destroyed or wounded or corrupted? The temple suffers, but the substance abides without spot, and preserves its entire dignity without defilement".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1103
verses.text: Of the same from his work on the titles of the Psalms of Degrees:—  "The Father who is perfect, infinite, incomprehensible, and is incapable alike of adornment or disfigurement, receives no acquired glory; nor yet does His Word, who is God begotten of Him, through whom are angels and heaven and earth's boundless bulk and all the form and matter of created things; but the man Christ raised from the dead is exalted and glorified to the open discomfiture of His foes".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1104
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "They however who have lifted up hatred against Him, though they be fenced round with the forces of His foes, are scattered abroad, while the God and Word gloriously raised His own temple".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1105
verses.text: Of the same from his interpretation of the nd Psalm:—  "Moreover the prophet Isaiah following the tracks of His sufferings, among other utterances exclaims with a mighty voice 'And we saw Him and He had no form nor beauty.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1106
verses.text: His form was dishonoured and rejected among the sons of men,' thus distinctly showing that the marks of indignity and the sufferings must be applied to the human but not to the divine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1107
verses.text: And immediately afterwards he adds 'Being a man under stroke, and able to bear infirmity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1108
verses.text: ' He it is who after suffering outrage was seen to have no form or comeliness, then again was changed and clothed with beauty, for the God dwelling in Him was not led like a lamb to death and slaughtered like a sheep, for His nature is invisible".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1109
verses.text: Testimony of the Holy Athanasius, bishop of Alexandria, and confessor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1110
verses.text: From his letter to Epictetus:—  "Whoever reached such a pitch of impiety as to think and say that the Godhead itself of one substance with the Father was circumcised, and from perfect became imperfect; and to deny that what was crucified on the tree was the body, asserting it on the contrary to be the very creative substance of wisdom?"  Of the same from the same treatise:—  "The Word associated with Himself and brought upon Himself what the humanity of the Word suffered, that we might be able to share in the Godhead of the Word.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1111
verses.text: And marvellous it was that the sufferer and He who did not suffer were the same; sufferer in that His own body suffered and He was in it while suffering, but not suffering because the Word, being by nature God, was impassible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1112
verses.text: And He Himself the incorporeal was in the passible body, and the body contained in itself the impassible Word, destroying the infirmities of His body".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1113
verses.text: Of the same from the same letter:—  "For being God and Lord of Glory, He was in the body ingloriously crucified; but the body suffered when smitten on the tree, and water and blood flowed from its side; but being temple of the Word, it was full of the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1114
verses.text: Wherefore when the sun saw its Creator suffering in His outraged body, it drew in its rays, and darkened the earth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1115
verses.text: And that very body with a mortal nature rose superior to its own nature, on account of the Word within it, and is no longer touched by its natural corruption, but clothed with the superhuman Word, became incorruptible".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1116
verses.text: Of the same from his greater discourse on the Faith:—  "Was what rose from the dead, man or God? Peter, the Apostle, who knows better than we, interprets and say, 'and when they had fulfilled all that was written of Him they took Him down from the tree and laid Him in a sepulchre, but God raised Him from the dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1117
verses.text: ' Now the dead body of Jesus which was taken down from the tree, which had been laid in a sepulchre, and entombed by Joseph of Arimathaea, is the very body which the Word raised, saying, 'Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1118
verses.text: ' It is He who quickens all the dead, and quickened the man Christ Jesus, born of Mary, whom He assumed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1119
verses.text: For if while on the cross He raised corpses of the saints that had previously undergone dissolution, much more can God the everliving Word raise the body, which He wore, as says Paul, 'For the word of God is quick and powerful.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1120
verses.text: '"  Of the same from the same work:—  "Life then does not die, but quickens the dead; for as the light is not injured in a dark place, so life cannot suffer when it has visited a mortal nature, for the Godhead of the Word is immutable and invariable as the Lord says in the prophecy about Himself 'I am the Lord I change not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1121
verses.text: '"  Of the same from the same work:—  "Living He cannot die but on the contrary quickens the dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1122
verses.text: He is therefore, by the Godhead derived from the Father, a fount of light; but He that died, or rather rose from the dead, our intercessor, who was born of the Virgin Mary, whom the Godhead of the Word assumed for our sake, is man".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1123
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "It came to pass that Lazarus fell sick and died; but the divine Man did not fall sick nor against His own will did He die, but of His own accord came to the dispensation of death, being strengthened by God the Word who dwelt within Him, and who said 'No man taketh it from me but I lay it down of myself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1124
verses.text: I have power to lay it down and I have power to take it again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1125
verses.text: ' The Godhead then which lays down and takes the life of man which He wore is of the Son, for in its completeness He assumed the manhood, in order that in its completeness He might quicken it, and, with it, the dead".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1126
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse against the Arians:—  "When therefore the blessed Paul says the Father 'raised' the Son 'from the dead' John tells us that Jesus said 'Destroy this temple and in three days I will raise it up…but He spake' of His own 'body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1127
verses.text: ' So it is clear to them that take heed that at the raising of the body the Son is said by Paul to have been raised from the dead, for he refers what concerns the body to the Son's person, and just so when he says 'the Father gave life to the Son' it must be understood that the life was given to the Flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1128
verses.text: For if He Himself is life how can the life receive life?"  Of the same from his work on the Incarnation:—  "For when the Word was conscious that in no other way could the ruin of men be undone save by death to the uttermost, and it was impossible that the Word who is immortal and Son of the Father should die, to effect His end He assumes a body capable of death, that this body, being united to the Word, who is over all, might, in the stead of all, become subject to death, and because of the indwelling Word might remain incorruptible, and so by the grace of the resurrection corruption for the future might lose its power over men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1129
verses.text: Thus offering to death, as a sacrifice and victim free from every spot, the body which He had assumed, by His corresponding offering He straightway destroyed death's power over all His kind; for being the Word of God above and beyond all men, He rightly offered and paid His own temple and bodily instrument, as a ransom for all souls due to death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1130
verses.text: And thus by means of the like (body) being associated with all men, the incorruptible Son of God rightly clothed all men with incorruption by the promise of the resurrection, for the corruption inherent in death no longer has any place with men, for the sake of the Word who dwelt in them by the means of the one body".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1131
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "Wherefore, after His divine manifestations in His works, now also on behalf of all He offered sacrifice, yielding to death His own temple instead of all, that He might make all men irresponsible and free from the ancient transgression, and, exhibiting His own body as incorruptible firstfruits of the resurrection of mankind, might shew Himself stronger than death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1132
verses.text: For the body, as having a common substance—for it was a human body, although by a new miracle its constitution was of the Virgin alone—being mortal, died after the example of its like; but by the descent of the Word into it no longer suffered corruption, according to its own nature, but, on account of God the Word who dwelt within it, was delivered from corruption".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1133
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "Whence, as I have said, since it was not possible for the Word being immortal to die, He took upon Himself a body capable of death, in order that He might offer this same body for all, and He Himself in His suffering on behalf of all through His descent into this body might 'destroy Him that hath the power of death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1134
verses.text: '"  Of the same from the same work:—  "For the body in its passion, as is the nature of bodies, died, but it had the promise of incorruption through the Word that dwelt within it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1135
verses.text: For when the body died the Word was not injured; but He was Himself impassible, incorruptible, and immortal, as being God's Word, and being associated with the body He kept from it the natural corruption of bodies, as says the Spirit to Him 'thou wilt not suffer thy Holy One to see corruption.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1136
verses.text: '"  The testimony of the holy Damasus, bishop of Rome:—  "If any one say that, in the passion of the Cross, God the Son of God suffered pain, and not the flesh with the soul, which the form of the servant put on and assumed, as the Scripture saith, Let him be anathema".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1137
verses.text: Testimony of the holy Ambrosius, bishop of Milan.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1138
verses.text: From his book on the Catholic faith:—  "There are some men who have reached such a pitch of impiety as to think that the Godhead of the Lord was circumcised, and from perfect was made imperfect; and that the divine substance, Creator of all things, and not the flesh, was on the tree".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1139
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "The flesh suffered; but the Godhead is free from death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1140
verses.text: He yielded His body to suffer according to the law of human nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1141
verses.text: For how can God die, when the soul cannot die? 'Fear not,' He says, 'them which kill the body but are not able to kill the soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1142
verses.text: ' If then the soul cannot be slain how can the Godhead be made subject to death?"  Testimony of the holy Basilius, bishop of Caesarea:—  "It is perfectly well known to every one who has the least acquaintance with the meaning of the words of the Apostle that he is not delivering to us a mode of theology but is explaining the reasons of the oeconomy, for he says 'God hath made that same Jesus whom ye have crucified both Lord and Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1143
verses.text: ' Thus he is plainly directing his argument to His human and visible nature".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1144
verses.text: Testimony of the holy Gregorius, bishop of Nazianzus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1145
verses.text: From his letter to the blessed Nectarius, bishop of Constantinople:—  "The saddest thing in what has befallen the churches is the boldness of the utterances of Apollinarius and his party.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1146
verses.text: I cannot understand how your Holiness has allowed them to arrogate to themselves the power of assembling on the same terms with us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1147
verses.text: And a little further on:—  "I will no longer call this serious; it is indeed saddest of all that the only begotten God Himself, Judge of all who exist, the Prince of Life, the Destroyer of Death, is made by him mortal and alleged to receive suffering in His own Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1148
verses.text: He represents the Godhead to have shared with the body in the dissolution of that three days death of the body, and so after the death to have been again raised by the Father".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1149
verses.text: Of the same from his former exposition to Cledonius:—  "It is the contention of the Arians that the manhood was without a soul, that they may refer the passion to the Godhead and represent the same power as both moving the body and suffering".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1150
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse about the Son:—  "It remained for us to treat of what was commanded Him and of His keeping the commandments and doing all things pleasing to Him; and further of His perfection, exaltation, and learning obedience by all that He suffered, His priesthood, His offering, His betrayal, His entreaty to Him that hath power to save Him from death, His agony, His bloody sweat, His prayer and similar manifestations, were it not clear to all that all these expressions in connexion with His Passion in no way signify the nature which was immutable and above suffering".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1151
verses.text: Of the same from his Easter Discourse (Or.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1152
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1153
verses.text: ):—  "'Who is this that cometh from Edom?' and from the earth, and how can the garments of the bloodless and bodiless be red as of one that treadeth in the wine-fat? Urge in reply the beauty of the garment of the body which suffered and was made beautiful in suffering, and was made splendid by the Godhead, than which nothing is lovelier nor more fair".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1154
verses.text: Testimony of Gregory, bishop of Nyssa.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1155
verses.text: From his catechetical oration:—  "And this is the mystery of the dispensation of God concerning the manhood and of the resurrection from the dead, not to prevent the soul from being separated from the body by death according to the necessary law of human nature, and to bring them together again through the resurrection".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1156
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "The flesh which received the Godhead, and which through the resurrection was exalted with the Godhead, is not formed of another material, but of ours; so, just as in the case of our own body, the operation of one of the senses moves to general sensation the whole man united to that part, in like manner just as though all nature were one single animal, the resurrection of the part pervades the whole, being conveyed from the part to the whole by what is continuous and united in nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1157
verses.text: What then do we find extraordinary in the mystery that the upright stoops to the fallen to raise up him that lies low?"  Of the same from the same work:—  "It would be natural also in this part not to heed the one and neglect the other; but in the immortal to behold the human, and to be curiously exact about the diviner quality in the manhood".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1158
verses.text: Of the same from his work against Eunomius:—  "'Tis not the human nature which raises Lazarus to life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1159
verses.text: 'Tis not the impassible power which sheds tears over the dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1160
verses.text: The tear belongs to the man; the life comes from the very life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1161
verses.text: The thousands are not fed by human poverty; omnipotence does not hasten to the fig tree.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1162
verses.text: Who was weary in the way, and who by His word sustains all the world without being weary? What is the brightness of His glory, what was pierced by the nails? What form is smitten in the passion, what is glorified for everlasting? The answer is plain and needs no interpretation".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1163
verses.text: Of the same from the same treatise:—  "He blames them that refer the passion to the human nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1164
verses.text: He wishes himself wholly to subject the Godhead itself to the passion, for the proposition being twofold and doubtful, whether the divinity or the humanity was concerned in the passion, the denial of the one becomes the positive condemnation of the other.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1165
verses.text: While therefore they blame them who see the passion in the humanity, they will bestow unqualified praise on them that maintain the Divinity of the Son of God to be passible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1166
verses.text: But the point established by these means becomes a confirmation of their own absurdity of doctrine; for if, as they allege, the Godhead of the Son suffers while that of the Father in accordance with its substance is conserved in complete impassibility, it follows that the impassible nature is at variance with the nature which sustains suffering".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1167
verses.text: The testimony of the holy Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1168
verses.text: From his discourse on the text "Verily, verily I say unto you, he that heareth my word and believeth on Him that sent me hath everlasting life":—  "Whose then are the sufferings? Of the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1169
verses.text: Therefore if you give to the flesh the suffering, give it also the lowly words; and ascribe the exalted words to Him to Whom you assign the miracles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1170
verses.text: For the God when He is in the act of working wonders naturally speaks in high and lofty language worthy of His works and the man when He is suffering fitly utters lowly words corresponding with His sufferings".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1171
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse on "My Father is greater than I":—  "But when you give the sufferings to the flesh and the miracles to God, you must of necessity, though unwillingly, give the lowly words to the man born of Mary, and the high and lofty words becoming God, to the Word who existed in the beginning.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1172
verses.text: The reason why I utter sometimes lofty words and sometimes lowly is that by the lofty I may show the nobility of the indwelling Word, and by the lowly make known the infirmity of the lowly flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1173
verses.text: So at one time I call myself equal to the Father and at another I call the Father greater; and in this I am not inconsistent with myself, but I shew that I am God and man; God by the lofty and man by the lowly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1174
verses.text: And if you wish to know in what sense my Father is greater than I, I spoke in the flesh and not in the person of the Godhead".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1175
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse on "If it be possible let this cup pass from me":—  "Ascribe not then the sufferings of the flesh to the impassible God, for I, O heretic, am God, and man; God, as the miracles prove; man as is shewn by the sufferings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1176
verses.text: Since then I am God and man, tell me, who was it who suffered? If God suffered, you have spoken blasphemy; but if the flesh suffered, why do you not attribute the passion to Him to whom you ascribe the dread? For while one is suffering another feels on dread; while man is being crucified God is not troubled".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1177
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse against the Arians:—  "And not to prolong what I am saying, I will shortly ask you, O heretic, did He who was begotten of God before the ages suffer, or Jesus who was born of David in the last days? If the Godhead suffered, thou hast spoken blasphemy; if, as the truth is, the manhood suffered, for what reason do you hesitate to attribute the passion to man?"  Of the same from his discourse concerning the Son:—  "Peter said, 'God hath made this Jesus both Lord and Christ' and said too, 'this Jesus whom ye crucified God hath raised up.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1178
verses.text: ' Now it was the manhood, not the Godhead, which became a corpse, and He who raised it was the Word, the power of God, who said in the Gospel, 'Destroy this temple and in three days I will raise it up.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1179
verses.text: ' So when it is said that God hath made Him who became a corpse and rose from the dead both Lord and Christ, what is meant is the flesh, and not the Godhead of the Son".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1180
verses.text: Of the same from his discourse on "The Son can do nothing of Himself":—  "For He had not such a nature as that His life could be held by corruption, since His Godhead was not forcibly reduced to suffering.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1181
verses.text: For how could it? But the manhood was renewed in incorruption.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1182
verses.text: So he says 'For this mortal must put on immortality and this corruptible must put on incorruption.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1183
verses.text: ' You observe the accuracy; he points distinctly to 'this mortal' that you may not entertain the idea of the resurrection of any other flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1184
verses.text: Testimony of the holy Flavianus, bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1185
verses.text: On Easter Day:—  "Wherefore also the cross is boldly preached by us, and the Lord's death confessed among us, though in nothing did the Godhead suffer, for the divine is impassible, but the dispensation was fulfilled by the body".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1186
verses.text: Of the same on Judas the traitor:—  "When therefore you hear of the Lord being betrayed, do not degrade the divine dignity to insignificance, nor attribute to divine power the sufferings of the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1187
verses.text: For the divine is impassible and invariable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1188
verses.text: For if through His love to mankind He took on Him the form of a servant, He underwent no change in nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1189
verses.text: But being what He ever was, he yielded the divine body to experience death".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1190
verses.text: Testimony of Theophilus, bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1191
verses.text: From his Heortastic Volume:—  "Of unreasoning beings the souls are not taken and replaced: they share in the corruption of the bodies, and are dissolved into dust.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1192
verses.text: But after the Saviour at the time of the cross had taken the soul from His own body, He restored it to the body again when He rose from the dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1193
verses.text: To assure us of this He uttered the words of the psalmist, the predictive exclamation, 'Thou wilt not leave my soul in Hell nor suffer thine Holy One to see corruption.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1194
verses.text: '"  Testimony of the blessed Gelasius, bishop of Caesarea in Palestine:—  "He was bound, He was wounded, He was crucified, He was handled, He was marked with scars, He received a lance's wound, and all these indignities were undergone by the body born of Mary, while that which was begotten from the Father before the ages none was able to harm, for the Word had no such nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1195
verses.text: For how can any one constrain Godhead? How wound it? How make red with blood the incorporeal nature? How surround it with grave bands? Grant now what you cannot contravene and, constrained by invincible reason, honour Godhead".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1196
verses.text: Testimony of the holy John, bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1197
verses.text: From his discourse on the words "My Father worketh hitherto and I work":—  "'What sign shewest Thou unto us seeing that Thou doest these things?' What then does He reply Himself? 'Destroy this temple,' He says, 'and in three days I will raise it up,' speaking of His own body, but they did not understand Him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1198
verses.text: And a little further on:—  "Why does not the evangelist pass this by? Why did he add the correction, 'But He spake of the temple of his body'? for He did not say destroy this 'body,' but 'temple' that He might shew the indwelling God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1199
verses.text: Destroy this temple which is far more excellent than that of the Jews.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1200
verses.text: The Jewish temple contained the Law; this temple contains the Lawgiver; the former the letter that killeth; the latter the spirit that giveth life".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1201
verses.text: Of the same from the discourse "That what was spoken and done in humility was not so done and spoken on account of infirmity of power but different dispensations":—  "How then does He say 'If it be possible'? He is pointing out to us the infirmity of the human nature, which did not choose to be torn away from this present life, but stepped back and shrank on account of the love implanted in it by God in the beginning for the present life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1202
verses.text: If then when the Lord Himself so often spoke in such terms, some have dared to say that He did not take flesh, what would they have said if none of these words had been spoken by Him?"  Of the same from the same work:—  "Observe how they spoke of His former age.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1203
verses.text: Ask the heretic the question Does God dread? Does He draw back? Does He shrink? Does He sorrow? and if he says yes, stand off from him for the future, rank him down below with the devil, aye lower even than the devil, for even the devil will not dare to say this.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1204
verses.text: But, should he say that each of these things is unworthy of God, reply—neither does God pray; for apart from these it will be yet another absurdity should the words be the words of God, for the words indicate not only an agony, but also two wills; one of the Son and another of the Father, opposed to one another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1205
verses.text: For the words 'Not as I will, but as Thou wilt,' are the words of one indicating this".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1206
verses.text: Of the same from the same work:—  "For if this be spoken of the Godhead there arises a certain contradiction, and many absurdities are thereby produced.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1207
verses.text: If on the contrary it be spoken of the flesh, the expressions are reasonable, and no fault can be found with them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1208
verses.text: For the unwillingness of the flesh to die incurs no condemnation; such is the nature of the flesh and He exhibits all the properties of the flesh except sin, and indeed in full abundance, so as to stop the mouths of the heretics.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1209
verses.text: When therefore He says 'If it be possible let this cup pass from me' and 'not as I will but as Thou wilt,' He only shews that He is really clothed with the flesh which fears death, for it is the nature of the flesh to fear death, to draw back and to suffer agony.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1210
verses.text: Now He leaves it abandoned and stripped of its own activity, that by shewing its weakness He may convince us also of its nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1211
verses.text: Sometimes however He conceals it, because He was not mere man".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1212
verses.text: Testimony of Severianus, bishop of Gabala.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1213
verses.text: From his discourse on the seals:—  "The Jews withstand the apparent, ignorant of the non-apparent; they crucify the flesh; they do not destroy the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1214
verses.text: For if my words are not destroyed together with the letter which is the clothing of speech, how could God the Word, the fount of life, die together with the flesh? The passion belongs to the body, but impassibility to the dignity".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1215
verses.text: See then how they whose husbandry is in the East and in the West, as well as in the South and in the North, have all been shewn by us to condemn your vain heresy, and all openly to proclaim the impassibility of the divine Nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1216
verses.text: See how both tongues, I mean both Greek and Latin, make one harmonious confession about the things of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1217
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1218
verses.text: —I am myself astonished at their harmony, but I observe a considerable difference in the terms they use.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1219
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1220
verses.text: —Do not be angry.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1221
verses.text: The very force of their fight against their adversaries is the cause of their seeming immoderate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1222
verses.text: The same thing is to be observed in the case of planters; when they see a plant bent one way or another, they are not satisfied with bringing it to a straight line, but bend it still further in the opposite direction, that by its being bent still further from the straight it may attain its upright stature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1223
verses.text: But that you may know that the very promoters and supporters of this manifold heresy strive to surpass even the heretics of old by the greatness of their blasphemies, listen once more to the writings of Apollinarius which proclaim the impassibility of the divine nature, and confess the passion to be of the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1224
verses.text: Testimony of Apollinarius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1225
verses.text: From his summary:—  "John spoke of the temple which was destroyed, namely the body of Him that raised it, and the body is entirely united to Him and He is not another among them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1226
verses.text: And if the body of the Lord was one with the Lord, the properties of the body were constituted His properties on account of the body".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1227
verses.text: And again:—  "And the truth is that His conjunction with the body does not take place by circumscription of the Word, so that He has nothing beyond His incorporation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1228
verses.text: Wherefore even in death immortality abides with Him; for if He transcends this composition, so does He also the dissolution.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1229
verses.text: Now death is dissolution.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1230
verses.text: But He was not comprehended in the composition; had He been so, the universe would have been made void; nor in the dissolution did He, like the soul, suffer the deprivation which succeeds dissolution".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1231
verses.text: And again:—  "As the Saviour says that the dead bodies go forth from their tombs, though their souls do not go forth thence, just so He says that He Himself will rise from the dead, although it is only His body that rises".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1232
verses.text: In another similar work he writes:—  "Of man is the rising from the dead; of God is the raising.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1233
verses.text: Now Christ both rose and raised, for He was God and man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1234
verses.text: Had the Christ been only man He would not have quickened the dead, and if He had been only God, He would not on His own account apart from the Father have quickened any of the dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1235
verses.text: But Christ did both; the same being is both God and man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1236
verses.text: If the Christ had been only man He would not have saved the world; if He had been only God He would not have saved it through suffering, but Christ did both, so He is God and man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1237
verses.text: If the Christ had been only man or if only God He could not have been a Mediator between men and God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1238
verses.text: And a little further on:—  "Now flesh is an instrument of life fitted to the capacity for suffering in accordance with the divine will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1239
verses.text: Words are not proper to the Flesh, nor are deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1240
verses.text: Being made subject to the capacity for suffering, as is natural to the flesh, it prevails over the suffering because it is the flesh of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1241
verses.text: And again a little further on:—  "The Son took flesh of the Virgin and travelled to the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1242
verses.text: This flesh He filled with the Holy Ghost to the sanctification of us all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1243
verses.text: So He delivered death to death and destroyed death through the resurrection to the raising of us all".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1244
verses.text: From his tract concerning the faith:—  "Since the passions are concerned with the flesh His power possessed its own impassibility, so to refer the passion to the power is an impious error".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1245
verses.text: And in his tract about the incarnation he further writes:—  "Here then He shews that it was the same man who rose from the dead and God who reigns over all creation".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1246
verses.text: You see now that one of the professors of vain heresy plainly preaches the impassibility of the Godhead, calls the body a temple, and persists in maintaining that this body was raised by God the Word.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1247
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1248
verses.text: —I have heard and I am astonished; and I am really ashamed that our doctrines should appear less tenable than the innovation of Apollinarius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1249
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1250
verses.text: —But I will bring you a witness from yet another heretical herd distinctly preaching the impassibility of the Godhead of the only begotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1251
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1252
verses.text: —Whom do you mean?  Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1253
verses.text: —You have probably heard of Eusebius the Phoenician, who was bishop of Emesa by Lebanon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1254
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1255
verses.text: —I have met with some of his writings, and found him to be a supporter of the doctrines of Arius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1256
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1257
verses.text: —Yes; he did belong to that sect, but in his endeavour to prove that the Father was greater than the only begotten he declares the Godhead of the depreciated Son to be impassible and for this opinion he contended with long and extraordinary perseverance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1258
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1259
verses.text: —I should be very much obliged if you would quote his words too.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1260
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1261
verses.text: —To comply with your wish I will adduce somewhat longer evidence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1262
verses.text: Now listen to what he says, and fancy that the man himself is addressing us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1263
verses.text: Testimony of Eusebius of Emesa:—  "Wherefore does he fear death? Lest he suffer anything from death? For what was death to Him? Was it not the severance of the power from the flesh? Did the power receive a nail that it should fear? If our soul suffers not the body's infirmities when united with it, but the eye grows blind and yet the mind retains its force; and a foot is cut off and yet the reasoning power does not halt—and this nature evidences, and the Lord sets His seal on, in the words 'Fear not them which kill the body but are not able to kill the soul' (and if they cannot kill the soul, it is not because they do not wish, but because they are not able, though they would like to make the soul share the suffering of the body yoked with it)—shall He who created the soul and formed the body suffer as the body suffers, although He does take upon Himself the body's sufferings? But Christ suffered for us, and we lie not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1264
verses.text: 'And the bread that I will give is my flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1265
verses.text: ' This He gave for us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1266
verses.text: "That which can be mastered was mastered; that which can be crucified was crucified, but He that had power alike to dwell in it and to leave it said 'Father into thy hands I commend my Spirit,' not into the hands of them who were trying to hasten His death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1267
verses.text: I am not fond of controversy; I rather avoid it; with all gentleness I wish to enquire into the points at issue between us as between brothers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1268
verses.text: Do not I say truly that the power could not be subject to the sufferings of the flesh? I say nothing; let him who will say what the power suffered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1269
verses.text: Did it fail? See the danger.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1270
verses.text: Was it extinct? See the blasphemy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1271
verses.text: Did it no longer exist? This is the death of power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1272
verses.text: Tell me what can so master it that it suffered and I withdraw.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1273
verses.text: But, if you cannot tell me, why do you object to my not telling you? What you cannot tell me, that it did not receive.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1274
verses.text: Drive a nail into a soul and I will admit that it can be driven into power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1275
verses.text: But it was in sympathy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1276
verses.text: Tell me what you mean by 'in sympathy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1277
verses.text: ' As a nail went into the flesh, so pain into the power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1278
verses.text: Let us understand 'was in sympathy' in this sense.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1279
verses.text: Then pain was felt by the power which was not smitten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1280
verses.text: For pain always follows on suffering.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1281
verses.text: But if a body often despises pain while the mind is sound, on account of the vigour of its thought, then in this case let some one explain impartially what suffered and what suffered with or was in sympathy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1282
verses.text: What then? Did not Christ die for us? How did He die? 'Father, into thy hands I commend my Spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1283
verses.text: ' The Spirit departed; the body remained; the body remained without breath.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1284
verses.text: Did He not die then? He died for us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1285
verses.text: The Shepherd offered the sheep, the Priest offered the sacrifice, He gave Himself for us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1286
verses.text: 'He that spared not His own Son but delivered Him up for us all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1287
verses.text: ' I do not reject the words, but I want the meaning of the words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1288
verses.text: The Lord says that the bread of God came down from Heaven, and though I cannot express it more clearly on account of the mysteries, He says in explanation 'It is my flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1289
verses.text: ' Did the flesh of the Son come down from heaven? No.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1290
verses.text: How then does He say, and that in explanation, the bread of God lives and came down from Heaven? He refers the properties of the power to the flesh, because the power which assumed the flesh came down from heaven.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1291
verses.text: Change the terms then; He refers to the power what the flesh suffers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1292
verses.text: How did Christ suffer for us? He was spat upon, He was smitten on the cheek, they put a crown about His brow, His hands and feet were pierced.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1293
verses.text: All these sufferings were of the body, but they are referred to Him that dwelt therein.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1294
verses.text: Throw a stone at the Emperor's statue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1295
verses.text: What is the cry? 'You have insulted the Emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1296
verses.text: ' Tear the Emperor's robe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1297
verses.text: What is the cry? 'You have rebelled against the Emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1298
verses.text: ' Crucify Christ's body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1299
verses.text: What is the cry? 'Christ died for us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1300
verses.text: ' But what need of me and thee? Let us go to the Evangelists.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1301
verses.text: How have you received from the Lord how the Lord died? They read 'Father into thy hands I commend my Spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1302
verses.text: ' The Spirit on high, the body on the Cross for us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1303
verses.text: So far as His body is attributed to Himself He offered the sheep".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1304
verses.text: Of the same from the same book:—  "He came to save our nature; not to destroy His own.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1305
verses.text: If I consent to say that a camel flies, you directly count it strange, because it does not fit in with its nature; and you are quite right.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1306
verses.text: And if I say that men live in the sea you will not accept it; you are quite right.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1307
verses.text: It is contrary to nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1308
verses.text: As then if I say strange things about these natures you count it strange; if I say that the Power which was before the ages, by nature incorporeal, in dignity impassible, which exists with the Father and by the Father's side, on His right hand and in glory, if I say that this incorporeal nature suffers, will you not stop your ears? If you will not stop your ears when you hear this, I shall stop my heart.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1309
verses.text: Can we do anything to an angel? Smite him with a sword? Or cut him in pieces? Why do I say to an angel? Can we to a soul? Does a soul receive a nail? A soul is neither cut nor burnt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1310
verses.text: Do you ask why? Because it was so created.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1311
verses.text: Are His works impassible and He Himself passible? I do not reject the oeconomy; on the contrary, I welcome the ill-treatment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1312
verses.text: Christ died for us and was crucified.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1313
verses.text: So it is written; so the nature admitted.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1314
verses.text: I do not blot out the words nor do I blaspheme the nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1315
verses.text: But this is not true.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1316
verses.text: Very well, then let something truer be said.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1317
verses.text: The teacher is a benefactor, never harsh, never an enemy, unless the pupil be headstrong.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1318
verses.text: Have you anything good to say? My ears are gratefully open.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1319
verses.text: Does any one want to quarrel? Let him quarrel at his leisure.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1320
verses.text: Could the Jews crucify the Son of God and make the power itself a dead body? Can the living die? The death of this power is its failure.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1321
verses.text: Even when we die, our body is left.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1322
verses.text: But if we make that power a dead body we reduce it to non-existence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1323
verses.text: I am afraid you cannot hear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1324
verses.text: If the body die, the soul is separated from it and remains; but if the soul die, since it has no body, it altogether ceases to exist.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1325
verses.text: A soul by dying altogether ceases to be.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1326
verses.text: For the death of the immortals is a contradiction of their existence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1327
verses.text: Consider the alternative; for I do not dare even to mention it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1328
verses.text: We say these things as we understand them, but if any one is contentions, we lay down no law.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1329
verses.text: But I know one thing, that every man must reap the fruit of his opinions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1330
verses.text: Each man comes to God and brings before Him what he has said and thought about Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1331
verses.text: Do not suppose that God reads books, or is troubled by having to recollect what you said or who heard you: all is made manifest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1332
verses.text: The judge is on the throne.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1333
verses.text: Paulus is brought before Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1334
verses.text: 'Thou saidst I was a man; thou hast no life with Me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1335
verses.text: Thou knewest not Me; I know not thee.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1336
verses.text: ' Up comes another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1337
verses.text: 'Thou saidst I was one of the things that are created.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1338
verses.text: Thou knewest not My dignity; I know not thee.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1339
verses.text: ' Up comes another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1340
verses.text: 'Thou saidst that I did not assume a body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1341
verses.text: Thou madest light of My grace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1342
verses.text: Thou shalt not share My immortality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1343
verses.text: ' Up comes another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1344
verses.text: 'Thou saidst that I was not born of a Virgin to save the body of the Virgin; thou shalt not be saved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1345
verses.text: ' Each one reaps the fruit of his opinions about the faith".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1346
verses.text: You see the other sect of your teachers, in which you supposed that you had learnt the suffering of the Godhead of the only Begotten, abhors this blasphemy, preaches the impassibility of the Godhead, and quits the ranks of them who dare to attribute the passion to it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1347
verses.text: Eran.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1348
verses.text: —Yes; I am astonished at the conflict, and I admire the man's sense and opinions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1349
verses.text: Orth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1350
verses.text: —Then, my good Sir, imitate the bees.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1351
verses.text: As you flit in mental flight about the meads of the divine Scripture, among the fair flowers of these illustrious Fathers, build us in your heart the honey-comb of the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1352
verses.text: If haply you find anywhere herbage bitter and not fit to eat, like these fellows Apollinarius and Eusebius, but still not quite without something that may be meet for making honey, it is reasonable that you should sip the sweet and leave the poisonous behind, like bees who lighting often on baneful bushes leave all the deadly bane behind and gather all the good.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1353
verses.text: We give you this advice, dear friend, in brotherly kindness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1354
verses.text: Receive it and you will do well.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1355
verses.text: And if you hearken not we will say to you in the word of the apostle "We are pure".

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 4:1356
verses.text: We have spoken, as the prophet says, what we have been commanded.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:1
verses.text: Demonstrations by Syllogisms.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:2
verses.text: That God the Word is Immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:3
verses.text: We have confessed one substance of the Father, of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost, and have agreed that it is immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:4
verses.text: If then there is one substance of the Trinity, and it is immutable, then the only begotten Son, who is one person of the Trinity, is immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:5
verses.text: And, if He is immutable, He was not made flesh by mutation, but is said to have been made flesh after taking flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:6
verses.text: If God the Word was made flesh by undergoing mutation into flesh, then He is not immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:7
verses.text: For no one in his senses would call that which undergoes alteration immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:8
verses.text: And if He is mutable He is not of one substance with Him that begat Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:9
verses.text: How indeed is it possible for one part of an uncompounded substance to be mutable and the other immutable? If we grant this we shall fall headlong into the blasphemy of Arius and Eunomius, who assert that the Son is of another substance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:10
verses.text: If the Lord is consubstantial with the Father, and the Son was made flesh by undergoing change into flesh, then the substance is at once mutable and immutable, which blasphemy if any one has the hardihood to maintain, he will no doubt make it worse by his blasphemy against the Father, for inasmuch as the Father shares the same substance, he will assuredly call Him mutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:11
verses.text: It is written in the divine Scriptures that God the Word took flesh, and also a soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:12
verses.text: And the most divine Evangelist says the Word was made flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:13
verses.text: We must therefore perforce do one of two things: either we must admit the mutation of the Word into flesh, and reject all divine Scripture, both Old and New, as teaching lies, or in obedience to the divine Scripture, we must confess the assumption of the flesh, banishing mutation from our thoughts, and piously regarding the word of the Evangelist.

verses.name: Theodoret: Dialogues 5:14
